\">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 21 Sep 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5ab914ce-204e-40ef-acfe-d7bfec642e1a.png","linkMd5":"b4d9e3e9db9a88cf27159e4ff10a3d3c","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn75@2020_2/2021/09/27/16-55-41-723_2587ed1ca9337960.webp","destWidth":690,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":7017,"destBytes":11032,"author":"Caroline Forsey","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5ab914ce-204e-40ef-acfe-d7bfec642e1a.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn75@2020_2/2021/09/27/16-55-41-723_2587ed1ca9337960.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Are%20Employees%20More%20or%20Less%20Productive%20Than%20They%20Were%20in%202020%3F%20How%20Marketers%20Can%20Navigate%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-3.png?width=624&height=416&name=Are%20Employees%20More%20or%20Less%20Productive%20Than%20They%20Were%20in%202020%3F%20How%20Marketers%20Can%20Navigate%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn30@2020_2/2021/09/27/16-55-45-532_02d131ea1681ff20.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Are%20Employees%20More%20or%20Less%20Productive%20Than%20They%20Were%20in%202020%3F%20How%20Marketers%20Can%20Navigate%20%5BNew%20Data%5D.png?width=624&height=416&name=Are%20Employees%20More%20or%20Less%20Productive%20Than%20They%20Were%20in%202020%3F%20How%20Marketers%20Can%20Navigate%20%5BNew%20Data%5D.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn87@2020_6/2021/09/27/16-55-44-879_4a2350049deb5f0c.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/how%20to%20boost%20team%20productivity%20in%202022%20according%20to%20hubspot%20manager%20Charlene%20Strain.png?width=1104&name=how%20to%20boost%20team%20productivity%20in%202022%20according%20to%20hubspot%20manager%20Charlene%20Strain.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn93@2020_6/2021/09/27/16-55-48-255_c0446ae25a8cb932.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Are%20Employees%20More%20or%20Less%20Productive%20Than%20They%20Were%20in%202020%3F%20How%20Marketers%20Can%20Navigate%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-2.png?width=671&name=Are%20Employees%20More%20or%20Less%20Productive%20Than%20They%20Were%20in%202020%3F%20How%20Marketers%20Can%20Navigate%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn67@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-43-981_6877b8ea0d35f1bb.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/how%20to%20boost%20team%20productivity%20in%202022%20according%20to%20hubspot%20manager%20Meg%20Prater.png?width=1104&name=how%20to%20boost%20team%20productivity%20in%202022%20according%20to%20hubspot%20manager%20Meg%20Prater.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn77@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-45-563_ff9e9843b63ed22c.webp","https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/iLLVXuvxWTAB7N2xtEmm9696TzhNW-VlWCpiLdF7G9GdNPgY1RuMJnShHf6EdcN5u-fr_vHEF-zB23p0GYIxZ30RQ9tdOVmDxQy9PT8BTkML5iJAkJE3swkml_zs8L6CQBDEuMp5=s0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn2@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-43-935_bfd69ba5a4398138.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3d8890a4-b446-496e-b60f-a8a7ee44ae85.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn13@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-48-927_d4985b3af97d5b9c.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fteam-productivity-shifts&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn65@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-46-357_52287a5d249db7b0.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1632761741234},{"createdTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","updatedTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","title":"How to Create Landing Pages for Real Estate [+Examples]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/real-estate-landing-pages","description":"<p>When people are looking to buy or rent a new house, what's the first thing they do? That's right, they go online.</p> \n<p>In fact, <a href=\"https://marclyman.com/how-buyers-find-homes/\">51% of home searches</a> start on the internet. People search Zillow, Apartments.com, Redfin, and local real estate websites.</p> \n<p>Additionally, people also turn to the internet when they want to value their home or learn more about the real estate market.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>All this to say that when it's time to generate leads in the real estate industry, posting online and creating a landing page is the first step.</p> \n<p>In this post, we'll discuss how to create a landing page for real estate and review sample real estate landing pages to inspire your own.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=5f39ea20-9313-42f4-b9c7-86b8b59e717a&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Free Resource: Real Estate Strategy Template\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5f39ea20-9313-42f4-b9c7-86b8b59e717a.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p></p> \n<h3>1. Choose the type of landing page you need.</h3> \n<p>Before you can get started, it's important to understand the different types of real estate landing pages.</p> \n<p>The three main types include:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Home valuation:</strong> This type of landing page lets users type in their address and get a quick idea of how much their home is worth.</li> \n <li><strong>Buying/selling websites:</strong> These websites are where buyers and sellers go to place listings online, including Zillow or Redfin.</li> \n <li><strong>Free content:</strong> This landing page is usually targeted toward those who want to start working in the real estate industry <em>or</em> are in the beginning stages of buying/selling. You can place free content on a landing page to get leads to download the offer so when the time comes to buy or sell, they think of you.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Depending on the type of landing page you need, the process and design will be a little different.</p> \n<h3>2. Use a simple lead capture form and search function.</h3> \n<p>When creating a landing page for real estate, the goal is to gain leads through a lead capture form asking for information (whether it be a name, email, or phone number). The first step to doing this is to have simple search functionality that is front and center in your design for home buying/selling or home valuation.</p> \n<p>If you're creating a landing page for free content, you won't need a search function, but you will need a lead capture form that is simple and easy to use (this should also be a large part of your design that is easy to see).</p> \n<p>The simplicity of the search function or lead capture form will make your call to action (CTA) stand out and get people searching through your site.</p> \n<p>With Zillow, the home page has a simple search function so homebuyers can search for houses in a certain area. This keeps the site clean and it gets straight to the point -- no distractions.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"real estate landing pages: zillow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Create%20Landing%20Pages%20for%20Real%20Estate%20%5B+Examples%5D-3.png?width=624&amp;height=216&amp;name=How%20to%20Create%20Landing%20Pages%20for%20Real%20Estate%20%5B+Examples%5D-3.png\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" title=\"\" width=\"624\" height=\"216\"></p> \n<h3>3. Always pay attention to curb appeal.</h3> \n<p>Everyone knows that curb appeal is important when it comes to buying or selling a home. The same holds true for your landing page. Use clear, crisp imagery that inspires home buyers to imagine their new life in the house you're selling. When this happens, buyers are more likely to convert.</p> \n<p>The visual design of your landing page is even more important than most landing pages. If people don't like the design of the landing page, they might not even like the house because they can't see past the poor web design.</p> \n<h3>4. Write honest copy.</h3> \n<p>The copy you write for each house should be honest. You'll want to include detailed information and use descriptive adjectives that will paint a picture for prospective buyers. But don't embellish.</p> \n<p>When people start visiting your house they'll see what's true and what isn't. If you aren't being honest in your copy, then people won't want to work with you because they can't trust you. You should use short copy that's punchy and to the point.</p> \n<p>Buying or selling a home is a major financial and life decision. Trust is of the utmost importance between you and your prospective leads.</p> \n<h3>5. Include testimonials.</h3> \n<p>Although most home buying efforts begin online, most people hire real estate agents through referrals. In fact, <a href=\"https://www.refermeiq.com/resources/real-estate-statistics-you-must-know/\">42% of sellers</a> who use real estate agents find these agents through referrals and <a href=\"https://www.refermeiq.com/resources/real-estate-statistics-you-must-know/\">82% of all real estate transactions</a> come from referrals. This means that customer testimonials and reviews are very important. On your landing page, include testimonials so visitors know they can trust you.</p> \n<p>It's a particularly good idea to place testimonials near your CTA, so it motivates people to click on your form.</p> \n<p>You can also place badges or awards on your landing pages to instill a sense of professionalism and credibility.</p> \n<h3>6. Highlight the benefits of your offer.</h3> \n<p>Depending on the type of landing page, you might need to highlight the benefit of your content offer. For example, if you have a home valuation calculator, it's important to write copy that emphasizes why this will give a seller more power in the process. Or if you're giving away a free checklist or ebook, explain how it helps people in the process of buying or selling.</p> \n<p>This is how you'll communicate your value with your leads, which will inspire them to convert.</p> \n<h3>7. Be personal.</h3> \n<p>The intent of your landing page is important. Your landing page will look different if it's a home valuation, buying/selling, or content offer page. The point of creating a landing page is to create a personal experience for those interested in certain offers.</p> \n<p>That's why landing pages are different from your everyday website. These pages keep customers focused on going down the path they want: searching for a home, getting in contact with an agent, etc.</p> \n<p>Additionally, the design of your landing page should be personalized to the experience of the viewer. This means that your page should be optimized for mobile, tablet, and desktop experiences. You might also have an app that will help your visitors come back anytime they're looking for a home.</p> \n<h2>Best Real Estate Landing Pages</h2> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"https://www.redfin.com/what-is-my-home-worth\">Redfin Home Valuation Landing Page</a></h3> \n<p>Talk about a simple landing page. This is a no-fuss home valuation landing page that lets visitors get a real-time estimate of how much their home is worth.</p> \n<p>This landing page is a good example of being simple, using short, punchy text and engaging graphics to draw attention to the simple CTA of entering a home address.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"real estate landing pages: redfin\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Create%20Landing%20Pages%20for%20Real%20Estate%20%5B+Examples%5D.png?width=624&amp;name=How%20to%20Create%20Landing%20Pages%20for%20Real%20Estate%20%5B+Examples%5D.png\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" title=\"\" width=\"624\"></p> \n<h3>2. <a href=\"http://hillrealtygrp.com/\">Hill Realty Group</a></h3> \n<p>This is a great example of a realty group's home search landing page. First, it focuses on the curb appeal of the properties and areas that it sells houses in. Then, it includes a simple property search where you can include your location, bed and bath requirements, etc.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"real estate landing pages: hill realty group\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Create%20Landing%20Pages%20for%20Real%20Estate%20%5B+Examples%5D-2.png?width=624&amp;name=How%20to%20Create%20Landing%20Pages%20for%20Real%20Estate%20%5B+Examples%5D-2.png\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" title=\"\" width=\"624\"></p> \n<h3>3. <a href=\"http://www.localgirlguide.com/\">The H. Williams Group</a></h3> \n<p>This is a sample real estate landing page with a content offer. This realtor has a simple lead capture form enticing visitors to download her guide to Alexandria. This is a great content offer because people looking for a guide to the area are most likely going to move there and may contact her to be their realtor.</p> \n<p>Additionally, this page is great because all the focus is on the simple capture form. The design is sleek and simple, with a logo, picture, headline, and capture form. That's it. That's why this landing page works.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"real estate landing pages: the H Williams group\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Create%20Landing%20Pages%20for%20Real%20Estate%20%5B+Examples%5D-1.png?width=624&amp;name=How%20to%20Create%20Landing%20Pages%20for%20Real%20Estate%20%5B+Examples%5D-1.png\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" title=\"\" width=\"624\"></p> \n<p>Creating a real estate landing page is very important for marketing your listings or offers. That's why it's important to create a landing page that will convert visitors into buyers.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=bda2ff96-1786-4644-9d40-c4ccd7b7f376&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New call-to-action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/bda2ff96-1786-4644-9d40-c4ccd7b7f376.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Freal-estate-landing-pages&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 17 Sep 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5f39ea20-9313-42f4-b9c7-86b8b59e717a.png","linkMd5":"a791c9db13ade3e6931231144a4532e6","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn60@2020_5/2021/09/27/16-55-42-300_1228983177d052d6.webp","destWidth":408,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":4511,"destBytes":6278,"author":"Rebecca Riserbato","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5f39ea20-9313-42f4-b9c7-86b8b59e717a.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn60@2020_5/2021/09/27/16-55-42-300_1228983177d052d6.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Create%20Landing%20Pages%20for%20Real%20Estate%20%5B+Examples%5D-3.png?width=624&height=216&name=How%20to%20Create%20Landing%20Pages%20for%20Real%20Estate%20%5B+Examples%5D-3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn42@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-49-157_c74f0b0bd97469b6.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Create%20Landing%20Pages%20for%20Real%20Estate%20%5B+Examples%5D.png?width=624&name=How%20to%20Create%20Landing%20Pages%20for%20Real%20Estate%20%5B+Examples%5D.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn44@2020_2/2021/09/27/16-55-46-512_7e1df1dc68ba5213.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Create%20Landing%20Pages%20for%20Real%20Estate%20%5B+Examples%5D-2.png?width=624&name=How%20to%20Create%20Landing%20Pages%20for%20Real%20Estate%20%5B+Examples%5D-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn19@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-47-059_d61fa194c91d0676.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Create%20Landing%20Pages%20for%20Real%20Estate%20%5B+Examples%5D-1.png?width=624&name=How%20to%20Create%20Landing%20Pages%20for%20Real%20Estate%20%5B+Examples%5D-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn20@2020_6/2021/09/27/16-55-46-239_9de68223b85b4294.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/bda2ff96-1786-4644-9d40-c4ccd7b7f376.png":null,"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Freal-estate-landing-pages&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn42@2020_2/2021/09/27/16-55-45-488_9066e422a651b80d.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1632761741221},{"createdTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","updatedTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","title":"20 Tips to Write Catchy Email Subject Lines [+ Examples]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/improve-your-email-subject-line","description":"<p>No matter what they say, people <em>do</em> judge emails by their subject lines.</p> \n<p>In fact,<a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/marketing-statistics\"> </a><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/marketing-statistics?_ga=2.184235814.1655989913.1631573248-924166743.1631573248\">47% of marketers</a> say they test different email subject lines to optimize their emails' performance. That's why it's so important to craft subject lines that are compelling enough to get people to click through.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>While they may seem like a small part of your message, they're one of the very first impressions you have on your email recipients. And, they're a marketer's ticket for standing out in a crowded inbox.</p> \n<p>Do you want your email content opened, read, and clicked? It all starts with the subject line. Read on for some tried-and-true tips to help jazz up your subject lines and boost your email engagement.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=c706e2ec-2e42-4977-a207-44505d19f1fe&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Download Now: 100 Email Subject Line Examples\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/c706e2ec-2e42-4977-a207-44505d19f1fe.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<h2>What makes a good email subject line?</h2> \n<p>Before we get to our tips, let's go over some fundamentals of what makes a great subject line. Regardless of your goals, these are the essential elements that your subject line should possess:</p> \n<h3>1. Urgency</h3> \n<p>Creating a sense of urgency is an efficient way to get people to take action. You can create a similar effect in your subject lines strategically.</p> \n<p>By communicating a known start and end date to a special sale or promotion, viewers scrolling through their inbox will click to see what they can get in that window of time. This is also a good practice when done in a small series of emails counting down the window of opportunity — as long as you’re not flooding their inbox and coming off spammy.</p> \n<h3>2. Curiosity</h3> \n<p>Sometimes, subject lines work because of their ability to send the message, \"You will benefit from opening this email.\" But other times, it's good to maintain some sense of mystery — especially if it pique's the recipient's natural curiosity and interest. Because they require opening the email to get more information, they can result in, well, a higher open rate. But make sure the subject line, while enigmatic, still aligns with your brand. Too obscure, and it could end up being seen as spam.</p> \n<h3>3. Offers</h3> \n<p>Here's where that benefit of opening a given email comes in. At the end of the day, people love new things and experiences — especially when they’re free, or at least discounted. Open with that by including it in your subject line. Personally, I'm much more inclined to open my daily newsletters when there's an offer or allusion for \"free stuff\" directly mentioned in my inbox.</p> \n<h3>4. Personalization</h3> \n<p>No two email subscribers are the same — and, sometimes, that means the emails you send to them shouldn't be, either. At this point, marketers have never had more ways to learn about their subscribers' preferences, jobs, or general (dis)likes. So when you send them content, on occasion, make it catered toward the individual.</p> \n<h3>5. Relevance and Timeliness</h3> \n<p>When we subscribe to an email list, it's usually because we want to be kept informed, or at least learn more about a given topic (more on that later). Similar to piquing your audience's curiosity, crafting email subject lines that incorporate trending topics or timely headlines can help you establish your brand as an authority within your industry — and can compel people to click to read.</p> \n<h3>6. Name Recognition</h3> \n<p>Let's face it: We all have famous people who, at some point, we presently or previously have admired. And when you understand your audience's preferences and interests, you can pique their interest by including the names of these admired, recognizable individuals by including them in your content — and mentioning them in your email subject lines. But take heed: This tactic really only works when it aligns with your brand, product, or service. So keep it relevant, rather than just throwing out a name for the sake of recognition.</p> \n<h3>7. Cool Stories</h3> \n<p>At the risk of sounding like a broken record, here's another place where curiosity comes into play. By front-loading your email subject line with a compelling allusion to a story — but can only be read if opened or clicked — your audience is likely to become intrigued, and want to learn more. Again, make sure the story is relevant to your brand. Otherwise, it might just confuse your readers and prevent them from opening the email.</p> \n<p>Now that you know the fundamentals, let’s dive into email subject line best practices.</p> \n<h2>Email Subject Line Best Practices</h2> \n<h3>1. Learn from successful email subject line examples.</h3> \n<p>Whenever we're scratching our heads wondering what to make our subject line, we often look to examples for inspiration. Seeing clever use of wordplay or emojis on one of our favorite newsletters can help us think of new ways to approach our subject line.</p> \n<p>To help you do the same, we've compiled a list of 100 email subject lines from real businesses. We hope you'll be just as inspired.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/email-subject-lines?hubs_post-cta=image\"><img alt=\"email subject lines examples\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-3.png?width=387&amp;name=20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-3.png\" title=\"\" width=\"387\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 387px;\"></a></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/email-subject-lines?hubs_post-cta=imagebottom\">Download the Free Email Subject Lines Examples Guide</a></p> \n<h3>2. Keep it short and sweet.</h3> \n<p>Email subject lines will get cut off if they're too long, particularly on mobile devices. And with up to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/email-marketing-stats?__hstc=200701681.08ac1cb1ea51df337b2af750beceb4f1.1631049039709.1631049039709.1631049039709.1&amp;__hssc=200701681.1.1631049039710&amp;__hsfp=988172843\">46% of email opens</a> taking place on mobile, we recommend using subject lines with fewer than 50 characters to make sure the people scanning your emails read the entire message.</p> \n<p>If you're struggling to keep your subject lines short, think about which words matter less and where you can remove a frivolous detail. For example, if you're sending an order confirmation, doesn't “Your order is being processed” look better than “Order #9435893458358 is being processed\"?</p> \n<p>The same goes for your regular emails: Don't waste your time including the word \"update\" or \"newsletter\" in the subject line. Some studies even suggest these words can decrease the message's open rate since it tells readers the email is associated with a series, and therefore they can catch the next one.</p> \n<h3>3. Use a familiar sender name.</h3> \n<p>That name recognition we mentioned earlier doesn't just apply to the famous — it applies to the familiar. When setting your sender name, be as human as you can. Olivia@yourcompany.com is both inviting and unintimidating to people when they open their inboxes.</p> \n<p>If you've already met your recipients from a previous conversation, use your own name as the sender's address — even if the email is technically coming from the company as a whole. The best impression you can make on your customers is that they're working with you, the individual — not the entire business.</p> \n<p>\"If the 'from' name doesn't sound like it's from someone you want to hear from, it doesn't matter what the subject line is,\" explains <span style=\"font-style: italic;\">Copy Hacker</span>'s<a href=\"https://litmus.com/blog/how-to-write-captivating-email-subject-lines\"> </a><a href=\"https://litmus.com/blog/how-to-write-captivating-email-subject-lines\">Joanna Wiebe</a>. Ultimately, people are busy, and they simply don't bother with you if you don't sound like someone who would make for an easy (or at least friendly) conversation.</p> \n<h3>4. Avoid the 'no-reply' sender name.</h3> \n<p>Thanks to the amount of spam people get these days, most people hesitate to open emails from unfamiliar senders. And, even fewer people like talking to a robot. Think about when you call a company and can't get a hold of an actual person. It's frustrating, right? This goes for email, as well.</p> \n<p>Never use \"noreply@company.com.\" I repeat: <em>Never</em> use this email address. Not only does it make it look less personable, but it also stops people from adding your email to their address book.</p> \n<p>Instead, avoid using a generic email address and send the email from a real person. For instance,<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/31634/A-B-Testing-in-Action-3-Real-Life-Marketing-Experiments.aspx\"> </a><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/31634/A-B-Testing-in-Action-3-Real-Life-Marketing-Experiments.aspx\">we once found that</a> emails sent from \"Maggie Georgieva, HubSpot\" performed better in terms of opens and click-through rate than emails sent from just \"HubSpot.\" (<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">HubSpot customers</span>: Learn how to personalize the \"From\" name and email address<a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/articles/kcs_article/email/how-do-i-personalize-the-from-name-and-address-in-an-email\"> </a><a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/articles/kcs_article/email/how-do-i-personalize-the-from-name-and-address-in-an-email\">here</a>.)</p> \n<h3>5. Use personalization tokens.</h3> \n<p>Remember the personalization we mentioned earlier? Using personalization tokens — like name or location — in the subject line adds a feeling of rapport, especially when it's a name. Everyone loves the sound of their own name. Plus, it increases clickthrough rate: In fact, research has shown that emails that included the first name of the recipient in their subject line had<a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/science-of-email-marketing-2014-report\"> </a><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/science-of-email-marketing-2014-report\">higher click-through rates</a> than emails that did not.</p> \n<p>One example of how brands affix this information to subject lines is the dog-walking company, Wag! who does this with dog names. Here's one such email that a HubSpot writer received:</p> \n<p><img alt=\"Email newsletter by Wag dog-walking service with pet name in the subject line\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-1.png?width=624&amp;name=20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-1.png\" title=\"\" width=\"624\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>That's great personalization and great timing.</p> \n<p>Another personalization tactic that works is to tailor subject lines to the recipient's location — things like lists of their respective cities' best outdoor bars and restaurants.</p> \n<p>Just don't go overboard with the personalization here. That can be a little creepy. But little personalized touches show that you know more about your recipients than just their email address. However, if you can't (or don't want to) use personalization tokens in the subject line, use \"you\" or \"your\" so it still sounds like you're addressing them directly.</p> \n<h3>6. Segment your lists.</h3> \n<p>While email blasts that go out to your entire list might be relevant and helpful to some people, it won't be to others — and could cause confusion or frustration. Why is this restaurant sending me a list of the best local steakhouses when I'm a vegetarian? Why is this company sending me case studies when I just signed up for its email list yesterday?</p> \n<p>Personalize the experience using information from the actions your customers have already taken — from which forms they've filled out, to which industries they're in, to what their personal preferences are. In<a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/email\"> </a><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/email\">email marketing</a>, you can personalize your recipients' experience using a little thing called <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33083/27-Ways-to-Slice-Dice-Your-Email-List-for-Better-Segmentation.aspx#sm.0000o5c3iom8gdkipdw2l236rj19q\">list segmentation</a>.</p> \n<h3>7. Don't make false promises.</h3> \n<p>Your email subject line is making a promise to your reader about what you will deliver in your message. Make sure that you make good on that commitment — and do not try to get your email opened by making false promises. This will irk your audience, and they'll learn not to trust your subject lines, resulting in a lower open rate and a higher unsubscribe rate.</p> \n<h3>8. Do tell them what's inside.</h3> \n<p>Speaking of making promises, if your visitor has downloaded an offer and you're delivering it via email, it's a great idea to use a subject line that says something like, “Your new ebook inside!” or, “Your guide awaits!” This works better than a simple “thank you” in the subject line because it makes it clear that something is waiting inside the email.</p> \n<h3>9. Time it right.</h3> \n<p>Sending an email at the<em> right </em>time with the <em>right</em> subject line can make a huge difference in open and click-through rate. A prime example? When food publication Eater sends at 6:45 P.M. on a Wednesday evening that said, \"Where to Drink Beer Right Now\" — just in time for happy hour. Nailed it.</p> \n<p>Another favorite example is a classic email from Warby Parker with the subject line, \"Uh-oh, your prescription is expiring.\" It was sent two weeks before the recipient needed to renew his prescription. By sending an email at the right time, Warby Parker increased the chances of their email getting opened — and included a relevant call-to-action about getting a glasses upgrade, too.</p> \n<h3>10. Use concise language.</h3> \n<p>Keep in mind that people scan their inboxes very quickly — so the more clear and concise your subject line is, the better. It's usually a lot better to be concise than it is to use complex and flowery language — unless you're going for an elusive subject tone to entice your recipients.</p> \n<p>When you're going for a concise subject line, think about how your email will benefit your recipients. You'll want to make that benefit very clear. For example, \"Increase your open rates by 50% today” is more appealing than \"How to increase open rates.\"</p> \n<h3>11. Start with action-oriented verbs.</h3> \n<p>Subject lines are similar to calls-to-action, in that you want the language to inspire people to click. Subject lines that begin with action verbs tend to be a lot more enticing, and your emails could be drastically more clickable by adding a vibrant verb at the beginning.</p> \n<p>Actionable subject lines will inspire people to click on your email by instilling urgency and excitement. For example, in an email inviting people to a hockey legend dinner, the email subject line might read, “Dine with Bruins legend Bobby Orr,” rather than a more generic (and less actionable) “Local Boston Sports Legend Meal.\" The former email uses “Dine” to help the reader envision themselves at a dinner table.</p> \n<h3>12. Make people feel special.</h3> \n<p>The psychology of exclusivity is a powerful thing. When people feel like they're on the inside, it gives them a sense of belonging which builds loyalty and compels them to convert on your emails.</p> \n<p>The right phrasing can make your recipients feel special — and the effect can be magical. A few ideas for phrasing include:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>\"For our beloved customers only\"</li> \n <li>\"An exclusive offer for you\"</li> \n <li>\"My gift to you\"</li> \n <li>\"You're invited!\"</li> \n <li>\"Private invite\"</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>13. Create a sense of importance.</h3> \n<p>There's a phrase that, for many of us, is reminiscent of classic infomercials: \"Act now!\"</p> \n<p>And while we wouldn't encourage using that exact language in your content, we do agree that communicating urgency and scarcity in an email subject line can help compel readers to click (or act) — when phrased creatively and strategically.</p> \n<p>But because you don't want to be known as \"the brand that cried wolf,\" use these subject lines sparingly, and try to limit them to when the occasion genuinely calls for immediate action.</p> \n<h3>14. Use numbers.</h3> \n<p>A lot of businesses send emails with vague statements in their subject lines — which is why using data and numbers is a great way to get your emails noticed, demonstrate a clear and straightforward message about your offer, and set the right expectations.</p> \n<p>Just like with blog titles, using numbers in your subject line is an effective email marketing best practice. You might use numbers to refer to the title of your listicle, the page length of an offer, a specific discount, or the numerical benefit of a particular resource you're providing — like \"Join more than 750 others at this event!\"</p> \n<h3>15. Pose a compelling question.</h3> \n<p>Asking a question in your subject line can also draw readers in — especially if you're asking a question you know is relevant to your recipients' buyer persona. This is just one way to pique that curiosity we mentioned earlier. For example, you might try the following: “Are you making these SEO mistakes?” or “Do you know what your website is doing wrong?\"</p> \n<p>Zillow once sent an email with the subject line, \"What Can You Afford?\" that linked to a website showing apartments for rent. A subject line like this is both encouraging and a touch competitive: While it gives hope that there are apartments out there that'll fit within your budget, it also pits your cash against what the market offers.</p> \n<p>Another example comes from DocuSign. It sent an email late in the lead nurturing process, with the subject line, \"What are your customers saying?\" The body of the email contained<a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/ultimate-case-study-creation-kit\"> </a><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/ultimate-case-study-creation-kit\">a bunch of case studies</a> that were meant to help the recipient move closer to actually purchasing DocuSign. This was a smart move: Folks who are further down the funnel are likely more receptive to hearing customer testimonials.</p> \n<h3>16. Don't be afraid to get punny.</h3> \n<p>Most people love a good pun. It's a great way to delight your recipients and spice up your emails. Some of the best punny email subject lines come from JetBlue, with subject lines like \"Land wander-ful low fares now!\"</p> \n<p>Quirky — a community-led invention platform — worded one of its email subject lines like this: \"Abra-cord-abra! Yeah, we said it.\" That second part is conversational and self-referential — and exactly what most people would say after making a really cheesy joke in real life.</p> \n<p>If you're the least bit punny, think about small ways you can slip them into your emails when it's appropriate. Just don't overdo it. And remember the rule: When in doubt, ask a coworker.</p> \n<h3>17. DON'T USE ALL CAPS or overuse exclamation points!!!</h3> \n<p>A subject line that says, “OPEN NOW AND RECEIVE A FREE TRIAL” or, \"50% off coupon today only!!!!!!!!\" isn't going to get your email opened. If anything, it'll probably get your email ignored.</p> \n<p>Why? People don't like to be yelled at, and using all caps and/or a lot of exclamation points can rub people the wrong way.</p> \n<p>Not only are these tactics disruptive, but they look spammy. So instead of using disruptive tactics like these to stand out in people's inboxes, try personalizing your emails, establishing relevance, and using catchy and delightful language.</p> \n<h3>18. Don't include a question and exclamation in the same subject line.</h3> \n<p>Here's a subject line that can automatically wind up in a recipient's spam folder: <em>\"Want a solution fast? Act now!\"</em></p> \n<p>The fast solution isn't the problem in the example above. It's also not “act now” — although those are known email marketing spam words. It's both phrases together. This is a classic email saboteur, and it comes in many forms. All you need is to ask and yell at the same time.</p> \n<p>Oftentimes webservers flag emails as spam if they contain both a question mark and an exclamation mark in the subject line. The example above is a common one. A good solution? Don't do that!</p> \n<p>Not only is this format overdone, but it's alienating to your audience. Open-ended questions are a show of ignorance; any good marketer knows their leads better than that.</p> \n<h3>19. Use engaging preview text.</h3> \n<p>While preview text isn't technically part of your subject line, it does appear right near the subject line — and it certainly deserves your attention.</p> \n<p>Preview text provides recipients with a peek at the content inside your email, which email clients like the iPhone Mail app, Gmail, and Outlook will display alongside the subject line. (The exact amount of text shown depends on the email client and user settings.)</p> \n<p><img alt=\"email preview text in inbox\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-2.png?width=624&amp;name=20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-2.png\" title=\"\" width=\"624\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>When you don't set the preview text yourself, the email client will automatically pull from the body of your email. That can look messy depending on your email content, and it's also a wasted opportunity to engage your audience. (<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">HubSpot customers</span>:<a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/articles/KCS_Article/Email/What-is-the-Secondary-Content-Preview-Text-section-of-my-email\"> </a><a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/articles/KCS_Article/Email/What-is-the-Secondary-Content-Preview-Text-section-of-my-email\">Click here</a> to learn how to set the preview text of your emails.)</p> \n<h3>20. A/B test your subject lines.</h3> \n<p>Although these tips and best practices are a great place to start, what works best for some companies may not work as well for others. It's all about figuring out what works best for your specific audience. That's where <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-do-a-b-testing\">A/B testing</a> comes in.</p> \n<p>While it can be tempting to use your intuition to predict what subject line language will make people click on your emails, you should always A/B test your highest-stakes subject lines, and tweak the wording according to your results. What works best for your audience: Long or short subject lines? Including numbers or not including numbers? Questions or statements? (<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">HubSpot customers</span>: Learn how to A/B test emails in HubSpot<a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/email-user-guide-v2/how-to-utilize-ab-testing-in-email\"> </a><a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/email-user-guide-v2/how-to-utilize-ab-testing-in-email\">here</a>.)</p> \n<p>Now that we’ve gone through our best practices, let’s review the steps to creating good email subject lines.</p> \n<h2>How to Write Good Email Subject Lines</h2> \n<h3>Step 1: Identify the purpose of the email.</h3> \n<p>Why is the email being sent and how does that inform the subject line? Identify the true purpose or intention of the email and use that as the foundation to build upon when brainstorming your subject line idea.</p> \n<h3>Step 2: Determine the call to action.</h3> \n<p>What will make the user click on the email? A discount? Something free? Important information? What is enticing enough to make them want to see or learn more about your offer? Having a call to action with an incentive yet to be seen is tempting.</p> \n<h3>Step 3: Draft multiple subject lines.</h3> \n<p>Write similar subject lines that use varying words and tones. You want to have a few ideas to choose from, so you’re not stuck stewing over the same sentence for long.</p> \n<h3>Step 4: Get feedback.</h3> \n<p>Have colleagues review the subject lines to give their feedback on which they preferred. Having a second opinion can help you see it from a different perspective.</p> \n<h3>Step 5: Test your subject line.</h3> \n<p>As mentioned earlier, perform an <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-do-a-b-testing\">A/B test</a> to see which subject line performs best. After you’ve conducted the test, take the most effective email subject line and use it in your upcoming email marketing campaign.</p> \n<p>Now that we’ve gone through the steps to create a good subject line, let’s examine some effective examples.</p> \n<h2>Examples of Catchy Email Subject Lines</h2> \n<p>To give you some added inspiration, here's a quick list of the most intriguing subject lines we've seen recently.</p> \n<h3>EF Tours: “👻 Trip or Treat!”</h3> \n<p><img alt=\"examples of catchy email subject lines: EF Tours\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-Sep-13-2021-10-48-05-88-PM.png?width=636&amp;name=20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-Sep-13-2021-10-48-05-88-PM.png\" title=\"\" width=\"636\" style=\"width: 636px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>This subject line from EF Tours has tasteful use of a quirky emoji, coupled with a sense of urgency from a time-bound sale. These two tricks create an email subject line that would stand out from the rest of your inbox.</p> \n<h3>Chanel: “Smoldering Red Lipstick”</h3> \n<p><img alt=\"examples of catchy email subject lines: Chanel\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-4.png?width=624&amp;height=144&amp;name=20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-4.png\" title=\"\" width=\"624\" height=\"144\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>This example from Chanel is simple but effective. Viewers can visualize a beautiful red lip, and feel enticed to click to see if the product really achieves a “smoldering” look.</p> \n<h3>Wish: “Electrify your night out.”</h3> \n<p><img alt=\"examples of catchy email subject lines: Wish\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-Sep-13-2021-10-48-05-55-PM.png?width=624&amp;height=144&amp;name=20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-Sep-13-2021-10-48-05-55-PM.png\" title=\"\" width=\"624\" height=\"144\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>Wish helps the reader to see how much more fun their night could be in one of its dresses. With this imagery, they’ll want to see how fun their selection of dresses could be — especially if it’s discounted.</p> \n<h3>Drizly: “...here’s $5 to stay in.”</h3> \n<p><img alt=\"examples of catchy email subject lines: Drizly\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-Sep-13-2021-10-48-05-70-PM.png?width=624&amp;height=144&amp;name=20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-Sep-13-2021-10-48-05-70-PM.png\" title=\"\" width=\"624\" height=\"144\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>This subject line is more unique than others — it makes you question what Drizly means by the first half and explicitly gives you an incentive to open the email.</p> \n<h3>Shutterfly: “Claim your UNLIMITED free photo book”</h3> \n<p><img alt=\"examples of catchy email subject lines: Shutterfly\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-Sep-13-2021-10-48-06-16-PM.png?width=624&amp;height=144&amp;name=20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-Sep-13-2021-10-48-06-16-PM.png\" title=\"\" width=\"624\" height=\"144\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>While we mentioned earlier to be careful with CAPS lettering, it doesn’t overwhelm this Shutterfly subject line and makes an interesting offer.</p> \n<h3>Mediabistro: “Generous PTO and Summer Fridays”</h3> \n<p><img alt=\"examples of catchy email subject lines: Mediabistro\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D.png?width=624&amp;height=144&amp;name=20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D.png\" title=\"\" width=\"624\" height=\"144\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>The viewer can envision themselves taking advantage of work perks like these from Mediabistro, and will feel inclined to read more on the subjects presented.</p> \n<h2>Catch more Clicks with Catchy Subject Lines</h2> \n<p>At the end of the day, if your emails aren't getting opened, they're not getting seen. By using some of our tips, we hope you can come up with creative and engaging subject lines of your own. You already have great content to share — now, prove it in your subject line.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's Note: This blog post was originally published in July 2018 but has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=1508edd6-0b38-4be7-8db4-57ab0c9bd4b8&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New Call-to-action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/1508edd6-0b38-4be7-8db4-57ab0c9bd4b8.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fimprove-your-email-subject-line&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" (Olivia Allen)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/c706e2ec-2e42-4977-a207-44505d19f1fe.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn6@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-41-687_5dbf71c62fc21253.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-3.png?width=387&name=20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-3.png":null,"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-1.png?width=624&name=20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn58@2020_6/2021/09/27/16-55-46-361_0ae239d245bd0d49.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-2.png?width=624&name=20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn94@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-46-887_10353f920759db49.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-Sep-13-2021-10-48-05-88-PM.png?width=636&name=20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-Sep-13-2021-10-48-05-88-PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn28@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-46-564_d99dede9e0fc0ede.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-4.png?width=624&height=144&name=20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-4.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn6@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-45-482_a7ac30073f3efaf7.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-Sep-13-2021-10-48-05-55-PM.png?width=624&height=144&name=20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-Sep-13-2021-10-48-05-55-PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn82@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-47-691_0edf7d16f85fc9c2.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-Sep-13-2021-10-48-05-70-PM.png?width=624&height=144&name=20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-Sep-13-2021-10-48-05-70-PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn66@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-44-813_765d680aadcf444e.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-Sep-13-2021-10-48-06-16-PM.png?width=624&height=144&name=20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D-Sep-13-2021-10-48-06-16-PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn70@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-48-637_be0f3e364e03f66d.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D.png?width=624&height=144&name=20%20Tips%20to%20Write%20Catchy%20Email%20Subject%20Lines%20%5B+%20Examples%5D.png":null,"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/1508edd6-0b38-4be7-8db4-57ab0c9bd4b8.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn18@2020_4/2021/09/27/16-55-43-954_d109356b207317d6.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fimprove-your-email-subject-line&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn14@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-45-375_9cf50ae4a4813481.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1632761741211},{"createdTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","updatedTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","title":"7 Reasons Scale-Ups Earn Investments, According to HubSpot's Founder","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/why-scaleups-earn-investments","description":"<p>Every successful company starts with a single idea.</p> \n<p>It's how those ideas are approached, molded, and questioned that dictate whether or not they go on to evolve into a startup.</p> \n<p>However, reaching startup-dom doesn't complete the lifecycle of these ideas. Instead, becoming a startup is the moment when ideas begin to grow into something actionable, driven by a collection of intentional goals.</p> \n<p>And as all of us who have lived the startup life know — when you're a startup, more often than not your goal is simple: to survive.</p> \n<p>I like to think of being a startup as treading water. Succeeding as a startup requires constant motion to ensure you can find product-market-fit, drive early customer growth, and build a baseline product all at the same time. The moment you stop moving is the moment you lose traction.</p> \n<p>And this is all before you've even begun to scale.</p> \n<p>Fortunately, there comes a point where you've treaded water long enough to reach your first lifeboat: Investments.</p> \n<p>That's where it gets exciting.</p> \n<p>As startups move from idea mode to scaleup mode, there are a number of signs I look for in order to determine if I'm going to invest. Of course, not every scaleup has to get every one of these signs right to be worthy of investment, but the more positive signals a scaleup has to offer, the higher the odds of long-term success for that organization.</p> \n<p>So, what <em>is</em>&nbsp;the secret sauce that these special startups have?</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=38d93e33-110d-4097-bb9f-3a38329eae3a&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Access Free Resources to Help Your Company Scale\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/38d93e33-110d-4097-bb9f-3a38329eae3a.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<h2 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">7 Signs that a Scaling Company is Worth the Investment</h2> \n<p>While scaling is a universal concept, the act of scaling efficiently rarely looks exactly the same for all companies.</p> \n<p>Instead, each scale-up encounters their own unique trials, speed bumps, and roadblocks on the path to sustainable growth. When I am looking for scaling companies to invest in, I always take into account the individual circumstances of each company in the context of their growth to see whether or not they have set themselves up for long-term success.</p> \n<p>As an investor, these are the core values I've seen that have proven to be present at companies with growth potential.</p> \n<h3>1. There's evidence of customer happiness.</h3> \n<p>The customer experience doesn't lie. In fact, it's become a <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-sales-and-customer-experience-australia\">key part of GTM strategies</a>&nbsp;at companies like HubSpot, which are investing in Chief Customer Officers and finding more ways to serve the customer across the organization. That's all to say — the customer should be at the center of every decision.</p> \n<p>For evidence of customer happiness, take a look at the NPS (<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/what-is-nps\">Net Promoter Score</a>) and other customer satisfaction scores of the company in question. If the results are in the green, you're looking at a scale-up that is already making a positive impact on their customers. If instead the results are in the red, investors take warning.</p> \n<p>Another way to determine customer happiness is to look for low or decreasing churn. A company's retention rates are the first sign that they are either a fan favorite, or a stepping stone that customers take on their way to a more prepared company.</p> \n<h3>2. The organization's primary roles have great people.</h3> \n<p>In the early years of a startup — when the primary focus is on the product — other roles like sales, marketing, and operations aren't typically fully staffed. However, this practice doesn't cut it when it comes to scaling.</p> \n<p>When you're a scale-up, these roles should be filled with amazing people. If not, there should at least be a plan in place to hire them.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>After all, the potential of a scale-up lies in the potential of the people who are dedicated to its growth.</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>Without staffing all of the necessary teams with top talent, you could be unknowingly stunting your company's growth. In the early days at HubSpot, Brian and I surrounded ourselves with people who were smarter than us, and invested in people we believed in. (Somehow they weren't all developers, like I requested … but I digress …). Those investments paid off, big time, and we're still surrounded by those people today.</p> \n<h3>3. Unit economics are stable and sustainable.</h3> \n<p>Of course, no one expects scale-ups to already come with an impressive ROI. A vanity metric or single data point isn't exactly enough to convince an investor that your scale-up is worth their time and money. Instead, what I look for is stability and sustainability.</p> \n<p>To be primed for viable growth, your customer lifetime value should be some multiple (usually 3+) of your customer acquisition cost. What this number will tell me is that your company is not only desirable by your customers, but that you already have what it takes to retain them and continue&nbsp;to gain value from them as they grow with you over time.</p> \n<p>Scalability and sustainability are two sides of the same coin. With the ability to establish sustainable <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/ecommerce/ecommerce-marketing-metric-youre-not-tracking\">unit economics</a>&nbsp;early on in your lifespan of startup-hood, you'll be primed to scale when the time comes.</p> \n<h3>4. The culture of the organization is well-articulated.</h3> \n<p>Company culture is not something that appears overnight. Instead, it's embedded in every decision your company makes and in the people who work at your organization. Every organization has their own specific company culture, but some are better at articulating theirs than others.</p> \n<p>Company culture encompasses your mission, vision, and values and is the mark of a company with what speaker and author <a href=\"https://angeladuckworth.com/grit-book/\">Angela Duckworth</a>&nbsp;has coined as \"grit.\" <a href=\"https://angeladuckworth.com/grit-book/\">Grit</a>&nbsp;is \"the power of passion and perseverance,\" which translates nicely to what makes startups successful — having a clearly defined passion, and the perseverance to achieve the long-term vision.</p> \n<p>Of course, to be effective, your company culture doesn't need to be composed in a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/34234/the-hubspot-culture-code-creating-a-company-we-love.aspx\">slide deck with 128 slides</a>,&nbsp;but it <em>should</em> be written down. This way, when potential investors like myself take a look at your scale-up, we won't have to spend our time guessing the motives and shared vision that drives your organization. Instead, we will be able to see how your culture guides decision-making across your organization.</p> \n<p>It's a good idea to begin defining your culture sooner rather than later. Company culture provides a stable jumping-off point for most of your initiatives, including recruitment, retention, and alignment. The greater understanding you have of your culture, the more efficiently you'll be able to create a shared vision for your organization.</p> \n<p>If your company culture could use a tune-up, take a look at HubSpot's <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/company-culture\">Ultimate Guide to Company Culture</a>.</p> \n<h3>5. There's a strong focus on creating customer value.</h3> \n<p>There's a reason why I'm so intent on investing in companies who keep a close eye on their customer value. By continuously integrating customer feedback and preferences into your scale-up, you'll be more prepared to <em>proactively</em>&nbsp;create customer value, as opposed to operating in a purely reactive state.</p> \n<p>The companies that succeed today are no longer those that just delight their customers sometimes, but rather those that consistently find ways to exceed expectations and create a personalized experience.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, the best way to maintain a strong focus on creating customer value is to open up a line of dialogue between yourself and your customers. If you haven't yet, take this as a sign to begin establishing your means of gathering customer input.</p> \n<p>Start by asking yourself questions like:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>How is your team getting customer input and acting on it?</li> \n <li>Beyond customer support, who else is focused on the customer?</li> \n <li>Is there a customer success team?</li> \n <li>Have you defined the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/voice-of-the-customer\">voice of your customers</a>?</li> \n <li>How is your customer involved or represented in your business' decision-making?</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>6. The company has a strong strategic planning process, and knows how to determine product priorities.</h3> \n<p>Remember what I said earlier about the importance of creating sustainable systems? The important thing isn't that the planning process works seamlessly and is already primed to scale.</p> \n<p>The emphasis is on the fact that there <em>is </em>a process and mechanism in place for making these decisions at all.</p> \n<p>Trust me: A disorganized planning and priority-setting process makes it impossible to scale.</p> \n<p>The process of scaling is all about proactively setting your company up for future successes. When you have a clearly defined planning process, you're communicating to any potential investors that you are looking to the future and priming to scale.</p> \n<p>As an aside, while you're evaluating your processes, take a look at your systems. Are they built for scaling organizations? Will it be easy to upgrade when you're ready?</p> \n<h3>7. The organization has an engaged workforce.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>Last, but certainly not least, the final sign that a company is scaling sustainably and worth investing in is the satisfaction of their employees.</p> \n<p>An unhappy workforce is a red flag (for new hires and investors alike). Not only should a company have a process for regularly collecting employee feedback, but they should also have a proven record of responding to and acting on the results of the feedback they collect.</p> \n<p>A handful of disengaged or unsatisfied employees is typical, but a collection of them becomes a trend to be prevented at all costs. If you experience high turnover rates, you'll want to fix that quickly — it's impossible to scale without investing in the long-term growth and development of your employees.</p> \n<p>At HubSpot, we have an eNPS (employee NPS) survey that we conduct every quarter for all employees. This way, we are consistently in tune with their needs and preferences, so we can provide employees with the supportive work environment they deserve. We read and evaluate every comment and are constantly looking for ways to improve our employees' experience.</p> \n<p>To begin conducting comprehensive employee surveys of your own, here is <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/enps\">Everything You Need to Know About eNPS</a>.</p> \n<p>And there you have it! The secret sauce I've noticed in startups with real potential to scale, and what they did to stand out.</p> \n<p>Whether I am actively looking for new companies to invest in or not, I always have my antenna up to notice exciting new scale-ups. To invest in sustainable models that support growth at your organization while prioritizing your customer experience, download our guide to <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/scaling-sales-ops-customer-centered-growth\">Scaling Sales Operations for Customer-Centered Growth</a>.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=8f18bb1a-03d7-4fb9-afca-66ac4ccebf6d&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"scaling showcase\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/8f18bb1a-03d7-4fb9-afca-66ac4ccebf6d.png\"></a></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fwhy-scaleups-earn-investments&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 20 Sep 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/38d93e33-110d-4097-bb9f-3a38329eae3a.png","linkMd5":"089700505222749f77f5d80e8022ff8a","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn51@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-42-288_38a6c8c73a912088.webp","destWidth":470,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":5393,"destBytes":7366,"author":"dshah@hubspot.com (Dharmesh Shah)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/38d93e33-110d-4097-bb9f-3a38329eae3a.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn51@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-42-288_38a6c8c73a912088.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/8f18bb1a-03d7-4fb9-afca-66ac4ccebf6d.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn12@2020_5/2021/09/27/16-55-48-049_dcf7aaf8330e44ab.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fwhy-scaleups-earn-investments&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn18@2020_2/2021/09/27/16-55-44-323_4ee896d3025635a2.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1632761741237},{"createdTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","updatedTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","title":"How to Create a Funnel Report [Quick Guide]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/funnel-reporting","description":"<p>You’ve probably heard that it’s crucial to keep a full, flowing funnel for a business. But what does this mean, and how do you know when you’re on the right track?</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Funnel reporting is key to understanding the inner workings of your business. With a detailed funnel report, you can see where customers are at every stage of the sales process. The funnel report can show how many leads you are generating, what deals are being negotiated, what contracts are being finalized, and, ultimately, how many sales are going through.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=0d883e85-c2e5-49bb-bef2-bfddb500d84b&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"→ Free Download: Free Marketing Reporting Templates [Access Now]\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/0d883e85-c2e5-49bb-bef2-bfddb500d84b.png\"></a></p> \n<p>Knowing your funnel at all times can help ensure that funnel doesn’t dry up, leaving you without leads or consistent sales. So, let’s dive into what exactly funnel reporting is and how to create a funnel report.</p> \n<h2>What is funnel reporting?</h2> \n<p>Before you understand funnel reporting, you need to understand the funnel. The funnel is essential to mapping out the customers’ journey to purchasing, from brand awareness all the way through to a sale. Keeping a funnel full of ongoing leads is important to a thriving business.</p> \n<p>As such, a funnel report can give insight as to how a customer discovers your brand and what leads them to either flow through the funnel all the way to purchase or drop off somewhere along the way.</p> \n<p>The funnel report can determine how effective your marketing efforts are, the number of people coming into the funnel, and conversion rates. This report can also provide insight into ongoing lead generation and sales, so you can see just how many leads you are generating and how many are in the process of signing contracts or making purchases.</p> \n<h3>1. Awareness</h3> \n<p>As the customer first enters your funnel, it’ll be through awareness. There are many ways a potential customer can first hear about your brand, whether they hear about your product through word of mouth, see an ad on Instagram, or pass your billboard while driving to work.</p> \n<h3>2. Interest</h3> \n<p>Once the customer has found your brand, if they like what they see, they’ll likely start doing some digging. Reading reviews, checking out your FAQ section, and comparing you to competitors are all likely to happen in this stage.</p> \n<h3>3. Decision</h3> \n<p>Now, the potential customer will start really considering making a purchase. They might consult with a sales rep or ask for pricing quotes.</p> \n<h3>4. Action</h3> \n<p>As the customer moves through the funnel, they will use the information gathered from the previous steps to decide whether or not to make a purchase. That’s why investing in excellent branding, marketing, and customer service is so important, as they will each leave an impact throughout the funnel process and can ultimately be a make-it-or-break-it situation for potential clients.</p> \n<p>Ready to start reporting? Here’s how to create a funnel report. These reports can typically be generated through tools like Google Analytics. To make it easier, <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/reporting-dashboards\"><span>consider Dashboard &amp; Reporting Software</span></a>, which will house all your analytics, reports, and dashboards in one easy-to-navigate space.</p> \n<h3>1. Input Data</h3> \n<p>First and foremost, you’ll need to input data, from the number of customers clicking on your website link to the number of sales that go through and everything in between. This is something that can be automated and pulled for you through Google Analytics or HubSpot. You’ll set the number of building blocks to differentiate the different stages as well.</p> \n<h3>2. Filter</h3> \n<p>Next, you can filter out data you don’t need. The platform you use to create your funnel report will offer basic and/or customizable filter options.</p> \n<h3>3. Organize into Groups</h3> \n<p>To better analyze the report, you can organize the funnel by different marketing methods or products being sold. For example, you might create a funnel breakdown that separates the types of marketing used.</p> \n<h3>4. Visualize</h3> \n<p>Now, the platform will display the funnel report based on your filters and breakdowns. You’ll be able to see how many people found your website, then compare it to say, how many people made an inquiry, signed up for your newsletter, and/or purchased your products or services.</p> \n<h3>5. Note Strengths and Weaknesses</h3> \n<p>With your funnel in front of you, note conversions. See where customers are dropping off and where they are coming from. Your funnel report might show a lot of people coming in from social, despite most of your efforts being on email marketing, where less people are converting into sales. Noting your observations can help you adjust your future marketing strategies.</p> \n<h3>1. Next-Step Conversions</h3> \n<p>One of the simpler funnel reports is for next-step conversions. This funnel report will show the conversion rates between steps. So if you have 500 people see your social media ad, and 100 click through to your website, the conversion for this step is 20%.</p> \n<h3>2. Cumulative Conversions</h3> \n<p>Similarly, cumulative conversion funnel reports will also visualize conversion, but they will compare each stage’s numbers to the starting stage. This is most helpful when making comparisons to competitors or previous funnel reports.</p> \n<h3>3. Trends</h3> \n<p>A funnel trend will visualize changes in conversion rates as time goes on, for better or for worse. This can help you note what marketing strategies work and which ones don’t over time.</p> \n<h3>4. Time to Convert</h3> \n<p>How long does it take for a potential customer to make a purchase from the awareness stage to the action stage? A time-to-convert funnel will show how long it takes a customer to make it through each stage of the funnel.</p> \n<h3>5. Frequency</h3> \n<p>A frequency funnel report can help you identify what stage is most successful in drawing in customers or where customers tend to drop off.</p> \n<h2>Use Funnel Reports to Improve Marketing Strategies</h2> \n<p>A funnel report is an invaluable tool to track the progression of potential clients to customers making purchases. Knowing how clients become aware of your brand and what leads to them ultimately abandoning or making a purchase can help you sharpen your marketing skills.</p> \n<p>A funnel report will allow you to visualize the weaker parts of your marketing strategies to improve them while also spotlighting successful — sometimes surprisingly-so — components of the funnel.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=3cb695d9-7dc5-4e70-8523-1e330e6bd58a&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\" marketing reporting templates\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3cb695d9-7dc5-4e70-8523-1e330e6bd58a.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Ffunnel-reporting&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 09 Sep 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/0d883e85-c2e5-49bb-bef2-bfddb500d84b.png","linkMd5":"24c7a50481dfbf1b17ece1f0193615ba","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn40@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-42-395_2824654e826e002c.webp","destWidth":476,"destHeight":60,"sourceBytes":5100,"destBytes":7214,"author":"Paige Bennett","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/0d883e85-c2e5-49bb-bef2-bfddb500d84b.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn40@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-42-395_2824654e826e002c.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3cb695d9-7dc5-4e70-8523-1e330e6bd58a.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn57@2020_6/2021/09/27/16-55-47-219_d6970030134c53c8.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Ffunnel-reporting&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn81@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-47-248_3464c017b3a71aa5.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1632761741229},{"createdTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","updatedTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","title":"15 Time Management Skills, According to HubSpot Marketing Managers","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/time-management-tips-long-term-deadlines","description":"<p>It's late and you're working on a project that's due soon.</p>  \n<p>You feel overwhelmed by your tasks and aren't quite sure how you got here. You make a self-promise to resolve this issue but you don't know how, so the cycle continues.</p> \n<p>Consider this your WebMD diagnosis: You're likely struggling with bad time management.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=52250291-8fed-4fe7-ad28-e6e244e1fcd8&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Download our complete productivity guide here for more tips on improving your  productivity at work.\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/52250291-8fed-4fe7-ad28-e6e244e1fcd8.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p>The good news is, time management is a learned skill. By following the tips below, written with cross-functional teams in mind, you can be on your way to getting back control of your time and working efficiently.</p> \n<h2>What can time management skills help a person do?</h2> \n<p>Time management is necessary for a successful personal and professional life.</p> \n<p>When you manage your time well, you can be more productive and efficient. You have a solid understanding of what each task requires and you can plan accordingly.</p> \n<p>It allows you to maximize your time and perform better.</p> \n<p>Managing your time well also helps you produce high-quality work. When we struggle with this skill, we often rush to complete our tasks and can easily feel overwhelmed.</p> \n<h3>1. Learn your pattern of productivity.</h3> \n<p>Everyone has a different productivity pattern.</p> \n<p>We've long separated people into two categories: Morning people and night people. However, there are many more facets to productivity.</p> \n<p>Perhaps you're more efficient during short sprints of focus, following the Pomodoro technique. Or you might prefer knocking out your top priorities in one stretch.</p> \n<p>Find out what makes you most productive and use that to your advantage. If you notice you're most productive in the early morning, use that time to cross your focus-heavy, high-priority tasks off your to-do list.</p> \n<p>Building your work schedule around your natural patterns will make it easier for you to focus and be more efficient in your workflow.</p> \n<h3>2.
