Prioritize your tasks.</h3> \n<p>Name a better feeling than crossing something off a to-do list.</p> \n<p>There's something about completing a task that fills you with a sense of accomplishment and builds momentum.</p> \n<p>My colleague and marketing manager for Channel Promotions at HubSpot, <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/jenniferyurikim/\">Jennifer Kim</a>, calls written to-do lists her holy grail.</p> \n<p>\"At the beginning of each day, I like to take the time to manually write out what tasks I need to complete for the day,\" she says. \"It's key for me to write out tasks manually versus typing them out because I'm able to get a better sense of what tasks will take the most time and what I need to prioritize as well as mentally get myself in the headspace to take each one on.\"</p> \n<p>She then cross-references this list with her Google Calendar to plan out her day.</p> \n<p>Now that you have every task written out, how do you decide what to tackle first? <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/meg-prater-she-her-a2a7b571\">Meg Prater</a>, senior manager of the Marketing, Sales, and Service blogs at HubSpot, has some advice.</p> \n<p>\"I prioritize based on impact to the business. Is there a planning meeting with our VP? The prep work for that should probably come first in my week when I'm freshest,\" she says. \"When I prioritize based on impact, I end the day knowing that I handled the tasks that were most valuable to the business and our goals – it's my North Star.\"</p> \n<p>Ranking your tasks ensures that you tackle the most important work first and can keep you from feeling overwhelmed.</p> \n<h3>3. Track your activities.</h3> \n<p>One issue many people face when managing their time is correctly assessing how long a task will take to complete.</p> \n<p>It can be hard to stick to a schedule if you over- or underestimated certain tasks. The task that was supposed to take 30 minutes took two hours and that can throw off your entire day.</p> \n<p>To avoid this slippery slope, take a week to track your activities.</p> \n<p>Write down your most common tasks. For example, as a writer, my tasks include research, media creation, and sourcing, writing, editing, uploading. I also have administrative tasks to complete throughout the week.</p> \n<p>Use a time tracking app like <a href=\"https://toggl.com/\">Toggl</a> or <a href=\"https://clockify.me/\">Clockify</a> to figure out how you are spending your time.</p> \n<p>\"Timing myself helps me to concretely see where I'm spending my time. Where are the time sucks? Am I giving myself enough time to recharge between tasks?\" says Prater. \"This allows me to be more efficient with my time allocation, and set time boundaries for tasks I'm spending too much time on.\"</p> \n<p>Once you know exactly what each task requires, you can make an accurate schedule and make adjustments to create a more efficient process.</p> \n<h3>4. Make collaborating easier.</h3> \n<p>If you work on a cross-functional team or project, it's vital that you set up tools that will make it easier for you to work together.</p> \n<p>Senior Audience Growth Manager at HubSpot <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/pamelabump\">Pamela Bump</a>, who often works with several teams, has a few recommendations.</p> \n<p>\"If you're in a role where you must do projects for different teams, like creating ad campaigns or email promotions, set up a form that cross-functional colleagues can fill out so your requests will all go to one place and can be reviewed at the same time.\"</p> \n<p>Consolidating your requests to one place makes it easier to review and ensures nothing gets lost somewhere.</p> \n<p>Bump adds that you should notify your cross-functional teams once you've launched the form and how you would like them to use it. You can inform them via email, Slack, or even an internal blog post that can be easily bookmarked or referenced.</p> \n<h3>5. Take regular breaks.</h3> \n<p>You've created your schedule for the day. You've been working since 8 a.m., it's now 1 p.m. and you can't seem to focus.</p> \n<p>Next thing you know, it's one hour later and nothing has been accomplished.</p> \n<p>Sometimes, we try to push through slumps when all we need is a break to decompress and get re-energized.</p> \n<p>Whether it's taking a walk, watching an hour of TV, or catching up with a colleague, it's important to take some time away from your work.</p> \n<h3>6. Be flexible.</h3> \n<p>Not every day will work out exactly as planned, and that's OK.</p> \n<p>Managing your time efficiently also means leaving some room for the unplanned. Perhaps, you planned on working on task A and that's not panning out.</p> \n<p>If that's the case, don't be afraid to swap it out with another task. As long as you keep the momentum going, you can still be successful.</p> \n<p>When Bump hits a roadblock in a task, she pivots.</p> \n<p>\"I look at my to-do list and see if there are any super-quick items I can tackle before getting started on the bigger item,\" she says. \"For example, if I pause to return an email or quickly schedule a piece of content to go live, I feel energized by knocking something off my to-do list and will be more motivated to work on the bigger task.\"</p> \n<p>Having structure is important, but leave room for tasks to move around.</p> \n<h3>7. Protect your time.</h3> \n<p>Protecting your time is one of the most important ways to manage your time well. It can look like saying no, delegating, and deprioritizing a task.</p> \n<p>Saying \"no\" at work always feels like a risk, like it's sending a signal that you're not a team player. But that couldn't be further from the truth.</p> \n<p>\"Not every ask that comes your way is a fire that needs immediate extinguishing. Many things in our professional lives can wait,\" Prater says. \"Prioritizing those asks as they come in, saying 'no' when an ask isn't in scope, and realizing when something is OK to wait until tomorrow to work on has been key for me.\"</p> \n<p>Prater adds that learning to delegate has been huge for her growth.</p> \n<p>\"I used to feel like I needed to control as much as possible in my sphere – to prove myself, or some nonsense like that,\" she says. \"Now, I trust the folks around me and view delegation as an opportunity for someone else to grow and develop. It frees up more of my time and has energized folks on my team with new skills.\"</p> \n<p>Don't be afraid to redirect your colleagues when your plate is already full and lean on your colleagues for help.</p> \n<h3>8. Use project management software.</h3> \n<p>Are you bad at managing your time or do you just not have the right tools to support your workflow?</p> \n<p>With project management software like <a href=\"https://asana.com/\">Asana</a>, <a href=\"https://www.atlassian.com/software/jira\">Jira</a>, and <a href=\"https://monday.com/\">Monday.com</a>, you can streamline your workflow and make cross-team collaboration that much easier.</p> \n<p>It can also be a valuable resource when you feel overwhelmed by your tasks.</p> \n<p>\"Asana has been a huge help in organizing out my tasks. My team has an ongoing sprint board where we write out our top 3-4 priorities for the week,\" Kim says. \"In the case that if I ever find myself overwhelmed with all that's going on, I can fall back to that sprint board and center myself on where I need to spend my time.\"</p> \n<p>The great thing about these tools is that they work well for individual and group projects.</p> \n<h3>9. Establish a routine and stick to it.</h3> \n<p>Imagine taking a different route to work every day. It would be hard to be consistent about when you'd arrive at work. I also imagine this constant change would create some unease and stress.</p> \n<p>Humans are creatures of habits and we crave consistency. At work, having a routine helps you maintain productivity.</p> \n<p>Whether you're going to the office every day or working from home, set a routine for your day. Be consistent about the time you wake up and your pre-work tasks.</p> \n<p>This process will help you get in the headspace to work once you're finally at your desk. If you find that your current routine has some kinks in it, try something different.</p> \n<h3>10. Lean on your team.</h3> \n<p>While you decide how you manage your time, you can also get support from your team.</p> \n<p>\"I really lean on my manager to talk through situations when I do feel that there's a lot going on,\" says Kim. \"It really helps to have her bigger picture perspective on what projects are most in line with my team's goals. We're also able to talk through whether there are areas that we can support each other's load.\"</p> \n<p>Your manager can help you prioritize your tasks in alignment with your team's broader goals. They can also help you protect your time when it comes to cross-functional projects.</p> \n<p>Bump encourages honesty with your colleagues and your manager about your bandwidth.</p> \n<p>\"When working with cross-functional teams, it can be easy to agree to too many tasks and not have time to complete them all,\" she says. \"If you foresee a time crunch, reach out to your colleagues or manager and see what can be moved or adjusted if needed due to your changing priorities.\"</p> \n<p>The work doesn't get done alone. So, make sure you're leaning on your team to help you manage your time and achieve your goals.</p> \n<h3>11. Stack your meetings.</h3> \n<p>Ever have meetings spread out throughout the day? Doing work in between those can seem impossible.</p> \n<p>It can feel like just when you're getting in your groove, you have to stop to jump into another meeting.</p> \n<p>\"I find that when my meetings are scattered throughout the day without any significant chunks of free time I can devote to my own tasks, I'm unable to focus and do what I need to do,\" says Kim.\"</p> \n<p>One way to prevent this is by stacking your meetings back-to-back, whenever possible. Have multiple one-on-ones this week? Try to knock them all out on the same day in a block of time.</p> \n<p>Kim says this tactic helps her get into focus mode.</p> \n<p>\"I'm able to do my best work when I can get into the right headspace – whether that's meeting mode or working mode – so this has been really effective for me.\"</p> \n<p>Bump suggests scheduling plan-oriented meetings on specific days of the week.</p> \n<p>\"This will leave you some wide-open time at the end of the week for larger projects like creating content or brainstorming new strategies,\" she says.</p> \n<h3>12. Limit distractions.</h3> \n<p>You're trying to get work done but your email inbox is pilling up and you keep getting pinged.</p> \n<p>Distractions like these make it impossible to focus on your tasks and manage your time well. Thankfully, many of these communication platforms offer features to limit your distractions.</p> \n<p>For instance, productivity software <a href=\"https://boomerangapp.com/\">Boomerang</a> offers a \"pause inbox\" feature that temporarily stops new emails from populating in your Gmail or Outlook account.</p> \n<p>You can also use the \"do not disturb\" feature on your messaging software to prevent notifications.</p> \n<p>You can also put a status like \"Heads down - slow to respond\" to let your colleagues know you may be unavailable for the next few hours.</p> \n<h3>13. Declutter your space.</h3> \n<p>Your space is a reflection of your mind.</p> \n<p>If your space is messy, it can make it harder to focus and manage your time effectively. It can also contribute to feelings of being overwhelmed.</p> \n<p>With this in mind, make sure your work environment reflects the state you want to be in. Remove non-essentials from your desk, add affirmations like \"You can do it!\" and \"Breathe\" to motivate you throughout the day.</p> \n<p>You can even add essential oils to create a calming environment and play some soothing music in the background.</p> \n<h3>14. Take accountability.</h3> \n<p>You may be responsible for keeping track of your progress toward achieving your goal, and holding yourself accountable to the timelines and benchmarks you've established will help you stay motivated and positive at work.</p> \n<p>Personal accountability leads to increased feelings of workplace satisfaction, creativity, and innovation, and there are a few ways to promote that while working on your long-term project, including:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Sharing progress toward goals with others</li> \n <li>Setting up a personal reward system for each benchmark you achieve on the path to project completion.</li> \n <li>Tracking your progress so you can visualize what portion of your project you've successfully completed.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>15. Review past performance.</h3> \n<p>Analyze and report on successes and challenges of projects for future goal-setting.</p> \n<p>Once you've successfully completed a long-term project, don't move on to the next one without first reflecting on your strategies for project management. What went well, and perhaps more importantly, what didn't?</p> \n<p>If your work is primarily comprised of long-term projects, you will need to continually refine and improve your approach to be as efficient as possible.</p> \n<p>Document your processes and share them with your team so they can learn from your triumphs and struggles for their projects as well.</p> \n<p>Managing your time is a learned skill that requires a lot of discipline and flexibility. It's also something that requires support from your team, as those interactions impact your ability to complete your tasks.</p> \n<p>While you may be an expert time manager tomorrow, following these tips will definitely help you improve your current process.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=57b789cd-3ca2-4d6b-b792-77e5b1163125&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"Take me to Projects\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/57b789cd-3ca2-4d6b-b792-77e5b1163125.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Ftime-management-tips-long-term-deadlines&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 06 Sep 2021 21:45:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/52250291-8fed-4fe7-ad28-e6e244e1fcd8.png","linkMd5":"0bc80147828f64b4661ca9b8198f8325","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn48@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-42-331_e57995fecd8b2257.webp","destWidth":395,"destHeight":60,"sourceBytes":4668,"destBytes":6412,"author":"mbretous@hubspot.com (Martina Bretous)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/52250291-8fed-4fe7-ad28-e6e244e1fcd8.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn48@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-42-331_e57995fecd8b2257.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/57b789cd-3ca2-4d6b-b792-77e5b1163125.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn61@2020_4/2021/09/27/16-55-45-394_9524aa96f1bc7dcb.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Ftime-management-tips-long-term-deadlines&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn39@2020_4/2021/09/27/16-55-46-848_fd2f043891f06515.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1632761741262},{"createdTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","updatedTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","title":"The Ultimate Guide to Podcast Advertising and Sponsorship","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/podcast-advertising-tips","description":"<p>According to research by <a href=\"https://www.podcastinsights.com/podcast-statistics/\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\"><span>Podcast Insights</span></a>, there are more than 2 million active podcasts and counting.</p> \n<p>As a marketer for a small to mid-sized business, you might be interested in podcast sponsorship, but not know where to start. Mainly because there are so many podcasts to choose from. How do you know which podcasts your target audience is listening to?</p> \n<a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=da1bfbbd-7ee9-4bf1-89d1-6d7a833deb08&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Download Now: Free Ad Campaign Planning Kit\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/da1bfbbd-7ee9-4bf1-89d1-6d7a833deb08.png\" align=\"middle\" /></a> \n<p>To help you determine what ad strategy is right for you and where to put your podcast dollars, I spoke to HubSpot's podcasting team and did some additional research to comprise a list of helpful strategies for finding, vetting, and advertising on a podcast that aligns with your brand.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/podcast-advertising-tips#terminology\">Podcast Advertising Terminology</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/podcast-advertising-tips#find-and-sponsor\">Tips for Finding and Sponsoring Podcasts</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/podcast-advertising-tips#how-to-advertise\">How to Advertise on Podcasts</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/podcast-advertising-tips#navigating-podcast-sponsorship\">Navigating Podcast Sponsorship</a></p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Podcast Advertising Terminology</h2> \n<p>Before we discuss the ins and outs of podcast advertising, let’s review the terminology you need to know before reaching out to podcast hosts and networks.</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>CPM Rate:</strong> CPM stands for \"cost per mille.\" The CPM represents a flat standard rate advertisers pay for every 1,000 impressions.</li> \n <li><strong>Host-Read Ad:</strong> a pre-recorded ad that is voiced by the host(s) of the podcast.</li> \n <li><strong>Dynamic Insertion:</strong> the use of software to automatically insert ads into pre-existing podcast audio. These ads can be easily changed across a podcast’s entire catalog without making changes to the original audio file.</li> \n <li><strong>Programmatic Ad:</strong> pre-recorded advertisements that do not feature the original host of the podcast. Programmatic ads are typically deployed using dynamic insertion.</li> \n <li><strong>Pre-Roll Ad:</strong> an ad placed at the beginning of a podcast episode.</li> \n <li><strong>Mid-Roll Ad:</strong> an ad placed near the middle of a podcast episode.</li> \n <li><strong>Post-Roll Ad:</strong> an ad placed at the end of a podcast episode.</li> \n <li><strong>CTA:</strong> Call to action; unique URLs and discount codes are typically included in podcast CTAs to measure the performance of an ad’s effectiveness on a particular podcast.</li> \n <li><strong>Downloads:</strong> how many times a podcast episode has been downloaded from a podcast hosting site. The most common metric to determine the impressions/listens of a podcast.</li> \n <li><strong style=\"color: inherit; font-size: 1.125rem;\">Live-Read Ad:</strong> an ad that is performed live during a podcast episode, as opposed to being scripted and edited or dynamically inserted into the episode.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Now that you're familiar with the necessary terminology, let's discuss how to find and sponsor podcasts.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>1. Consider podcast demographics.</h3> \n<p>While different types of TV shows might attract different audiences or demographics, the podcast demographics don't change drastically from show to show, according to HubSpot's former Podcast Manager Sam Balter.</p> \n<p>Balter explained that the podcast audience demographic, which is generally made up of <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/podcast-hubspot-marketer\">\"affluent educated millennials\"</a> is a \"good audience for brands pretty much regardless of what show you’re on.\"</p> \n<p>Why is the podcast audience so good? Because of their <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/podcast-hubspot-marketer\">age, income, and education level</a>, this particular group of people is old enough to make purchasing decisions and has enough income to make those purchases. Because many of them have jobs or are in higher education, these listeners might be interested in learning about a wide range of products or services that make daily life or work easier for them.</p> \n<p>According to Alanah Joseph, Senior Marketing Manager on the HubSpot Podcasts team, understanding the listener of the show is key to successful ad placements. She says:</p> \n<p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>\"When reviewing the custom ad placements on HubSpot Podcast Network shows, we define success through more than one lens. We’re looking at the ad from the point of a listener. Does the ad feel like it’s an authentic part of the show? Is it enjoyable to listen to?</em></p> \n<p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>From the lens of an advertiser, we’re measuring success by the size of the audience, specifically the number of downloads. Although there are other metrics we’d like to track and report, we’re limited in the data we can collect.\"</em></p> \n<p>Another great thing about podcast listeners is that they'll tune into podcast episodes for a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/podcast-hubspot-marketer\">longer amount of time</a> than they will to other content, like video. The podcast audience also enjoys long-form podcasts that are <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/podcast-hubspot-marketer\">30 minutes or longer</a>. Since there's <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/podcast-hubspot-marketer\">much less drop-off</a> on a podcast compared to other forms of content, like video, this means that ads could be placed towards the beginning or end of an episode and still have a good chance of being heard.</p> \n<h3>2. Understand standard podcast ad pricing.</h3> \n<p>The next question you might be asking is, \"How much will advertising on a podcast cost?\"</p> \n<p>If you're new to the podcast advertising world, you might not know how ads are usually prices. You might be worried that all podcast ads might have vastly different prices — or that podcasters will charge a lot for a poor ad slot.</p> \n<p>Podcast ad pricing might be more transparent than you think. According to Balter, podcasters and podcast networks commonly use the same formula to determine how much an ad in their podcasts will cost.</p> \n<p>If you want to get a ballpark idea of what ad slots for a specific show might cost before reaching out to a podcast team or network, plug the metrics you can find for that show's previous episodes into the formula shown below.</p> \n<p>As mentioned in the terminology section, CPM stands for \"cost per mille,\" or cost per 1,000 impressions.</p> \n<p>Balter says that the cost of a standard ad in a podcast usually costs between $10 and $50 with more popular podcasts also charging a premium.</p> \n<p>However, if you want to do a more intensive promotion — such as a full sponsored podcast episode — this cost may vary based on what the content will entail from the podcasters. For example, <a href=\"https://creative.gimletmedia.com/products/ads\">Gimlet</a>, a prominent podcast network that produces shows like <a href=\"https://creative.gimletmedia.com/shows/fortune-favors-the-bold\">Mastercard's \"Fortune Favors the Bold\"</a>, offers two tiers of advertising: audio ads and branded podcasts.</p> \n<h3>3. Look for podcasts that relate to your brand or industry.</h3> \n<p>Because the pool of podcasts is so large, there are plenty of opportunities to connect with niche audiences that relate to your specific industry.</p> \n<p>When an ad relates to the topic of a podcast series or episode, it might feel more natural to the listener. It's also strategically smart because listeners who are interested in this industry might identify with pain points that your service aims to solve.</p> \n<p>For example, if you place an ad about your B2B recruiting service on a podcast that discusses human resources, listeners who own or manage a B2B company, or human resources employees, might want to use your service to make their jobs easier.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://bullhorn.fm/thejoeroganexperience/posts\">Here's an example</a> outside of the B2B world. On an episode of \"<a href=\"https://bullhorn.fm/thejoeroganexperience/posts/puQcPrT-1241-sam-harris\">The Joe Rogan Experience</a>\", a general podcast that zones in on topics like technology, science, and entertainment, Joe Rogan reads a script that talks about how he uses ExpressVPN and Cash App in his daily life. Before going into detail about how he uses these products, he also notes that these companies sponsored the episode.</p> \n<p>In the ad, Rogan explains that he uses ExpressVPN to protect his internet data and personal information, while he uses Cash App to pay friends or make transactions on the go from his phone. If you can't listen to the podcast, here's a quick excerpt from the ad:</p> \n<p>\"With all the recent news about online security breaches, it's very hard not to worry about where your data goes. Making an online purchase or simply accessing your email could put your private information at risk ... That's why I decided to take back my privacy using ExpressVPN. ExpressVPN has easy-to-use apps and runs seamlessly in the background of my computer phone tablet.\"</p> \n<p>Although Rogan notes that he's reading sponsored material before beginning the segment, the services he discusses relate to technology, handy apps, and internet security, which are topics that he has covered on \"The Joe Rogan Experience\". Additionally, these topics might be interesting to the millennial podcast audience which is <a href=\"https://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2019/09/09/us-generations-technology-use/\">highly tuned into smartphone and computer technology</a>.</p> \n<p>Lastly, because Rogan describes his own experiences with ExpressVPN, the segment feels less like an ad and more like a friendly recommendation. In fact, listeners who are fans of Rogan might trust that he has used the advertised product and that he had a good experience with it. If they think he's a credible recommendation source, they might choose or consider ExpressVPN when looking for a data security provider.</p> \n<p>After an example, you need a brief section that sums up what readers should get from the example. In this case, something like, \"One of the main selling points of advertising on a podcast is that listeners are already comfortable with the host. When the host reads your ad copy, there's already a level of trust between the host and the audience that wouldn't be there with alternative mediums like video or display ads. It's almost like a lightweight celebrity endorsement.\"</p> \n<h3>4. Use your competitors for inspiration.</h3> \n<p>As with any new marketing or advertising technique, a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/competitor-analysis-guide\">competitive analysis</a> can help you identify what similar companies are doing, as well as opportunities where you can get ahead of them.</p> \n<p>If you have a direct competitor who has advertised on various podcasts, see if those shows might fit your ad strategy as well. Similarly, if there are brands in your industry that provide non-competing services and use podcast advertising, try to identify shows that they advertise on.</p> \n<p>From there, you could either look into contacting these podcast producers or their networks or look for podcasts that have a similar level of success and discuss similar topics. While you shouldn't directly copy what your competitor is doing, a competitive analysis could still inspire you to develop an ad strategy or promotional content that improves upon that of similar brands.</p> \n<h3>5. Purchase multiple ads for small shows rather than one for big podcasts.</h3> \n<p>As you start researching podcasts, you might find a long list of shows that will align very well with your product or service. When that happens, do you invest in one expensive ad for the biggest show with the most promising numbers? Or, do you use that money for multiple ads on different podcast episodes?</p> \n<p>Balter says, \"It’s better to play an ad multiple times on a smaller show than try to a single ad on a big show.\"</p> \n<p>If major podcasts have a huge listenership and ad premiums, you'll have to pay much more for one or two ads that may or may not be memorable. While you might get great visibility, this could be a huge gamble. If the ads don't provide ROI, you'll lose ad dollars.</p> \n<p>That's why the safest strategy is to follow Balter's advice and choose frequency over sheer audience reach.</p> \n<p>Look at a number of smaller podcasts that still have engaging content and really relate to your product or business. Then invest a bit of your spend in each. If one or two don't pan out well but the others do, consider swapping the low-performing podcasts out with other shows or purchasing more ads on episodes of podcasts that are giving you revenue or brand awareness.</p> \n<h3>6. Advertise on multiple podcasts within the same network.</h3> \n<p>If you plan to invest in multiple podcasts — or multiple ads within a podcast episode — and find a network that produces multiple shows that align with your product, consider building a relationship with that network and putting your ad dollars there.</p> \n<p>In the podcast world, Balter explains that advertising on shows within the same network is called a \"pulsing\" strategy, adding that it's better than airing multiple ads on one podcast episode but still can have similar reach.</p> \n<p>\"Because people who listen to <a href=\"https://creative.gimletmedia.com/'\">Gimlet</a> shows are likely to listen to other Gimlet shows, you can get a solid number of impressions off of a few shows over a relatively short amount of time without inundating listeners with the same ad over and over again.\"</p> \n<p>Here's an example of a Hendrick's Gin ad that Gimlet has circulated on a number of its podcasts and displayed on its <a href=\"https://creative.gimletmedia.com/products/ads\">advertising page</a>.</p> \n<p><iframe style=\"border-radius: 3px; box-shadow: 0 0 25px 0 rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.15); margin: 0px auto; display: block;\" src=\"https://player.gimletmedia.com/4mszd7\" width=\"560\" height=\"130\" frameborder=\"no\"></iframe></p> \n<p>The native ad begins by telling listeners that the episode they're listening to is sponsored by Hendrick's Gin. Then the ad's narrator goes on to discuss the flavors associated with the beverage and how people who drink it are looking to escape from their mundane life.</p> \n<p>This Hendrick's ad feels unique but it speaks to a wide variety of people that could be bored with their lives and doesn't note specific industries. The ad also doesn't specify the podcast it's on which makes it easy to place in many different ones.</p> \n<h3>7. Be vigilant of dishonest podcasters.</h3> \n<p>As you research various podcasts — especially those that are smaller, you might realize that it's easy to find numbers and success metrics for some, while others are less transparent. Because of this, you'll want to do some extra digging and properly vet the podcasts at the top of your list to make sure they're legitimate.</p> \n<p>Balter warns, \"Downloads are not algorithmically verified, therefore people sometimes make up how many downloads their show gets. So, if you’re sponsoring a less reputable podcast, make sure to get download numbers for a single episode.\"</p> \n<p>If you want to verify that the podcast is giving accurate numbers before reaching out to them, here are a few steps you can take.</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Look at all the sites they post their podcasts on:</strong> If they post on a major site like SoundCloud or Spotify, you should be able to see general platform-provided view numbers to get an idea of how successful their podcast was.</li> \n <li><strong>Look for them on social media:</strong> While podcasters might not be airing episodes on social media, they might have a following or a few social accounts to spread awareness of the show. If they do, look at the follower count, likes, and visual signs of engagement on these pages. If you can find signs of social engagement and a following, this might be a sign that they have a legitimate audience.</li> \n <li><strong>Work with a credible network:</strong> Many credible networks might be transparent about podcast numbers to potential and current advertisers. Additionally, you can look at the success of the network's other shows as evidence that they're associated with engaging content.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>When you do finally talk to the podcast producers, get as much specific data as possible about views and impressions. If they have or have had advertisers in the past, you might want to ask them if their advertisers have <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/measure-content-marketing-roi\">seen an ROI</a>. If they can show proof that advertisers make more money than they spend on ad slots, this shows that ads on this podcast can be successful.</p> \n<h3>8. Consider purchasing back catalog space.</h3> \n<p>A back catalog is a collection of a podcast's previously recorded episodes. Back catalog podcast episodes might still be listened to, shared quite regularly by listeners, and up for grabs when it comes to ad space.</p> \n<p>Because back catalog episodes have already aired and don't seem like an obvious ad opportunity, Balter says this tactic is \"interesting and something a lot of people don’t consider.\"</p> \n<p>If you do decide to advertise in back catalog podcasts, zone specifically into evergreen episodes that will continue to remain relevant for a longer period of time.</p> \n<p>For example, if you're a marketer for an e-commerce home-shopping site, you could advertise in back catalog podcasts about DIY ideas or home decorating. This type of podcast won't age drastically over time and might be relevant to anyone listening to podcasts about those topics.</p> \n<p>While these podcasts might've already been promoted during their first launch, podcasters are often encouraged to <a href=\"https://blog.pacific-content.com/dont-forget-about-your-podcast-s-back-catalog-2269a9a6d722\">re-promote evergreen back catalog content</a>. Your brand could also share the podcast on your company's social channels for some added promotion.</p> \n<h3>9. Determine what type of promotion you'd like to run.</h3> \n<p>While some companies like to create standard native ads that exist as pre-roll or mid-roll within a podcast episode, other brands might pay the podcast producers to create sponsored content.</p> \n<p>Similarly, advertisers might want to script the ad and have the host read it, or have the host casually work product discussion into the podcast conversation, so it feels more natural. Some podcasts may only offer certain types of sponsorship options, but if you still want to consider the different types, here are a few with an example for each:</p> \n<p><strong>Native Ad:</strong></p> \n<p>A native ad is created by the brand for the podcast. With this common strategy, you'll create a short audio clip that discusses your product, service, or another promotion related to your brand. These usually run for 30 seconds or less and sound a lot like audio ads you'd hear on traditional radio stations. These ads usually air as pre-roll or mid-roll ads after a podcast host says something like, \"And now, a word from our sponsors.\"</p> \n<p>Below is an example of an ad for the Toyota RAV4. In the 30-second ad, a narrator describes all the unique features that make the car safe, reliable, and fast. Like the Hendrick's Gin ad noted above, the ad doesn't acknowledge a specific podcast so it can be shared on multiple different shows.</p> \n<p><iframe style=\"border-radius: 3px; box-shadow: 0 0 25px 0 rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.15); margin: 0px auto; display: block;\" src=\"https://player.gimletmedia.com/3vsoxb\" width=\"560\" height=\"130\" frameborder=\"no\"></iframe></p> \n<p>If you're looking for inspiration for a quirkier native ad, check out <a href=\"https://www.geico.com/more/geico-community/commercials/radio/\">GEICO's list of ads</a>, which have been aired on both radio and podcasts.</p> \n<p><strong>Sponsored Content:</strong></p> \n<p>With sponsored content or branded podcasts, you pay the podcast production team to create interesting content about a topic related to your industry of the company.</p> \n<p>While the content might not discuss your product outright, the podcast hosts will note that your brand sponsored the podcast — and most likely include some information about your product or service.</p> \n<p>If the podcast is valuable and interesting to the listener, they might remember your brand and affiliate informative content with your company.</p> \n<p>One recent example was a mini-series called <a href=\"https://m.facebook.com/watch/?v=2279044105516875&amp;_rdr\">\"The Sauce\"</a> in 2018. The podcast, sponsored by McDonald's — and created by Gizmodo and Onion Labs — investigated why people rioted over the removal of Szechuan Sauce from the McDonald's menu. While the podcast has since been removed from Apple podcasts, you can find a short preview for it on <a href=\"https://m.facebook.com/watch/?v=2279044105516875&amp;_rdr\">Gizmodo's Facebook page</a>.</p> \n<p><strong>Paid Interview:</strong></p> \n<p>This is a type of sponsored content where an expert from or affiliated with an advertising brand is interviewed in exchange for the sponsorship dollars. While this gives your company's experts an opportunity to spread brand awareness and show their expertise, it also allows the podcast to create interesting interview content about a topic related to its own mission.</p> \n<p>In the example below, Daymond John interviews a rep from ZipRecruiter, on the podcast, <a href=\"https://www.stitcher.com/podcast/pods/rise-and-grind-with-daymond-john\">\"Rise and Grind.\"</a> Because the podcast series regularly discussed business, entrepreneurship, and management, this ZipRecruiter-sponsored interview about hiring talent, still feels like a natural piece of content.</p> \n<iframe style=\"margin: 0px auto; display: block;\" src=\"https://open.spotify.com/embed/episode/0qb9IXmFaztAKv2JuItqoK\" width=\"560\" height=\"232\" frameborder=\"0\"></iframe> \n<p>This paid interview tactic could also work for businesses in other industries as well. For example, if you're a marketer for a cookbook publisher, you could pay for a chef who created some of a new book's recipes to get interviewed on a podcast related to cooking, home-making, or DIY.</p> \n<p>In another example, if your company sells medical devices, you could pay for your CEO or an executive to be interviewed on a podcast that touches on medical news or technological advances.</p> \n<p>In either example, audiences who listen to those podcasts because they want to learn more about topics or products within their industry might hear the interviews, gain insight from the experts, and trust your brand more.</p> \n<p><strong>Product Placement:</strong></p> \n<p>This is a form of sponsored content where podcasters are paid to mention your product casually in the podcast's discussion.</p> \n<p>In a classic example, the \"My Brother, My Brother, and Me\" podcast aired an episode about Totinos which was sponsored by Totinos.</p> \n<div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-wrapper hs-responsive-embed\" style=\"width: 100%; height: auto; position: relative; overflow: hidden; padding: 0; max-width: 560px; max-height: 315px; min-width: 256px; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-inner-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.25%; margin: 0;\"> \n  <iframe class=\"hs-responsive-embed-iframe\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/tDSE4yqfiBY\" width=\"560\" height=\"315\" allowfullscreen=\"\"></iframe> \n </div> \n</div> \n<p>While the hosts played games and had random discussions about life, as they've done in most of their episodes, they were chewing Totino's pizza rolls most of the time and made each game or featured piece of content center around the food product.</p> \n<p><strong>Direct Response Ads</strong></p> \n<p>This is a native ad that feels like a product placement where the host reads a short script written by the advertiser. The ad ends with the host telling listeners to do something, such as click a link or use a coupon code. Unlike the more traditional pre-roll or mid-roll native ad, the listener is still immersed in the experience of listening to the host.</p> \n<p>Although the host notes that their discussion is sponsored, it still might make the listener feel like they are getting a solid recommendation from the host.</p> \n<p>On Dax Shepard's podcast, \"The Armchair Expert,\" he includes at least one direct response ad in the middle of each episode. At the 65:00 mark of <a href=\"https://open.spotify.com/episode/7n3uTTJ9kFax5c2f5YdNiZ\">this episode</a>, Shepard reads a script that explains the benefits of using the meal-delivery service DoorDash. Then, he tells listeners to download DoorDash and use the code \"DAX\" to get $5 off of their first order:</p> \n<h3>10. Purchase ad spots online.</h3> \n<p>If you're just looking to purchase a standard ad slot and already have an audio clip, some tools allow you to purchase space and target ads to appear on multiple podcasts.</p> \n<p>For example, if you're just planning to target one or two simple native ads to millennials on Spotify, you might want to use <a href=\"https://www.google.com/aclk?sa=L&amp;ai=DChcSEwif1OyOq9TkAhUCj8gKHVOUBL4YABADGgJxdQ&amp;sig=AOD64_1FprewWkVTwhPcCXxtfrZnWZDFhA&amp;q=&amp;ved=2ahUKEwiG6uOOq9TkAhXkQd8KHZLRCsIQ0Qx6BAgOEAE&amp;adurl=\">Spotify Ad Studio</a> to create and launch basic native ads on the music platform. If you want to launch to multiple host-read ads in a number of different podcasts, you could consider using a service like <a href=\"http://www.midroll.com/\">Midroll</a>, where you can submit ad information and purchase ad slots in a variety of different podcasts.</p> \n<h3>11. Or, reach out personally to podcasts you'd like to work with.</h3> \n<p>If you want to do something that requires more planning, like sponsored content, a paid interview, or preparing scripted product placements, you should make an in-person connection with podcasters.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>\"<i>By being intentional when looking for creators, we can create a truly collaborative environment and allow creators to infuse their personality and voice into our ads,\" says Joseph.</i></p> \n<p>Once you've done your research and found a few podcasts you're interested in, reach out to begin discussing your advertising options. Send an email with a little bit about your brand and why you think you could work well with them as an advertiser. Be sure to also ask about their growth and key success metrics to confirm that they are as promising as you think.</p> \n<p>Need help reaching out to potential podcast hosts or networks you’d like to sponsor? Check out the template below.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/zXqrfHa0vkLq1KpaWXM1R6T8diElJOdPhhSYYguyUvKBWpwqkZHNhe1aBx7WMovSnlCQJVIdIqqsiBVW8eXNdw5diD2b4t-esZMdMPy5KlFraXvZcPqJcnQZo2S1_BsiDUDeHp0Q=s0\" width=\"360\" height=\"556\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" alt=\"Podcast Sponsorship Template\" /></p> \n<p>Once you find the podcasters you'd like to partner with, keeping them involved in the creative process is key. Avoid handing them a dry script to read verbatim. \"I've learned the more we allow our podcasters to participate in the creation of the ad, the better the ad will be,\" Joseph says.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>12. Monitor your progress.</h3> \n<p>Regardless of what type of promotion you purchase, you should be tracking your money spent compared to the money the advertisement earned. This will help you determine the ROI of your campaigns.</p> \n<p>If you're publishing promotions on multiple podcasts, this will be an important way to tell which might warrant more advertisements and which might require less to no ad spend.</p> \n<p>With <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/measure-content-marketing-roi\">this post on marketing ROI</a>, you can learn how to use a simple formula to calculate and find a few examples of how it can be used when strategizing in the real world.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>How to Advertise on Podcasts</h2> \n<p>Ready to launch your advertising campaign on relevant podcasts? Here’s what you should consider.</p> \n<h3>1. Determine the type of ad you want to run.</h3> \n<p>As we reviewed above in the podcast terminology section, there are a few different types of podcast ads to consider. The right type of podcast ad for you will depend on your budget and the goals of your campaign.</p> \n<p>Host-read ads tend to cost more than programmatic ads, however, according to <a href=\"https://www.nielsen.com/us/en/insights/article/2020/host-read-podcast-ads-pack-a-brand-recall-punch/\"><span>Nielsen</span></a> host-read ads are more effective because hosts have already established trust and recognition with their audiences.</p> \n<h3>2. Select the best ad placement for your campaign.</h3> \n<p>Additionally, ad placement and length matter. Though the first few minutes of a podcast reaches the widest audience, pre-roll ads, or ads that play at the beginning of a podcast episode, tend to have a lower CPM rate because users can <a href=\"http://blog.bloomads.com/blog/mid-roll-vs-pre-roll-whats-the-best-place-for-a-podcast-ad\"><span>easily skip over the ad.</span></a></p> \n<p><span><img src=\"https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/vieH4unZTOgMvoHiC2trtE3TEuJ5rT5GZszl-pdA6c5XiM-3JesIgT0JOPn_1obTq8baRqsPpO4nkSjyPrtXikAFpOWzweCA_ZrBfUycwe_2nKtzD9hjVpWT06Xd4NI7Cn1Dg0ZH=s0\" width=\"624\" height=\"275\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" alt=\"Podcast Advertising\" /></span></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><span><a href=\"https://www.marketingweek.com/untapped-potential-podcast-advertising/\">Image Source</a></span></p> \n<p>On the other hand, mid-roll ad placements tend to have a higher CPM rate because listeners who reach the middle of an episode tend to be <a href=\"http://blog.bloomads.com/blog/mid-roll-vs-pre-roll-whats-the-best-place-for-a-podcast-ad\"><span>more engaged</span></a> and likely to follow a CTA. In terms of <a href=\"https://www.advertisecast.com/podcast-advertising-rates\"><span>length</span></a>, 30-second ad placements have an average CPM of $18, while 60-second ad placements have an average CPM of $25.</p> \n<h3>3. How to write a podcast ad.</h3> \n<p>Now that you know what type of ad you want to run and have determined the placement, it’s time to tackle the messaging. Whether you are doing host-read or programmatic ads, the on-air talent needs talking points from you to ensure the ad shares information that is relevant to your campaign.</p> \n<p>Here are the elements to include when writing a podcast ad script.</p> \n<h4>Hook the Listener</h4> \n<p>Begin with a bold or attention-grabbing statement to get the listener’s attention and reduce the likelihood of them fast-forwarding through the ad.</p> \n<h4>Personal Story</h4> \n<p>Once the audience is hooked on the ad, the on-air talent should introduce the product and share a quick personal story outlining why they enjoy the product. A simple way to do this is to mention what problem they were experiencing, how they were introduced to the product, and the positive results or solutions they experienced after using the product.</p> \n<h4>Call to Action</h4> \n<p>Close the ad by creating a clear call-to-action (CTA) for the listener. A popular CTA used in podcast advertising is special codes and unique URLs specifically for that show. These are easy for the audience to remember because they are typically related to the name of the podcast, and can be easily measured for KPI tracking.</p> \n<h3>4. How to create a podcast ad.</h3> \n<p>Once the script has been finalized, share it with the on-air talent so they can record the ad as a standalone mp3 file. During the post-production process, the ad should be placed in the episode audio file during the designated placement time. If using dynamic insertion technology, upload the mp3 file to the podcast hosting software so it can be automatically played during the episode.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Navigating Podcast Sponsorship</h2> \n<p>The podcast landscape is a pool of growing opportunities for marketers. And, if you're ready to start testing the sponsorship waters, be sure to keep these key tips in mind.</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Find podcasts that align with your brand: </strong>People are listening to an episode to get informed about a specific topic. If your ad aligns well with it, they might be interested in learning more about your product.</li> \n <li><strong>Choose frequency over audience reach:</strong> It's less risky and more efficient to invest in multiple ads on smaller podcasts rather than just one or two ads on a major podcast.</li> \n <li><strong>Consider working with a network: </strong>Networks may provide more legitimate view numbers and have a variety of podcasts with similar audiences that you can air your ads on.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>With the right strategy in place, you can get your product in front of an engaged community of potential buyers through podcast advertising.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=46d72524-f4a7-44e9-9af0-935be9bb3891&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" [+Template]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/social-media-holiday-calendar-2017","description":"<p>Do you celebrate International Cat Day, Pizza Day, or Talk Like a Pirate Day? </p> \n<p>There are a plethora of observance days worldwide during which marketers can share content relevant to their industries, get involved in a movement, or simply generate more awareness. But odds are, you probably don't acknowledge these days until you see your favorite brand posting about it.</p> \n<a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=3e56e15d-47bd-46c9-a256-99fde52abfe7&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"→ Free Download: Social Media Calendar Template [Access Now]\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3e56e15d-47bd-46c9-a256-99fde52abfe7.png\" align=\"middle\" /></a> \n<p>These social media \"holidays\" are a fun way to connect with new and existing followers who share an affinity for a specific food, fictional character, or pet.</p> \n<p>While we don't suggest sharing content on social media and then adding an irrelevant holiday hashtag to it, these holidays can be a chance to promote your brand in a relevant way. Not doing so could cause you to miss valuable opportunities where your brand can join the conversations taking place among members of your target audience.</p> \n<p>To help you plan for trending holidays, we created a list that you can bookmark, as well as a downloadable calendar so you can receive automatic reminders.<a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/social-media-content-calendar?hubs_post-cta=imagebottom&amp;__hstc=233546881.ad8091ec2768c1bb4cfceb9f006c7b7b.1615481181834.1615481181834.1615481181834.1&amp;__hssc=233546881.1.1615481181834&amp;__hsfp=512429567&amp;_ga=2.151656569.1551332056.1615481179-1803941423.1615481179\"></a><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/social-media-content-calendar?hubs_post-cta=imagebottom&amp;__hstc=233546881.ad8091ec2768c1bb4cfceb9f006c7b7b.1615481181834.1615481181834.1615481181834.1&amp;__hssc=233546881.1.1615481181834&amp;__hsfp=512429567&amp;_ga=2.151656569.1551332056.1615481179-1803941423.1615481179\"></a></p> \n<h2>Downloadable Holiday Calendar</h2> \n<p>To help you keep track of all these unique holidays, here's a Social Media Holiday Google Calendar.</p> \n<p>Aside from 2021 holidays, we've also set dates on the calendar to repeat annually — either on the exact date they occur or the weekday they occur within the month.</p> \n<p>Want to finish out your 2021 calendar with some upcoming holiday posts? Tap the + symbol in the lower right-hand corner of the calendar below to add it to your own Google calendar.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/social-media-content-calendar?hubs_post-cta=image\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-04-12%20at%203.30.43%20PM.png?width=650&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202019-04-12%20at%203.30.43%20PM.png\" width=\"650\" alt=\"social media holiday calendar template\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\" /></a><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/social-media-content-calendar?hubs_post-cta=imagebottom&amp;__hstc=233546881.ad8091ec2768c1bb4cfceb9f006c7b7b.1615481181834.1615481181834.1615481181834.1&amp;__hssc=233546881.1.1615481181834&amp;__hsfp=512429567&amp;_ga=2.151656569.1551332056.1615481179-1803941423.1615481179\">Use the Above Template to Plan Out Your Social Media Holiday Posts</a></p> \n<h2>National &amp; Global Holiday Calendar: 2021</h2> \n<p>The list isn't exhaustive (there are a lot of <a href=\"https://www.usfoods.com/our-services/business-trends/let-food-holidays-work-for-you.html\">food-specific holidays</a> out there), and these dates and hashtags may still be subject to change. But this is a great starting point for social media marketers who want to learn more about what's trending and how they can plan their content in a way that will be fun and engaging on social platforms.</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/social-media-holiday-calendar-2017#january\">January 2021 Social Media Holidays</a></li> \n <li><a +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3e56e15d-47bd-46c9-a256-99fde52abfe7.png","linkMd5":"168e1aba56b7785f53e06bc990ec7b8a","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn32@2020_6/2021/09/27/16-55-42-295_f265e6907ec7aa82.webp","destWidth":454,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":5078,"destBytes":7114,"author":"Amanda Sellers","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3e56e15d-47bd-46c9-a256-99fde52abfe7.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn32@2020_6/2021/09/27/16-55-42-295_f265e6907ec7aa82.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-04-12%20at%203.30.43%20PM.png?width=650&name=Screen%20Shot%202019-04-12%20at%203.30.43%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn7@2020_6/2021/09/27/16-55-46-188_0563389b70958c6a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-09-23%20at%2010-59-09%20AM-png.png?width=500&name=Screen%20Shot%202021-09-23%20at%2010-59-09%20AM-png.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn66@2020_6/2021/09/27/16-55-45-220_6ee48e637d63a367.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-09-23%20at%2011-00-23%20AM-png.png?width=500&name=Screen%20Shot%202021-09-23%20at%2011-00-23%20AM-png.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn32@2020_5/2021/09/27/16-55-45-960_280f1950c1f058ea.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-09-23%20at%2011-02-44%20AM-png.png?width=500&name=Screen%20Shot%202021-09-23%20at%2011-02-44%20AM-png.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn86@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-46-929_643c1ee61c30bbda.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-09-23%20at%2011-03-26%20AM-png.png?width=500&name=Screen%20Shot%202021-09-23%20at%2011-03-26%20AM-png.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn98@2020_6/2021/09/27/16-55-44-500_5c48f4aedd0f8769.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-09-23%20at%2011-07-04%20AM-png.png?width=500&name=Screen%20Shot%202021-09-23%20at%2011-07-04%20AM-png.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn62@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-45-541_0d4e9c6b7086cc7f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-09-23%20at%2011-04-31%20AM-png-1.png?width=500&name=Screen%20Shot%202021-09-23%20at%2011-04-31%20AM-png-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn92@2020_5/2021/09/27/16-55-44-898_b05b5a7bf2142fd4.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-09-23%20at%2011-08-35%20AM-png.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn89@2020_5/2021/09/27/16-55-48-701_4267f65dd7530178.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-09-23%20at%2011-09-21%20AM-png.png?width=500&name=Screen%20Shot%202021-09-23%20at%2011-09-21%20AM-png.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn35@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-44-484_2167fe1f63dc24af.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-09-23%20at%2011-10-03%20AM-png.png?width=500&name=Screen%20Shot%202021-09-23%20at%2011-10-03%20AM-png.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn28@2020_5/2021/09/27/16-55-44-082_2347caa3bc11f839.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-09-23%20at%2011-12-39%20AM-png.png?width=500&name=Screen%20Shot%202021-09-23%20at%2011-12-39%20AM-png.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn100@2020_2/2021/09/27/16-55-46-284_42a1bea6deae88c0.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-09-23%20at%2011-13-29%20AM-png.png?width=500&name=Screen%20Shot%202021-09-23%20at%2011-13-29%20AM-png.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn94@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-44-927_5523ac2ea0b21df6.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-09-23%20at%2011-14-15%20AM-png.png?width=500&name=Screen%20Shot%202021-09-23%20at%2011-14-15%20AM-png.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn57@2020_4/2021/09/27/16-55-47-529_afad69c1e62cbb4c.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3798b15e-747c-485c-9978-e2892c7e9811.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn19@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-44-001_dfeb7fad21cab804.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fsocial-media-holiday-calendar-2017&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn98@2020_2/2021/09/27/16-55-46-872_36aa0155e4e75688.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1632761741241},{"createdTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","updatedTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","title":"What is an A/A Test & Do You Really Need to Use It?","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/aa-test","description":"<p>What's worse than working with no data?</p>  \n<p>Working with \"bad\" data.</p> \n<p>As marketers, we love to test headlines, call-to-actions, and keywords (to name a few). One of the ways we do this is by running A/B tests.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=5d42eade-1de3-4ff1-adba-6b1521e6cbde&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Free Download: A/B Testing Guide and Kit\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5d42eade-1de3-4ff1-adba-6b1521e6cbde.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p>As a refresher, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-do-a-b-testing?_ga=2.32430716.331648612.1631219468-1271636242.1631219468\">A/B testing</a> is the process of splitting an audience to test a number of variations of a campaign and determining which performs better.</p> \n<p>But A/B testing isn't foolproof.</p> \n<p>In fact, it's a complicated process. You often have to rely on testing software to pull the data, and there's a high probability of receiving a false positive. If you're not careful, you could make incorrect assumptions about what makes people click.</p> \n<p>So how can you ensure your A/B test is operating correctly? This is where A/A testing comes in. Think of it as a test to the test.</p> \n<p>The idea behind an A/A test is that the experience is the same for each group, therefore the expected KPI (Key Performance Indicator) will also be the same for each group.</p> \n<p>For example, if 20% of group A fills out a form on a landing page, the expected result is that 20% of group B (who are interacting with an identical version of the landing page) will do the same.</p> \n<h2>Differences Between an A/A Test and an A/B Test</h2> \n<p>Performing an A/A test is similar to that of an A/B test; an audience is divided into two similarly sized groups, but instead of directing each group to different variations of content, each group interacts with identical versions of the same piece of content.</p> \n<p>Here’s another way to think about it: have you ever heard the idiom, \"Comparing apples to oranges\"? An A/B test does exactly that — compares two different variants of a piece of content to see which performs better. An A/A test compares an apple to, well, an identical apple.</p> \n<p>When running an A/B test, you program a testing tool to change or hide some part of the content. This is not necessary for an A/A test.</p> \n<p>An A/A test also requires a larger sample size than an A/B test to prove a significant bias. And, due to such a large sample size, these tests take much longer to complete.</p> \n<h2>How to Do A/A Testing</h2> \n<p>Exactly how you do an A/A will vary depending on the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/a-b-testing-tools?_ga=2.196476910.331648612.1631219468-1271636242.1631219468\">testing tool</a> you use. If you're a HubSpot Enterprise customer conducting an A/A or A/B test on an email, for example, HubSpot will automatically split traffic to your variations so that each variation receives a random sampling of visitors.</p> \n<p>Let's cover the steps to run an A/A test.</p> \n<h3>1. Create two identical versions of a piece of content — the control and the variant.</h3> \n<p>Once your content is created, identify two groups of the same sample size you would like to conduct the test with.</p> \n<h3>2. Identify your KPI.</h3> \n<p>A KPI is a measure of performance over a period of time. For example, your KPI could be the number of visitors who click on a call-to-action.</p> \n<h3>3. Using your testing tool, split your audience equally and randomly, and send one group to the control and the other group to the variant.</h3> \n<p>Run the test until the control and variation hit a determined number of visitors.</p> \n<h3>4. Track the KPI for both groups.</h3> \n<p>Because both groups are sent to identical pieces of content, they should behave the same. Therefore, the expected result will be inconclusive.</p> \n<h2>A/A Test Uses</h2> \n<p>A/A testing is primarily used when an organization implements a new A/B testing software or reconfigures a current one.</p> \n<p>You can run an A/A test to accomplish the following:</p> \n<h3>1. To check the accuracy of an A/B testing software.</h3> \n<p>The intended result of an A/A test is that the audience reacts similarly to the same piece of content.</p> \n<p>But what if they don't?</p> \n<p>Here's an example: Company XYZ is running an A/A test on a new landing page. Two groups are sent to two identical versions of the landing page (the control and the variant). Group A has a conversion rate of 8%, while Group B has a rate of 2%.</p> \n<p>In theory, the conversion rate should be identical. When there is no difference between the control and the variant, the expected result will be inconclusive. Yet, sometimes a \"winner\" is declared on two identical versions.</p> \n<p>When this happens, it is essential to evaluate the testing platform. The tool may have been misconfigured, or it could be ineffective.</p> \n<h3>2. To set a baseline conversion rate for future A/B tests.</h3> \n<p>Let's imagine that Company XYZ runs another A/A test on the landing page. This time, the results of Group A and Group B are identical — both groups achieve an 8% conversion rate.</p> \n<p>Therefore, 8% is the baseline conversion rate. With this in mind, the company can run future A/B tests with the goal of exceeding this rate.</p> \n<p>If, for example, the company runs an A/B test on a new version of the landing page and receives a conversion rate of 8.02%, the result is not statistically significant.</p> \n<h2>A/A Testing: Do You Really Need to Use It?</h2> \n<p>To run an A/A test, or not — that is the question. And the answer will depend on who you ask. There is no denying that A/A testing is a hotly debated topic.</p> \n<p>Perhaps the most prevalent argument against A/A testing boils down to one factor: time.</p> \n<p>A/A testing takes a considerable amount of time to run. In fact, A/A tests typically require a much larger sample size than A/B tests. When testing two identical versions, you need a large sample size to prove a significant bias. Therefore, the test will take more time to complete, and this may eat into time spent running other valuable tests.</p> \n<p>However, it makes sense to run an A/A test in some cases, especially if you are uncertain about a new A/B testing software and want additional proof that it's both functional and accurate. A/A tests are a low-risk method to ensure your tests are set up properly.</p> \n<p>A/A testing can help you prepare for a successful AB testing program, provide data benchmarks, and identify any discrepancies in your data.</p> \n<p>Although A/A tests have utility, running such a test should be a relatively rare occurrence. While A/A test can run a \"health check\" on a new A/B tool or software, it may not be worth optimizing every minor alteration to your website or marketing campaign due to the considerable amount of time it takes to run.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=1fb2d19e-9ff9-40a7-947e-cc67e7d472cb&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"The Ultimate A/B Testing Kit\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/1fb2d19e-9ff9-40a7-947e-cc67e7d472cb.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Faa-test&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 22 Sep 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5d42eade-1de3-4ff1-adba-6b1521e6cbde.png","linkMd5":"33f3112aef03ff60f8202e9e6c9e863e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn88@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-42-636_1068aaa9a6acaf25.webp","destWidth":378,"destHeight":60,"sourceBytes":3884,"destBytes":5928,"author":"Erin Rodrigue","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5d42eade-1de3-4ff1-adba-6b1521e6cbde.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn88@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-42-636_1068aaa9a6acaf25.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/1fb2d19e-9ff9-40a7-947e-cc67e7d472cb.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn62@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-48-465_39667621be686c34.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Faa-test&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn45@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-43-942_a3547e31f9c48657.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1632761741208},{"createdTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","updatedTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","title":"The Best Integrated Marketing Campaigns, According to HubSpot Marketers","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/our-favorite-integrated-marketing-examples","description":"<p>Integrated marketing is any marketing campaign that uses multiple channels in execution. For example, you might see a popular new donut flavor in a commercial, then drive past the donut shop to see posters of the donut. And if you flip through Instagram once you get to your destination, you might see a GIF on your feed, displaying the donut.</p>  \n<p>This style of marketing is great for boosting leads and brand awareness. Using multiple sources to deliver the same campaign diversifies the audience that interacts with its content. In this post, let's look at some recent integrated marketing campaigns that delivered a great experience for customers and leads alike.</p> \n<a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=aacfe6c7-71e6-4f49-979f-76099062afa0&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"→ Download Now: Free Marketing Plan Template\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/aacfe6c7-71e6-4f49-979f-76099062afa0.png\" align=\"middle\"></a> \n<h2>Best Integrated Marketing Campaigns</h2> \n<h3>1. Hyundai Elantra</h3> \n<p style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Channels:&nbsp;<span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Spotify, Website</span></p> \n<p style=\"font-weight: bold;\"><span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">A great example of an integrated marketing campaign comes from the 2021 Hyundai Elantra award-winning campaign.</span></p> \n<p style=\"font-weight: bold;\"><span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">To increase brand awareness among the younger, millennial demographic, Hyundai partnered with Spotify and musicians in LA, Miami, and NYC to give customers an insider's guide of the city.</span></p> \n<p style=\"font-weight: bold;\"><span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">The city guides were made available to audiences everywhere through Spotify podcasts, where drivers could follow along from place to place by listening to the podcast.</span></p> \n<p style=\"font-weight: bold;\"><span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">These guides were audio, video, and even a microsite that housed itineraries and stop descriptions.</span></p> \n<p style=\"font-weight: bold;\"><span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">As an associate marketing manager at HubSpot, I think this is a great campaign that utilizes the right channels for the audience that Hyundai is trying to reach.</span></p> \n<h3>2. \"Fatima,\" the movie</h3> \n<p><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Channels:</span> Facebook Premiere, other social media channels</p> \n<p>In 2020, McKinney and Picturehouse teamed up <span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; font-weight: 400;\">to launch a new film, Fatima, the historical drama of the Virgin Mary’s appearances to three children in Fátima, Portugal, over a hundred years ago.</span></p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; font-weight: 400;\">The companies developed social content to inspire, connect and elevate the film’s key themes. It was a social campaign that included more than 200 pieces of content reaching 14 million people.</span></p> \n<div> \n <div> \n  <p>But one month before the movie's release, the world and Fatima were put on pause due to COVID-19. To keep people interested and engagement up for another four months, the companies created “Together In Spirit,” a virtual pilgrimage transporting people to the Shrine at Fátima. The campaign videos got more than 27 million views.</p> \n  <p>At a time when everyone was isolated, the goal of the broadcast was to provide a message of hope, and in the process, it became the best-performing Facebook Premiere event in motion picture history.</p> \n </div> \n</div> \n<h3>3. Hulu's HAHA Awards</h3> \n<p><strong>Channels</strong>: Twitter, LinkedIn, YouTube, Website</p> \n<p>One of my favorite integrated marketing campaigns to come along is the launch of Hulu's HAHA Awards. HAHA is a clever acronym, standing for \"Hilarious Animated Hulu Awards,\" which I love.</p> \n<p>Initially, I saw the commercial during a regular ad break while watching — of course — Hulu:</p> \n<div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-wrapper hs-responsive-embed\" style=\"width: 100%; height: auto; position: relative; overflow: hidden; padding: 0; max-width: 560px; max-height: 315px; min-width: 256px; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-inner-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.25%; margin: 0;\">\n  <iframe class=\"hs-responsive-embed-iframe\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/5dv9BUqiROY\" width=\"560\" height=\"315\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n </div> \n</div> \n<p>Because there's no awards show for animated content, the team at Hulu decided to change that — and get fans involved. Fans can vote for the awards on <a href=\"https://twitter.com/hulu/status/1280894695845974017\">Twitter</a> and <a href=\"http://hulu.com/haha\">Hulu's website</a>.</p> \n<p>I appreciate that anyone with a Twitter account can participate in voting, regardless of if they are Hulu customers. Some of the categories are popular TV shows, like Archer and Bob Burgers, so the masses can vote. Additionally, people without a Twitter or Hulu account can vote, just by visiting the website.</p> \n<p>The tactic of using YouTube to introduce the campaign, as well as alternate methods of voting, makes this campaign a chance for Hulu to delight customers and earn more quality leads from social media.</p> \n<h3>4. Victoria Monet's \"Audience\"</h3> \n<p><strong>Channels:</strong> Instagram, Facebook, Billboards</p> \n<p>For the single, \"Experience,\" R&amp;B singers <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/victoriamonet/\">Victoria Monet</a> and <a href=\"https://www.khalidofficial.com/\">Khalid</a> collaborated with Spotify for a release campaign. The campaign included online and in-person marketing tactics and is the favorite campaign of HubSpot staff writer Jay Fuchs.</p> \n<p>In Canada, there was a billboard put up in Toronto, promoting the song's Spotify release. In response, Monet posted a picture on Instagram to share with her fans and promote the single:</p> \n<iframe style=\"border: none; overflow: hidden; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\" src=\"https://www.facebook.com/plugins/post.php?href=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2FVictoriaMonet%2Fposts%2F3145924568836475&amp;show_text=true&amp;width=552&amp;height=661&amp;appId\" width=\"552\" height=\"661\" frameborder=\"0\"></iframe> \n<p>The use of online and in-person marketing methods makes this integrated campaign one that can be seen from anywhere. From the billboard in Canada to international Facebook and Instagram fans, the release of \"Experience\" was anticipated globally. In fact, in one month, the single became Monet's <a href=\"https://open.spotify.com/artist/63XBtGSEZINSyXylZxEUbv\">most popular song</a> on the streaming service.</p> \n<h3>5. Gillette, \"The Best Men Can Be\"</h3> \n<p><strong>Channels: </strong>Website, YouTube</p> \n<p>\"In 2019, Gillette launched its campaign, 'The Best Men Can Be'. The campaign included an <a href=\"https://t.sidekickopen79.com/s1t/c/5/f18dQhb0S7lM8dDMPbW2n0x6l2B9nMJN7t5X-FdSD1CN64k8yjQBdbMV1Xcyb5N-pjx103?te=W3R5hFj4cm2zwW4mKLS-4rCvX6W4hCVj23Fbt5SW4myB8V3QJdFtW3X-PC_4hnSjdW1VnjYP3M1XSvW4hLxWp3K6KcJn4fJgsx1V3&amp;si=7000000000560688&amp;pi=09f18490-1c40-4985-c598-cbf31cf36894\">inspiring video</a>, a <a href=\"https://t.sidekickopen79.com/s1t/c/5/f18dQhb0S7lM8dDMPbW2n0x6l2B9nMJN7t5X-FdSD1CN64k8yjQBdbMV1Xcyb5N-pjx103?te=W3R5hFj4cm2zwW3P28cb3K9G6yW1JxwY51LwWgDW4hLTFJ3CcYkTW1LF6VG1Gyy3_W4fdhmr41n_sSf41n_n904&amp;si=7000000000560688&amp;pi=09f18490-1c40-4985-c598-cbf31cf36894\">landing page</a> that celebrates male advocates and leaders in the community, and a hashtag, #thebestmencanbe, to encourage user participation across social channels,\" says HubSpot Marketing Manager, Caroline Forsey.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/integrated%20campaigns-3.png\" alt=\"integrated marketing campaigns: gillette\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><span style=\"font-family: 'times new roman', times;\"><a href=\"https://gillette.com/en-us/about/the-best-men-can-be\">Image Source</a></span></p> \n<p>\"The campaign, created in response to the #metoo movement, urged men to hold themselves to a higher standard,\" says Forsey. In the corresponding ad for the movement, viewers are shown hypothetical real-life instances of men stepping in to be themselves, and making positive change in their community. To heighten awareness of the movement, the landing page highlights real accounts of men upholding the hashtag Gillette created.</p> \n<p>\"While the campaign <a href=\"https://t.sidekickopen79.com/s1t/c/5/f18dQhb0S7lM8dDMPbW2n0x6l2B9nMJN7t5X-FdSD1CN64k8yjQBdbMV1Xcyb5N-pjx103?te=W3R5hFj4cm2zwW4mKLS-3_R5ZJW3K9F8z3P7-dJW3XtNr93_rhg1W3ZY6x-4fGvkrW3K9FJ11GyZbyW45LLHw41n_L3w3ZY7qp48-2&amp;si=7000000000560688&amp;pi=09f18490-1c40-4985-c598-cbf31cf36894\">received some backlash</a> from both stakeholders and consumers, I think it was worth the price because it redefined the shaving brand as a relevant, values-oriented brand. For me personally, I shared the ad with all my male friends and family members, and it sparked a discussion — which, really, is what marketing is all about,\" Forsey commented.</p> \n<p>Gillette's tactic of getting their customers involved proved to be successful in the moment and long-term. Discussions, like the one Forsey had with men in her life, were happening nationwide. In fact, my university class had one about the campaign. This integrated campaign, boosted by real accounts, was proven to be not only successful but valuable.</p> \n<h3>6. REI, #RecreateResponsibly</h3> \n<p><strong>Channels:</strong> Website, Instagram</p> \n<p>Outdoor activity is at the core of REI's products. <a href=\"https://www.rei.com/\">REI</a> sells camping essentials, such as tents, clothes, and insulated containers. In 2020, REI partnered with several groups in Washington state that aim to preserve wildlife and nature, making it the favorite campaign of HubSpot marketing manager, Clint Fontanella.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.outdooralliance.org/\">Outdoor Alliance</a>, <a href=\"https://outdoorindustry.org/\">The Outdoor Industry Association</a>, and national parks came together for the #RecreateResponsibly campaign.
