\">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 22 Sep 2021 21:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/fd1d8911-635d-4be6-8755-5ab6a332b129.png","linkMd5":"b63a2909d1b10087127603f9d1176bdf","destWidth":476,"destHeight":60,"sourceBytes":4464,"destBytes":7216,"author":"cchi@hubspot.com (Clifford Chi)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/fd1d8911-635d-4be6-8755-5ab6a332b129.png":null,"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/jitterbit-cloud-integration-platform.png?width=650&name=jitterbit-cloud-integration-platform.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn78@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-44-105_4a1884f775955dd0.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/operations-hub-cloud-integration-platform.png?width=650&name=operations-hub-cloud-integration-platform.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn6@2020_2/2021/09/27/16-55-47-641_9a422361cb3c9150.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/zapier-cloud-integration-platform.jpeg?width=650&name=zapier-cloud-integration-platform.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn36@2020_6/2021/09/27/16-55-44-071_47143c755bae1289.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/mulesoft-cloud-integration-platform.jpeg?width=650&name=mulesoft-cloud-integration-platform.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn10@2020_4/2021/09/27/16-55-48-225_176fceef5e6e1463.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/ibm-appconnect-cloud-integration-platform.png?width=650&name=ibm-appconnect-cloud-integration-platform.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn65@2020_4/2021/09/27/16-55-47-191_1240fa9b7fed10ed.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/dell-boomi-cloud-integration-platform.jpeg?width=650&name=dell-boomi-cloud-integration-platform.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn30@2020_5/2021/09/27/16-55-43-968_b0fdf3b470a12285.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3cb695d9-7dc5-4e70-8523-1e330e6bd58a.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn57@2020_6/2021/09/27/16-55-47-219_d6970030134c53c8.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fcloud-integration&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn36@2020_4/2021/09/27/16-55-46-658_e407c7164bf654ab.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1632761741217},{"createdTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","updatedTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","title":"Organic Marketing vs. Paid Marketing: Everything You Need to Know","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/organic-marketing","description":"<p>Have you ever heard of the law of attraction? It sounds 'woo-woo' but stay with me here. It's a philosophy that means we can attract into our lives whatever we're focusing on. More simply put, positive thoughts will naturally bring positivity your way.</p> \n<p>Organic marketing works similarly. The goal is to <em>naturally</em> attract your audience to your brand or business. But how do you do that?</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>In this post, we'll go over what organic marketing is and how it's different from paid forms of marketing.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=aacfe6c7-71e6-4f49-979f-76099062afa0&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"→ Download Now: Free Marketing Plan Template\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/aacfe6c7-71e6-4f49-979f-76099062afa0.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p>The main goal of organic marketing is to increase brand awareness and build a connection with your audience, whether through educational or entertaining content. Of course, as a business, you'll need multiple ways to attract leads and convert users. Organic marketing is just one way to do that (paid marketing is another, which we'll dive into below).</p> \n<p>With organic marketing, you can attract visitors to your site, who will hopefully convert to paid customers eventually. The goal is to keep your business top of mind when it comes time for a consumer to make purchasing decisions.</p> \n<p>Additionally, organic marketing impacts your paid marketing efforts because if someone organically comes across your website, you can retarget them later with paid ads (on social media, search engines, etc.).</p> \n<p>Ultimately, the goal of organic marketing is to drive traffic to your site. While you'll use <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/organic-vs-paid-social-media\">social media channels</a>, the best place to spend your time with organic marketing is SEO. In fact, SEO drives <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/marketing-statistics\">1000%+ more traffic</a> than organic social media.</p> \n<p>To measure the effectiveness of your organic marketing efforts, you'll look at which content is driving the most traffic to your site, leads generated from those campaigns, and which channels drive the highest amount of high converting traffic to your site.</p> \n<h2>Organic Marketing Examples</h2> \n<p>Before we dive into the differences between organic and paid marketing, let's look at some examples of organic marketing:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Unpaid social media posts on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Snapchat, Pinterest, Tik Tok, etc.</li> \n <li>Blog posts (this very post you're reading is an organic marketing effort)</li> \n <li>Guest posts</li> \n <li>User-generated content</li> \n <li>Email newsletters</li> \n <li>SEO</li> \n <li>Online PR and link generation</li> \n <li>YouTube</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Now, let's learn a little bit more about inorganic, or paid marketing.</p> \n<p>Inorganic marketing strategies include paid search ads, paid social media ads, sponsored posts, display ads, video ads on YouTube, etc. With paid media, you can micro-target your ideal audience and reach people who might never have heard of your business otherwise.</p> \n<p>While organic marketing is more like word-of-mouth marketing, paid marketing is similar to sales-focused marketing. The goals for the two are very different. One is to attract audiences and increase brand awareness and the other is to convert audiences on a specific campaign.</p> \n<p>You'll measure the success of paid marketing through <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/return-on-ad-spend\">return on ad spend (ROAS)</a>, driving impressions, achieving high conversion rates, etc.</p> \n<p>Now that we know more about the differences between organic and inorganic/paid marketing, let's dive into how to build an organic marketing strategy.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h3>1. Analyze your current traffic habits.</h3> \n<p>To build an organic marketing strategy, you should analyze your audience's current traffic habits on your site and then compare them to your ideal audience.</p> \n<p>First, it's important to know where you get the most organic traffic currently. Is it from your YouTube channel, blog posts, or email newsletters?</p> \n<p>Then, think about how your ideal audience usually discovers a business like yours. Do they rely on industry publications, social media, or review sites?</p> \n<p>It's important to understand what type of organic traffic that your target audience is consuming so that you can create that content. Additionally, you need to understand what organic traffic is already working for your business so you can continue creating that content.</p> \n<p>Organic marketing only works when you truly understand your audience and what they want to see.</p> \n<h3>2. Create content.</h3> \n<p>Once you know which channels you want to focus on and where your target audience spends their time online, then it's time to start creating content. However, before you can just create content, you need to brainstorm the types of content assets you want to create and build a list of several ideas.</p> \n<p>For instance, if you want to focus on blogging, do your keyword research and competitor analysis, and then build a list of keywords you can create posts around. Then, you can start creating content.</p> \n<p>However, if you want to focus on creating case studies or research, you'll have to do first-hand research, and then decide how you'll publish your findings.</p> \n<p>Before you can create content, you'll need to know which platforms and channels you want to focus on.</p> \n<h3>3. Optimize your content.</h3> \n<p>If you were to ask what makes organic content work, the answer would be SEO. You'll want to optimize all your content so that it will show up on search engines and social media platforms. For example, the strategies might be similar, but you'll optimize your blog content, video descriptions on YouTube, and social media posts.</p> \n<p>To <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/seo-strategy\">optimize this content</a>, usually, the strategies involve incorporating keywords into your content, having a great design, and using metadata to let search engines know what your content is about.</p> \n<h3>4. Evaluate and improve.</h3> \n<p>Lastly, the key to any organic marketing strategy is to evaluate and iterate. You can use tools, like <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/seo\">HubSpot's SEO marketing software</a> to plan your SEO strategy, optimize your content, and measure real return on investment.</p> \n<p>This type of software will help you measure and keep track of your KPIs so you can see what's working and what isn't.</p> \n<p>Organic marketing is all about bringing people to you, instead of reaching out to people via paid methods. With organic marketing, you'll create several types of content to keep people engaged and interested in your brand. When it comes time to make a purchasing decision, they'll think of you first.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=af934ebe-a3e6-4d2a-b12f-1c7ea40641fb&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"Marketing Plan Template\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/af934ebe-a3e6-4d2a-b12f-1c7ea40641fb.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Forganic-marketing&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 14 Sep 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/aacfe6c7-71e6-4f49-979f-76099062afa0.png","linkMd5":"2340ad90fff5c20ae586f26a2b246b34","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn4@2020_6/2021/09/27/16-55-41-606_5a38291bbbb54ba3.webp","destWidth":433,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":5125,"destBytes":6842,"author":"Rebecca Riserbato","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/aacfe6c7-71e6-4f49-979f-76099062afa0.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn4@2020_6/2021/09/27/16-55-41-606_5a38291bbbb54ba3.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/af934ebe-a3e6-4d2a-b12f-1c7ea40641fb.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn6@2020_2/2021/09/27/16-55-44-989_b69ef96b2d492171.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Forganic-marketing&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn31@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-48-737_a847dc577bb4d5d3.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1632761741216},{"createdTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","updatedTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","title":"20 Technical Skills Every Marketer Needs","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/technical-skills","description":"<p>Traditionally, the marketing field emphasized creative thinking over technical skills. But to build a successful career as a marketer today, you need more than a knack for pitching ideas and coming up with clever copy.</p> \n<p>That's where technical skills come in. These skills are earned from experiences or education (think, data analysis, project management, and computer programming).</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=4e634041-e1ce-4a85-8e65-aea12fc10b84&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"→ Click here to download leadership lessons from HubSpot founder, Dharmesh  Shah [Free Guide].\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/4e634041-e1ce-4a85-8e65-aea12fc10b84.png\"></a></p> \n<p>Now more than ever, employers are emphasizing skills over pedigree. LinkedIn data from the past year shows a <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/business/talent/blog/talent-strategy/why-skills-based-hiring-starts-with-job-descriptions\"><span>20% increase in managers</span></a> who don't have a traditional four-year degree. This trend highlights the push toward skills-based hiring, which prioritizes a person's capabilities over their credentials.</p> \n<p>Hiring for skill rather than a degree is a good step forward for all, and it's wise to leverage your strengths when going after a new role or promotion. That's why you want to make sure you have the right technical skills for your career path to stay competitive and advance in your career.</p> \n<p>Let's walk through all you need to know about technical skills and which ones you should look to develop as a marketer.</p> \n<h2>What are technical skills?</h2> \n<p>Often known as <a href=\"https://www.indeed.com/career-advice/resumes-cover-letters/hard-skills-for-a-resume\"><span>hard skills</span></a>, technical skills are easily defined and measured competencies you gain through training or education. They allow you to complete a job-specific task and often vary from one industry to another.</p> \n<p>While technical skills are typically required for engineers, business analysts, mathematicians, and scientists, more industries than ever need employees with technical knowledge. In fact, Gartner found that 58% of the <a href=\"https://www.gartner.com/en/newsroom/press-releases/2021-02-03-gartner-hr-research-finds-fifty-eight-percent-of-the-workforce-will-need-new-skill-sets-to-do-their-jobs-successfully\"><span>workforce needs new skills</span></a> to successfully do their jobs. This is largely due to the digital transformation and massive increase in data, which requires people who can use technology to interpret data and take action to drive a company forward.</p> \n<p>Before scrambling into a data analysis course, it's important to realize that there are dozens of technical skills that don't require you to become part marketer, part computer scientist. Let's take a look at the different types of skills so you know which are right for you.</p> \n<h3><span style=\"font-size: 14px; color: #434343;\">Types of Technical Skills</span></h3> \n<p>With rapidly advancing technology, nearly every role requires some sort of technical skill. Here are several types you may come across in the marketing world.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/lDtZpD1aZFsWHuLRxxKGgy69ShfwenwENaoCkkiVJ0qm3c_Wt0JnhF4041IMwem7tpzCoKHFHWdk4EEUeiggV72-eGflgmeOlt_0BP94kUyu3wR1_LHSJpRDJ_tIDVzyPDNmQ_s8=s0\" width=\"556\" height=\"368\"></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://www.thebalancecareers.com/marketing-skills-list-2062431\"><span>Image Source</span></a></p> \n<p>While the skills associated with creativity, negotiation, stress management, communication, and public speaking are usually considered \"<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/soft-skills\"><span>soft skills</span></a>,\" categories like technology and analytical thinking involve technical skills.</p> \n<p>Similar to technical skills, soft skills are learned through experience or education. These skills are harder to measure, but you'll need them to communicate with your team, negotiate a project deadline, come up with creative ideas, and prioritize your workload.</p> \n<p>For example, a project manager may have a positive attitude and excellent time management skills (both soft skills), but understanding the ins and outs of the company's CMS system (a technical skill) is crucial for timely deliverables and successful projects.</p> \n<p>Here's an overview of the types of technical skills needed for different marketing roles.</p> \n<h4>Digital Media and Design</h4> \n<ul> \n <li>Graphic design software (Adobe InDesign, Photoshop, Illustrator, After Effects, Premiere)</li> \n</ul> \n<ul> \n <li>Content management systems (CMS)</li> \n <li>Image and file management</li> \n <li>Content curation</li> \n</ul> \n<h4>Project Management</h4> \n<ul> \n <li>Project management software (such as Asana, Trello, or ClickUp)</li> \n <li>Budget planning</li> \n <li>Risk management</li> \n <li>Project planning</li> \n <li>Content management systems (CMS)</li> \n <li>Task management</li> \n</ul> \n<h4>Marketing and Content Creation</h4> \n<ul> \n <li>Data analysis</li> \n <li>Campaign management</li> \n <li>Budgeting</li> \n <li>Content management systems (CMS)</li> \n <li>Interviewing</li> \n <li>Vendor management</li> \n <li>Pitching</li> \n <li>Copywriting</li> \n <li>Editing</li> \n <li>Researching and reporting</li> \n <li>SEO/SEM</li> \n <li>Digital ad management</li> \n <li>Social media marketing</li> \n <li>Content strategy</li> \n</ul> \n<h2>Technical Skills in the Workplace</h2> \n<p>Now that you know what type of technical skills apply to your field, how do you know which to develop? To understand which skills are most important for the future, LinkedIn performed a study to find the <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/business/learning/blog/learning-and-development/most-in-demand-skills-2020\"><span>most in-demand skills</span></a>—several of which apply to marketers.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/xwOvNDNV7Nh9NNeECA-m7aC0GmJjK8WDMr8JTvqDIN-BjKd6R52MNlhuoeqF8vyh7pI7Vlc-CUzMDX_6R-pKZURSZZsuX5Tg-SvrjfwaWi-L0vtjzp1JAPa508R0P5y_AxHZLLle=s0\" width=\"407\" height=\"601\" alt=\"Skills Companies Need Most\"></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/business/learning/blog/learning-and-development/most-in-demand-skills-2020\"><span>Image Source</span></a></p> \n<p>Technical skills like analytical reasoning, affiliate marketing, and business analysis are essential to succeeding as a marketer. But you'll need more than those to build a thriving career. To understand the skills you need in the workplace, start by looking at job descriptions for positions you want now — and in the future.</p> \n<p>Hiring managers often create a list of \"required\" and \"recommended\" skills they want candidates to have. Required skills are often the technical skills you need to perform the job well after you're hired, while recommended skills are capabilities the company is willing to help you develop through training.</p> \n<p>Once you've scoured job descriptions and created a list of technical skills employers look for, it's also smart to talk with your manager about the skills you need to advance your career. They should be able to point you in the right direction for your individual development.</p> \n<p>If you work for a supportive company, your manager may offer resources to help you work toward those skills. This could include stipends for books, courses, certifications, or schooling. Or it could mean putting you on projects that give you hands-on experience, like managing the budget for a social campaign or designing the visuals for the weekly email newsletter.</p> \n<p>Technical skills in marketing vary by role, so it's important to do your research and consider your career path before asking your manager for help. If they don't know which direction you want to go, they won't be able to provide the specific skills you'll need to get there.</p> \n<p>Look at the examples below to highlight the skills you already have and learn more about which ones you may need.</p> \n<h3>Examples of Technical Skills in the Workplace</h3> \n<h4>Digital Media and Design</h4> \n<ul> \n <li>Graphic and web design (Adobe InDesign, Photoshop, Illustrator, After Effects, Premiere)</li> \n</ul> \n<ul> \n <li>UX/UI research and design</li> \n</ul> \n<ul> \n <li>Database management</li> \n</ul> \n<ul> \n <li>Animation</li> \n</ul> \n<ul> \n <li>Interactive media management</li> \n</ul> \n<ul> \n <li>Usability testing</li> \n</ul> \n<ul> \n <li>Photography</li> \n</ul> \n<ul> \n <li>Content management systems (Notion, Asana, Monday, Trello, WordPress, Squarespace, Wix)</li> \n</ul> \n<ul> \n <li>HTML, CSS, Java, or other coding languages</li> \n <li>Data visualization</li> \n <li>Video and audio production</li> \n <li>Typography</li> \n <li>Wireframing</li> \n <li>Prototyping</li> \n <li>Color theory</li> \n <li>User modeling</li> \n</ul> \n<h4>Project Management</h4> \n<ul> \n <li>Microsoft Office</li> \n <li>Google Suite</li> \n <li>Content management systems (CMS)</li> \n <li>Project management software</li> \n <li>Budget planning</li> \n <li>Risk management</li> \n <li>Project planning</li> \n <li>Task management</li> \n</ul> \n<h4>Marketing</h4> \n<ul> \n <li>Campaign management</li> \n <li>Managing budgets</li> \n <li>Search engine optimization (SEO)</li> \n <li>Search engine marketing (SEM)</li> \n <li>Content management systems (CMS)</li> \n <li>Vendor management</li> \n <li>Social media management</li> \n <li>Ad targeting</li> \n <li>Content strategy</li> \n <li>Brand positioning and strategy</li> \n <li>Paid media management</li> \n <li>A/B testing</li> \n <li>Digital strategy</li> \n <li>Email marketing</li> \n <li>Web analytics</li> \n <li>Automation software</li> \n <li>Conversion rate optimization</li> \n <li>Omnichannel strategy</li> \n <li>Event planning</li> \n <li>Product management</li> \n</ul> \n<h4>Content Creation</h4> \n<ul> \n <li>Copywriting</li> \n <li>Technical writing</li> \n <li>Editing</li> \n <li>Pitching</li> \n <li>Researching and reporting</li> \n <li>UX copywriting</li> \n <li>SEO/SEM knowledge</li> \n <li>Content strategy and management</li> \n <li>Social media</li> \n <li>Email marketing</li> \n</ul> \n<h4>Analytics</h4> \n<ul> \n <li>Data analysis</li> \n <li>Demographics reporting</li> \n <li>Digital media testing</li> \n <li>Google Analytics</li> \n <li>Microsoft Excel and PowerPoint</li> \n <li>MATLAB</li> \n <li>Python</li> \n <li>SQL and NoSQL</li> \n <li>Identifying key performance indicators</li> \n <li>Setting metrics benchmarks</li> \n <li>Linear algebra and calculus</li> \n <li>Data visualization</li> \n <li>Data cleaning</li> \n <li>Working with APIs</li> \n <li>Tagging</li> \n</ul> \n<h2>Technical Skills to Put on a Resume</h2> \n<p>After scanning the above lists, you may have more technical skills than you realized. So which should make it on your resume?</p> \n<p>You want to highlight the skills you already have, or can easily develop, that are most relevant to the position. Aim for a list of 10-20 skills with a mix of both soft and technical skills. Pay attention to the skills listed in the \"required\" section of a job description because listing those on your resume will make you a more competitive candidate.</p> \n<p>If you have a unique technical skill for your field that an employer is looking for (say, you're a Social Media Manager and an Adobe InDesign whiz), bump it to the top of your skill list to make your resume stand out.</p> \n<p>Keep in mind, certain skills are more in-demand than others. Here are the <a href=\"https://www.indeed.com/career-advice/finding-a-job/in-demand-skills/\"><span>top 20 skills</span></a> you should consider adding to your resume (if you have them), according to Indeed.</p> \n<ol> \n <li>Cloud computing</li> \n <li>Artificial intelligence</li> \n <li>Sales leadership</li> \n <li>Analysis</li> \n <li>Translation</li> \n <li>Mobile app development</li> \n <li>People management</li> \n <li>Video production</li> \n <li>Audio production</li> \n <li>UX design</li> \n <li>SEO/SEM marketing</li> \n <li>Blockchain</li> \n <li>Industrial design</li> \n <li>Creativity</li> \n <li>Collaboration</li> \n <li>Adaptability</li> \n <li>Time management</li> \n <li>Persuasion</li> \n <li>Digital journalism</li> \n <li>Animation</li> \n</ol> \n<p>Of course, you don't want to oversell your capabilities. Make sure you actually have every skill listed on your resume. If a future employer catches you in a lie, that will be the end of your opportunity for landing the job — and it could tarnish your reputation for future roles as well.</p> \n<h2>Importance of Technical Skills</h2> \n<p>Marketing, especially digital marketing, revolves around data. The <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/818754/global-marketing-data-market-size/\"><span>global marketing data market</span></a> is projected to grow to $52.3 billion in 2021, with nearly 62% of senior industry experts using a data-sharing solution to support their teams' <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/1206485/data-sharing-solutions-marketing-usa/\"><span>marketing and advertising</span></a> efforts.</p> \n<p>Marketers use data to connect with audiences, create innovative campaigns, convert people to customers, and keep buyers coming back. But leveraging data requires certain skills.</p> \n<p>Having the sought-after technical skills lets you excel at your job and makes you a more competitive candidate for future roles. The more skills you have, the more opportunities you have to take on senior-level positions and earn a higher salary.</p> \n<p>Consider the difference between the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics national wage estimates for Marketing Specialists versus Marketing Managers. Marketing Managers, who have considerably more experience and technical skills, make an estimated $80,500 more per year than Marketing Specialists.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/U6aStaJtqo1hc12MzAxChmKXHdQUJLoh33-vINnNqPfvEaObWp8xJXFPumAcZ6E-XnTNorauUAnzGAkd3kjp1CN8RW9C6ozngEUjiYxtv91a9rqi-Yo546AzF40vxFgHuXU-2Q35=s0\" width=\"624\" height=\"132\" alt=\"National Estimates for Marketing Research Analysts\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://www.bls.gov/oes/current/oes131161.htm\"><span>Image Source</span></a></p> \n<p><img src=\"https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/X1jsGz8joqIwvEnOdi5nWfH0VL28NP4CdudNL7H2w7U9j7ZLjhtzV3nU3URJf1-A6klwN8_QlPCJ5aK_Ws4amB8zcFC362-Cx3SgmGV059jNioE7eVT36AMeeUZefBRno_lg_rCy=s0\" width=\"465\" height=\"134\" alt=\"National estimates for Marketing Managers\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://www.bls.gov/oes/current/oes112021.htm\"><span>Image Source</span></a></p> \n<p>The correlation between income and technical skills is also consistent with other industries. In 2021, the largest <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/1198202/average-salary-premium-by-tech-job-skill-area/\"><span>average salary premium</span></a> in the North American technology industry was estimated to be nearly $24,969 for IT automation expertise, followed by AI and machine learning with $14,175, and fintech with $13,799.</p> \n<p>Needless to say, learning technical skills is one way to boost your income. But it's not all you need for long-term career success.</p> \n<h3>Soft Skills vs. Technical Skills</h3> \n<p>Creativity, critical thinking, collaboration, problem-solving, and emotional intelligence are common soft skills, which are just as important as technical skills for landing a job and growing your career.</p> \n<p>Whether you're a social media specialist or a digital media analyst, you'll need certain soft skills to complement your technical knowledge and get the job done. Each marketing role has its own requirements, so do the same research that you did for the technical skills. If you get stuck, consider if you have any of the following in-demand soft skills.</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Ability to meet deadlines</li> \n <li>Decision making</li> \n <li>Handling criticism</li> \n <li>Attention to detail</li> \n <li>Critical thinking</li> \n <li>Teamwork</li> \n <li>Time management</li> \n <li>Multitasking</li> \n <li>Organizational skills</li> \n <li>Prioritizing</li> \n <li>Problem-solving</li> \n <li>Working independently</li> \n <li>Working remotely</li> \n <li>Collaboration</li> \n <li>Persuasion</li> \n <li>Adaptability</li> \n <li>Emotional intelligence</li> \n</ul> \n<h2>Technical Skills Over Time</h2> \n<p>Mastering the technical skills you need as a marketer is never done. Technology evolves, algorithms change, and new social media platforms pop up often.</p> \n<p>To stay on top of your game, you have to keep your technical skills sharp. Use them as frequently as possible, and pick up new skills when needed. I've witnessed many situations where a junior marketing hire teaches a seasoned pro a thing or two about developing a social media strategy or how to reach a certain audience.</p> \n<p>Honing your technical skills is a life-long process. So never assume you're safe to kick back and do well at your job without learning anything new. And when you do pick up a new skill or enhance a skill that you have, add it to your resume and LinkedIn profile.</p> \n<p>Because for any role, employers want candidates who have the skills they need to do their job effectively and drive company growth.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=5f7685cd-6442-4846-afea-a28dcbad007c&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New Call-to-action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5f7685cd-6442-4846-afea-a28dcbad007c.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Ftechnical-skills&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 06 Sep 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/4e634041-e1ce-4a85-8e65-aea12fc10b84.png","linkMd5":"539e77abd4171705d730250959948a83","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn35@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-42-278_a76d18c90cdcfa92.webp","destWidth":660,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":7430,"destBytes":10618,"author":"Katrina Kirsch","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/4e634041-e1ce-4a85-8e65-aea12fc10b84.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn35@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-42-278_a76d18c90cdcfa92.webp","https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/lDtZpD1aZFsWHuLRxxKGgy69ShfwenwENaoCkkiVJ0qm3c_Wt0JnhF4041IMwem7tpzCoKHFHWdk4EEUeiggV72-eGflgmeOlt_0BP94kUyu3wR1_LHSJpRDJ_tIDVzyPDNmQ_s8=s0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn21@2020_4/2021/09/27/16-55-46-243_bcf4778229b836af.webp","https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/xwOvNDNV7Nh9NNeECA-m7aC0GmJjK8WDMr8JTvqDIN-BjKd6R52MNlhuoeqF8vyh7pI7Vlc-CUzMDX_6R-pKZURSZZsuX5Tg-SvrjfwaWi-L0vtjzp1JAPa508R0P5y_AxHZLLle=s0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn24@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-44-399_6ed2c605f982242a.webp","https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/U6aStaJtqo1hc12MzAxChmKXHdQUJLoh33-vINnNqPfvEaObWp8xJXFPumAcZ6E-XnTNorauUAnzGAkd3kjp1CN8RW9C6ozngEUjiYxtv91a9rqi-Yo546AzF40vxFgHuXU-2Q35=s0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn26@2020_2/2021/09/27/16-55-45-517_f7ab1751849d8258.webp","https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/X1jsGz8joqIwvEnOdi5nWfH0VL28NP4CdudNL7H2w7U9j7ZLjhtzV3nU3URJf1-A6klwN8_QlPCJ5aK_Ws4amB8zcFC362-Cx3SgmGV059jNioE7eVT36AMeeUZefBRno_lg_rCy=s0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn63@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-44-051_6331f20d7ad67f61.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5f7685cd-6442-4846-afea-a28dcbad007c.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn38@2020_4/2021/09/27/16-55-47-520_15a22acbc5258093.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Ftechnical-skills&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn23@2020_4/2021/09/27/16-55-46-166_2c8f365eb8419ad8.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1632761741257},{"createdTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","updatedTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","title":"What is Expert Power and How Can You Develop It?","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/expert-power","description":"<p>Have you heard the expression that it takes <a href=\"https://www.bakadesuyo.com/2012/05/is-it-true-that-10000-hours-of-practice-will/\">10,000 hours of deliberate practice</a> to make you an expert?</p> \n<p>That's approximately 417 days if you were practicing 24 hours a day. Since that's impossible, calculating about 3-4 hours a day of deliberate practice, it would take around 8-10 years to be considered an expert at something.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Yet, perceived expertise is different. Much of the time we consider people at our company experts in a certain field, even if they haven't been in that field for 10 years yet.</p> \n<p>That's because they have expert power.</p> \n<p>In this post, we'll discuss what expert power is and how you can develop it as a leader.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=4e634041-e1ce-4a85-8e65-aea12fc10b84&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"→ Click here to download leadership lessons from HubSpot founder, Dharmesh  Shah [Free Guide].\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/4e634041-e1ce-4a85-8e65-aea12fc10b84.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img alt=\"expert power\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/What%20is%20Expert%20Power%20and%20How%20Can%20You%20Develop%20It%3F.png\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" title=\"\"></p> \n<h2>Examples of Expert Power</h2> \n<p>If you work in a corporate setting, those who are at the director level or above often have expert power since they've risen to their position presumably because of their extensive knowledge and experience. Many times those who have expert power are in positions of leadership, however, this doesn't always have to be the case.</p> \n<p>Expert power is situational and anyone can have it in different areas. As a millennial, growing up with technology, I'm often perceived as an expert in social media. After talking to me and hearing me discuss my love of reality TV, I'm usually given expert power in pop culture as well.</p> \n<p>On the other hand, if I was talking to my uncle, who is in a high leadership position in finance, I would have no expert power in that scenario. Expert power can switch dynamics depending on the subject matter.</p> \n<p>When you have expert power at work, you'll stand out in your career, rise the ranks to leadership, and display confidence in your area of expertise because of your high skill level.</p> \n<p>With expert power, you'll be trusted with high-pressure decisions and you'll feel more confident in your ability to make those decisions because of your expertise. Now, let's discuss the benefits of having expert power.</p> \n<h2>Benefits of Expert Power</h2> \n<h3>1. Streamlined business decisions.</h3> \n<p>With expert power comes the ability to make more informed, streamlined decisions for your company. The longer you do something, and the more you focus on your education in that area, the better decisions you'll make, and the more confident you'll be in those decisions.</p> \n<p>For example, when I was first getting started in writing, my process wasn't refined or streamlined. It took me much longer to complete writing tasks. Now that I've been a writer for over 10 years, I can write much quicker, and make better decisions in my writing. I know when I'm researching what to include and what not to include. That confidence and ability come with time, continuously working with my mentors and managers on my skills, and getting consistent feedback.</p> \n<p>When you have expert power in a certain area, your decisions are more streamlined, quicker, confident, and efficient.</p> \n<h3>2. Opportunity for career advancement.</h3> \n<p>One of the main benefits of expert power in the workplace is the ability to advance your career (hopefully at an accelerated pace). When you're getting started in your career, a great thing to do is spend a lot of time learning and developing your expertise.</p> \n<p>Once it becomes clear that you're focused on a certain area and developing certain skills, you'll have perceived expert power and be able to advance your career. Personally, I've been able to achieve promotions and advance my career because of my expert power in writing.</p> \n<h3>3. Developed leadership skills.</h3> \n<p>Besides gaining confidence and being able to further your career, you'll also be developing your leadership skills, which will be a huge benefit to your career. While I might not have expert power in something like engineering, I'm confident in my ability to lead a team of writers, because I've worked on enough teams and been doing this for a certain amount of time.</p> \n<p>However, it's important to note that just because you're an expert in a certain field doesn't mean you'll necessarily be a good leader. That's why it's important to continue developing expert power and leadership skills. Let's dive into how to do that below.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h3>1. Deliberate practice.</h3> \n<p>Becoming an expert in your field doesn't mean that you can just show up and achieve expertise through osmosis. You have to be deliberately practicing and studying. This means that the first step to developing expert power is to practice, practice, practice. Whether it's a tactical skill like construction or a conceptual skill like business strategy, you need to immerse yourself in the world. This means you might have to work an entry-level job to gain real-world experience in your industry.</p> \n<h3>2. Work with mentors and leaders.</h3> \n<p>The best way to continue developing your expert power is to work with mentors and leaders from who you can learn. Having a mentor means soaking up their knowledge, asking them for tips and advice, discussing what's going well in your career and what isn't going well, and then just listening. Expertise comes from experience and you can benefit from listening to the stories of other people's experiences. Additionally, you'll gain leadership skills by studying how your mentors lead others.</p> \n<h3>3. Volunteer your expertise.</h3> \n<p>Whatever level of expertise you have, don't be afraid to share it. If you work in a corporate setting and are a developing business leader, share your experiences and what you've learned when your team is discussing strategy. Don't be afraid to enter those conversations. Not only will people begin to realize that you're an expert in a certain area, but you'll also learn a lot from other people's feedback.</p> \n<h3>4. Never stop being a student in your industry.</h3> \n<p>To be an expert in something you also have to be a student in that industry. If you stop being a student, then your expertise will expire. You should read books, stay up to date with the news and trends in your field, and volunteer for projects at your workplace so you can soak up knowledge. That's how you'll truly develop expert power and maintain it.</p> \n<h3>5. Keep your credibility.</h3> \n<p>You'll only have expert power if you have credibility in your field. Maintaining your ethics and reliability is of vast importance because expert power only comes to those who can be trusted to make strategic business decisions on an ongoing basis. If your expertise is haphazard you won't have perceived power from those around you.</p> \n<h3>6. Work in a fast-paced environment.</h3> \n<p>A great way to develop expert power is to work in a fast-paced environment and learn to make strategic, decisive choices quickly. This means keeping yourself cool, calm, and collected in the face of a critical situation. With this experience, you'll develop excellent expert power and leadership skills.</p> \n<h3>7. Lead with HEART.</h3> \n<p>At HubSpot, our culture is defined by having <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/34234/the-hubspot-culture-code-creating-a-company-we-love.aspx\">HEART</a> -- Humble, Empathetic, Adaptable, Remarkable, Transparent. We have a culture of amazing, growth-minded people whose values include using good judgment and solving for the customer. These traits will help you develop expert power because you'll be remarkable in your industry, but also humble enough to adapt and listen to those who have expert power in areas that you don't.</p> \n<h3>8. Be solution-oriented.</h3> \n<p>Something I'm always trying to develop as an aspiring business leader is to be solution-oriented. When you come to your manager with a problem, have a few solutions ready as well. This will help you develop your expert power because you'll get immediate feedback from your manager on your solutions. They'll be able to tell you from their experience if those solutions will work, and then you'll level up your expertise with every problem you face.</p> \n<p>Expert power is something that is hugely important for aspiring business leaders because it's this power that gives you the ability to lead with confidence and humility. With those two things, you'll be successful in whatever industry you choose.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=5f7685cd-6442-4846-afea-a28dcbad007c&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New Call-to-action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5f7685cd-6442-4846-afea-a28dcbad007c.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fexpert-power&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 21 Sep 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/4e634041-e1ce-4a85-8e65-aea12fc10b84.png","linkMd5":"afea222b43ffc0de76539d6d706a08d9","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn35@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-42-278_a76d18c90cdcfa92.webp","destWidth":660,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":7430,"destBytes":10618,"author":"Rebecca Riserbato","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/4e634041-e1ce-4a85-8e65-aea12fc10b84.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn35@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-42-278_a76d18c90cdcfa92.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/What%20is%20Expert%20Power%20and%20How%20Can%20You%20Develop%20It%3F.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn44@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-46-010_e007dfbf744fb9d9.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5f7685cd-6442-4846-afea-a28dcbad007c.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn38@2020_4/2021/09/27/16-55-47-520_15a22acbc5258093.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fexpert-power&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn71@2020_6/2021/09/27/16-55-48-102_b04d2123618499cf.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1632761741209},{"createdTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","updatedTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","title":"12 Gantt Chart Examples You'll Want to Copy","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/gantt-chart-example","description":"<p>Gantt charts. Love ‘em, hate ‘em, or can’t live without ‘em, they’re a reality of a marketer’s life. But how do you make yours stand out from the rest?</p>  \n<p>I’ve gathered some of the best examples around, along with some free templates to get you started. Dive in below and find your favorite. But first ...</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=d3746ff9-0945-4bc2-971b-694a113daa42&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"→ Download Now: Free Gantt Chart Template\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/d3746ff9-0945-4bc2-971b-694a113daa42.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p></p> \n<p>The elements within a Gantt chart can be grouped into four categories: resources, milestones, tasks, and dependencies.</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Resources:</strong> Project managers must have insight into what resources are needed for tasks outlined in a Gantt chart, in order for each to be completed on time.</li> \n <li><strong>Milestones:</strong> Along your timeline, there will likely be milestones, both small and large, that must be hit in order to keep your project on track. A milestone for a blog launch might be, “<em>Blog post draft due on 5/30.</em>”</li> \n <li><strong>Tasks:</strong> There are specific things that need to be completed along the way of your project. In our blog post example, a task might be, <em>“Edit blog post.</em>”</li> \n <li><strong>Dependencies:</strong> Tasks on your Gantt chart will be related to each other, for example, the editor won’t be able to complete her task of editing the blog post until the writer has met their milestone and submitted their draft on 5/30. These are dependencies and should be noted in your chart.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>Benefits of Using a Gantt Chart</h3> \n<p>The main goal of a Gantt chart is to track the timeline and completion of a project. It’s beneficial for project managers who need to keep team momentum on campaigns with many moving parts, like product launches or marketing events. Here are some additional benefits of using Gantt charts:&nbsp;</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Visual tracking gives an overarching view of projects and their timelines, helping DRIs understand progress and assign responsibility accordingly.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>Clear project timelines aid with resource planning, as you'll know which tasks require which tools and exactly when DRIs will need those tools.&nbsp;&nbsp;</li> \n <li>Visual understanding of which project elements rely on each other for completion so PMs can inform responsible individuals of high-priority tasks.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>Increased transparency, as all involved parties are aware of expectations and how individual progress impacts team progress.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>You can create Gantt charts in Excel, PowerPoint, Google Sheets, and more, and this tracking method can be used in a variety of industries, from marketing to construction, and even design.</p> \n<p>So, what does that look like? Let’s dive in with some beautiful Gantt chart examples, below. Prepare to geek out.</p> \n<h2>Gantt Chart Examples</h2> \n<h3>1. Gantt Chart in Excel</h3> \n<p>Creating Gantt charts in Excel is a common practice and one you’ll likely come across in your work. Excel doesn’t have a predefined Gantt chart, but the “Stacked Bar” feature is your friend, once more, allowing you to show project progression. Here’s an example of an Excel Gantt chart. <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/business-templates/gantt-chart?_ga=2.166289723.446548473.1631200910-262426828.1631200910\">Download it free, here</a>. <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/business-templates/gantt-chart?hubs_post-cta=image&amp;_ga=2.234565596.356920229.1631199556-177774985.1631199556\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/excel-gantt-chart-template.jpg?width=1615&amp;name=excel-gantt-chart-template.jpg\" alt=\"gantt chart excel template\" width=\"1615\" style=\"width: 1615px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></a></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\">&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/business-templates/gantt-chart?_ga=2.131376650.446548473.1631200910-262426828.1631200910\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>And here’s a helpful “how-to” video for the excel-challenged among us &lt;raises hand&gt;.</p> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-wrapper hs-responsive-embed\" style=\"float: none; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 100%; height: auto; position: relative; overflow: hidden; padding: 0; max-width: 560px; max-height: 315px; min-width: 256px; margin: 0px auto;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-inner-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.25%; margin: 0;\">\n  <iframe class=\"hs-responsive-embed-iframe\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/GskOcaOyW6U\" width=\"560\" height=\"315\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n </div> \n</div> \n<h3>2. Gantt Chart in PowerPoint</h3> \n<p>Want to include a Gantt chart in your next PowerPoint Presentation? Use this PowerPoint example as your guide. PowerPoint doesn’t have a built-in Gantt feature, but you can build and edit a chart inside of the platform using their “Stacked Bar” feature.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/powerpoint-gantt-chart-example.jpg?width=808&amp;name=powerpoint-gantt-chart-example.jpg\" alt=\"gantt chart powerpoint template example\" width=\"808\" style=\"width: 808px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"><span style=\"font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://www.officetimeline.com/make-gantt-chart/powerpoint\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></span></p> \n<h3>How to Make a Gantt Chart in PowerPoint</h3> \n<p>When using the above template to make a Gantt chart in PowerPoint, consider these pro tips:&nbsp;</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Leverage the task bars to your advantage and adjust their length in accordance with your plan. This template is also flexible, so you can shorten or increase the length of tasks if things come up during your project execution process.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>Make unique color-codes for each specific task so you can place a corresponding milestone image when completed so you can monitor your progress and immediately understand what color means what.&nbsp;</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>3. Gantt Chart in Word</h3> \n<p>What’s that? You’re not familiar with Microsoft’s “Stacked Bar” feature yet? Well, if you’re getting friendly with Gantt charts, you’ll be using this go-to feature quite a bit.</p> \n<p>If you’re creating a Gantt chart in Microsoft Word, you’ll stack bars once more. But if you’ll be updating and tweaking your Gantt chart regularly, Excel or PowerPoint may give you better flexibility. <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/ms-word-gantt-chart-example.jpg?width=802&amp;name=ms-word-gantt-chart-example.jpg\" alt=\"gantt chart microsoft word template\" width=\"802\" style=\"width: 802px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 13px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"http://templatelab.com/gantt-chart-templates/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<h4>How to Make a Gantt Chart in Word</h4> \n<p>When using the template above, leverage the stackable bars feature to create an interactive Gantt chart to clearly demonstrate task progress and monitor your accomplishments.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>In addition, create a daily check-ins schedule on your chart so you can move the “Today” line forward as each day goes on, helping you stay on track and understand what’s to come.</p> \n<h3>4. Gantt Chart in Google Sheets</h3> \n<p>If Google Sheets is where you spend most of your time, this is the Gantt chart for you. G-Sheets makes it easy to build customizable Gantt charts you can edit as needed -- all using a few simple formulas.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/google-sheet-gantt-chart-example.jpg?width=845&amp;name=google-sheet-gantt-chart-example.jpg\" alt=\"gantt chart google sheets template\" width=\"845\" style=\"width: 845px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"><span style=\"font-size: 13px; font-style: italic;\"><a href=\"https://www.lifewire.com/create-gantt-chart-in-google-sheets-4160488\">Image Source</a></span></p> \n<h4>How to Make a Gantt Chart in Google Sheets</h4> \n<p>If you’re creating a Gantt chart in Google Sheets, use the above template and circulation table for automated chart creation. Simply input the information specific to your business, and the chart will be created automatically.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>You have less creative freedom with this chart, but it is great for those hesitant to create a chart from scratch.</p> \n<h3>5. Gantt Chart in Google Docs</h3> \n<p>Want a Gantt Chart you can share and collaborate on with colleagues? Consider creating your chart in a Google Document. Save it to your Google Drive and share as normal. Google offers “Stacked chart” options in their “Chart Editor,” so getting started is a breeze.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/google-doc-gantt-chart-example.jpg?width=1073&amp;name=google-doc-gantt-chart-example.jpg\" alt=\"gantt chart google docs template\" width=\"1073\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"><span style=\"font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://www.smartsheet.com/free-google-docs-templates-google-timeline-templates\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></span></p> \n<h4>How to Make a Gantt Chart in Google Docs</h4> \n<p>In Google Docs, use the timeline template documents to your advantage and give yourself an overview of your project progress. It’ll help with visualization, staying on track, and allowing you to see how you’re progressing over time so you can share information with relevant stakeholders, internal and external.</p> \n<h3>6. Gantt Chart for Editorial Calendar</h3> \n<p>Take your editorial calendar up a notch with a Gantt chart. Include publication dates as your milestones, add subgroups for each phase of content creation, and add tasks to your chart.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/editorial-calendar-gantt-chart-example.jpg?width=667&amp;name=editorial-calendar-gantt-chart-example.jpg\" alt=\"gantt chart example: editorial calendar\" width=\"667\" style=\"width: 667px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"><span style=\"font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://www.teamgantt.com/blog/how-we-manage-our-editorial-calendar-with-teamgantt\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></span></p> \n<h3>7. Gantt Chart for Project Management</h3> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">Project management is one of the most common verticals relying on Gantt charts. These charts help project managers identify the tasks involved in each project, create a timeline for each task, and assign dates, tools, and progress updates for each of the tasks within the project.<br><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/gantt-chart-for-project-management-example.jpg?width=848&amp;name=gantt-chart-for-project-management-example.jpg\" alt=\"gantt chart example: project management\" width=\"848\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"><span style=\"font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://www.proofhub.com/articles/benefits-of-gantt-charts\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></span></p> \n<h3>8. Gantt Chart for Marketing Campaign</h3> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">There are many tools available that help marketers create Gantt charts especially for marketing campaigns. This example, from GanttPro offers ready-made campaign templates with predefined tasks, subtasks, and milestones. <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/gantt-chart-for-marketing-campaigns.jpg?width=611&amp;name=gantt-chart-for-marketing-campaigns.jpg\" alt=\"gantt chart example: marketing campaign gantt chart\" width=\"611\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"><span style=\"font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://ganttpro.com/free-marketing-campaign-template/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></span></p> \n<h3>9. Gantt Chart for Design Projects</h3> \n<p>Designers, you can use Gantt charts, too. Plan design launches, track brainstorming, and share draft progress with a carefully organized chart, like the example below. <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/gantt-chart-example-for-designers.jpg?width=1303&amp;name=gantt-chart-example-for-designers.jpg\" alt=\"gantt chart example: design projects\" width=\"1303\" style=\"width: 1303px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://www.smartdraw.com/gantt-chart/examples/design-project-chart/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<h3>10. Gantt Chart for Product Launch</h3> \n<p>Product launches have many moving parts. Keep track of research, budgets, team roles, and even risk assessment in a customizable Gantt chart like this one. You can even set dependencies and assign tasks to certain people.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/product-launch-gantt-chart-example.jpg?width=2032&amp;name=product-launch-gantt-chart-example.jpg\" alt=\"gantt chart example: product launch\" width=\"2032\" style=\"width: 2032px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://ganttpro.com/free-new-product-launch-plan-template/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></span></p> \n<h3>11. Gantt Chart for Social Media Campaign</h3> \n<p>When you’re mapping a social media marketing campaign using a Gantt chart, make sure to include the tools you’ll need, the content you’ll be sharing, and the assets used on each channel. We loved this example, from Fabrik.&nbsp;<img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/social-media-campaign-gantt-chart-example.jpg?width=646&amp;name=social-media-campaign-gantt-chart-example.jpg\" alt=\"gantt chart example: social media campaign\" width=\"646\" style=\"width: 646px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"http://fabrikbrands.com/create-digital-marketing-strategy-grows-leads-revenue/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<h3>12. Gantt Chart for Event Marketing</h3> \n<p>From outreach prior to the event to “Thank you” emails once it’s over, planning an event requires high levels of organization. Use a Gantt chart like this one to keep track of your strategy, team progress, and key actions before, during, and after your event.<br><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/event-marketing-gantt-chart-example.jpg?width=1241&amp;name=event-marketing-gantt-chart-example.jpg\" alt=\"gantt chart example: event marketing\" width=\"1241\" style=\"width: 1241px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 13px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://www.smartsheet.com/marketing-timeline-tips-and-free-templates\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>When you're ready to begin creating your own Gantt chart, refer to the high-quality examples on this list and download our free Excel template to get started.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=ee956e70-8ced-4b49-a47b-2779505db687&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New Call-to-action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/ee956e70-8ced-4b49-a47b-2779505db687.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fgantt-chart-example&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\"
