\">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 23 Sep 2021 17:45:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/d3746ff9-0945-4bc2-971b-694a113daa42.png","linkMd5":"c739d7f65e104b9b9803a85e34bc44e4","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn95@2020_4/2021/09/27/16-55-42-314_afd4cd68fa0b5763.webp","destWidth":418,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":4642,"destBytes":6722,"author":"Meg Prater","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/d3746ff9-0945-4bc2-971b-694a113daa42.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn95@2020_4/2021/09/27/16-55-42-314_afd4cd68fa0b5763.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/excel-gantt-chart-template.jpg?width=1615&name=excel-gantt-chart-template.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn1@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-45-395_3aaa344186f724bd.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/powerpoint-gantt-chart-example.jpg?width=808&name=powerpoint-gantt-chart-example.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn10@2020_4/2021/09/27/16-55-44-477_eea9e873488273b1.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/ms-word-gantt-chart-example.jpg?width=802&name=ms-word-gantt-chart-example.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn84@2020_6/2021/09/27/16-55-46-585_9a77ec0caef913f1.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/google-sheet-gantt-chart-example.jpg?width=845&name=google-sheet-gantt-chart-example.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn17@2020_4/2021/09/27/16-55-45-152_e5d1bd224392161a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/google-doc-gantt-chart-example.jpg?width=1073&name=google-doc-gantt-chart-example.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn88@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-46-109_ce96e7b78b8d9c5e.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/editorial-calendar-gantt-chart-example.jpg?width=667&name=editorial-calendar-gantt-chart-example.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn35@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-45-876_9b8849a962023d56.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/gantt-chart-for-project-management-example.jpg?width=848&name=gantt-chart-for-project-management-example.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn98@2020_6/2021/09/27/16-55-47-764_35027cf6e61d8189.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/gantt-chart-for-marketing-campaigns.jpg?width=611&name=gantt-chart-for-marketing-campaigns.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn39@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-47-083_0800820df980e2fc.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/gantt-chart-example-for-designers.jpg?width=1303&name=gantt-chart-example-for-designers.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn59@2020_2/2021/09/27/16-55-47-598_02adb8098564c484.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/product-launch-gantt-chart-example.jpg?width=2032&name=product-launch-gantt-chart-example.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn100@2020_2/2021/09/27/16-55-45-700_46160a7006e7d40f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/social-media-campaign-gantt-chart-example.jpg?width=646&name=social-media-campaign-gantt-chart-example.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn2@2020_6/2021/09/27/16-55-44-774_03af5988e879c815.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/event-marketing-gantt-chart-example.jpg?width=1241&name=event-marketing-gantt-chart-example.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn33@2020_4/2021/09/27/16-55-45-548_6a9ef6d80a91b599.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/ee956e70-8ced-4b49-a47b-2779505db687.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn85@2020_6/2021/09/27/16-55-44-616_8a691d15f45f6cf8.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fgantt-chart-example&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn28@2020_5/2021/09/27/16-55-47-879_7fc8027de9186f65.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1632761741256},{"createdTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","updatedTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","title":"6 Analytical Skills Marketers Need and How to Improve Them","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/analytical-skills","description":"<p>If you've ever tried to solve a Rubix Cube, you've put your analytical skills to the test. Making the colors match up requires problem-solving, logical reasoning, and pattern recognition.</p> \n<p>While the majority of marketers will never make it to the next speedcubing competition, the skills you learn with puzzles like this are essential to a successful marketing career.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=4e634041-e1ce-4a85-8e65-aea12fc10b84&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"→ Click here to download leadership lessons from HubSpot founder, Dharmesh  Shah [Free Guide].\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/4e634041-e1ce-4a85-8e65-aea12fc10b84.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p>In today's workforce, nearly <a href=\"https://www.pewresearch.org/social-trends/2020/01/30/employment-is-rising-most-rapidly-in-jobs-most-in-need-of-social-fundamental-and-analytical-skills/\"><span>one in four workers</span></a> have a job in which analytical skills are considered the most important factor. Companies want to hire for these skills because it shows a candidate's ability to think logically and use data to inform decision-making. In fact, Indeed found the <a href=\"https://www.indeed.com/career-advice/finding-a-job/in-demand-skills\"><span>most in-demand skills</span></a> for employers — and several analytical skills top the list.</p> \n<p>That's why it's important to know how analytical skills apply to your career and what you can do to develop these skills over time.</p> \n<p>As a marketer, being able to understand problems and provide solutions is essential to a long, successful career. It means you can take a critical lens to the details of a problem to fully understand it. This helps you notice trends, understand the steps needed to take action, and offer novel solutions. But that doesn't mean you have to throw creativity out the door. Using analytical skills to problem solve can look like a structured, methodical approach or a more creative one.</p> \n<p>We'll explore the various types of analytical skills later on, but first, let's look at how analytical skills differ from critical thinking skills.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/RrP4jhDZJdEEZlbR2WO1rM6q8xW_ont2GKkr0EJqI-yFJFxcTTQg8pm0XglaGpVNcFKlRbdKerzVJZFfCHIbms1QhJsdbZPadCfaU1584fU4OJb2kXUzJnPVTxCjQEAG4UGct6eI=s0\" width=\"624\" height=\"413\" alt=\"5 Types of Analytical Skills\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://www.thebalancecareers.com/analytical-skills-list-2063729\"><span>Image Source</span></a></p> \n<h3>Analytical Skills vs. Critical Thinking</h3> \n<p>A person who uses logic to find patterns, brainstorm, analyze data, and make decisions based on that information has analytical skills. One of the skills required to do that is critical thinking.</p> \n<p>In other words, critical thinking is just one of many skills you need to be an analytical thinker.</p> \n<p>You probably use critical thinking more often than you imagine, like when you:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Question whether a piece of information is a fact or an opinion.</li> \n <li>Break problems down to understand the reasoning behind them.</li> \n <li>Draw conclusions from data, rather than a gut feeling.</li> \n <li>Make intentional, rational, and goal-oriented decisions.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Marketers who have strong critical thinking skills make reasonable, logical judgments and think through every decision. They provide facts and logical arguments to back their choices, which leads to smart decisions and improves company success.</p> \n<p>While each role has its own analytical skill requirements, there are several that will benefit any marketer throughout their career.</p> \n<h2>Example of Analytical Skills</h2> \n<p>If you're looking for a marketing role that leans towards analytics, such as a market research analyst position, it's best to develop analytical skills specific to that position and your desired industry. Analytical skills are soft skills, so you'll also want to develop hard role-specific <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/technical-skills\"><span>technical skills</span></a>.</p> \n<p>For an analyst, that means mastering technical skills like Google Analytics and statistical software, while also having analytical skills such as creating data collection methods and presenting findings to senior leadership.</p> \n<p>But across the board, all marketers can benefit from developing these in-demand analytical skills.</p> \n<h3>1. Critical Thinking</h3> \n<p>Any position across all levels of a company can benefit from critical thinking skills. It's the ability to question an idea or examine why a problem exists. This can lead you to tackle issues others thought impossible and understand whether resolving a problem is worth the time, money, and effort. Critical thinking can take many forms in marketing, such as:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Decision-making</li> \n <li>Content and brand auditing</li> \n <li>Prioritization</li> \n <li>Troubleshooting</li> \n <li>Case analysis</li> \n <li>Correlation</li> \n <li>Data interpretation</li> \n <li>Judgment</li> \n <li>Market research analysis</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>2. Data Analysis</h3> \n<p>Neil Hoyne, Chief Measurement Strategist at Google, once said, \"The companies that are going to win are the ones who are using data, not guessing.\"</p> \n<p>Interpreting data is more than collecting and reading information — it's making sense of what's before you by connecting patterns and recognizing trends. Strong data analysis skills allow you to pull insights from a large volume of data, which you can share with key decision-makers. This skill can show up in marketing role requirements in a few common ways.</p> \n<ul> \n <li>ROI analysis</li> \n <li>SWOT analysis</li> \n <li>Data visualization</li> \n <li>Pattern recognition</li> \n <li>Process analysis</li> \n <li>Industry and market research</li> \n <li>Presentation skills</li> \n <li>Measuring customer satisfaction</li> \n <li>Marketing analytics</li> \n <li>Customer segmentation strategies</li> \n <li>Predictive analysis</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>3. Creative Thinking</h3> \n<p>I once had a manager who was known for saying, \"The first answer isn't the answer.\" She knew the role creativity played in problem-solving and pushed our team to view a possible solution from all angles. Marketers with this analytical skill work to find out-of-the-box solutions and patterns that others brush past. And if you need any more convincing, 'creativity' ranks on Indeed’s top 20 list of most in-demand skills for today's workforce. At work, creative skills involve:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Brainstorming</li> \n <li>Collaboration</li> \n <li>Adaptability</li> \n <li>Budgeting</li> \n <li>Search engine optimization (SEO)</li> \n <li>Strategic planning</li> \n <li>Organizational restructuring</li> \n <li>Predictive modeling</li> \n <li>Campaign development</li> \n <li>Branding</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>4. Communication</h3> \n<p>Employers consistently rank communication as a must-have skill — and for good reason. Being able to explain your idea for a project or give feedback is essential as a marketing professional.</p> \n<p>Communicating clearly helps you keep everyone on the same page when rolling out a campaign or diffuse a problem with a deadline when it (inevitably) arises. Strong communication skills needed in marketing include:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Written and verbal communication</li> \n <li>Body language</li> \n <li>Interpersonal skills</li> \n <li>Active listening</li> \n <li>Conducting presentations</li> \n <li>Reporting</li> \n <li>Confidence and clarity of expression</li> \n <li>Sharing feedback</li> \n <li>Responsiveness</li> \n <li>Delegating responsibilities</li> \n <li>Respect and empathy</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>5. Problem-solving</h3> \n<p>Deciding how to respond to a harsh customer comment on social media. Distributing an advertising budget. Prioritizing which roles to hire for as a growing team.</p> \n<p>All of these situations require analytical problem-solving skills, and all will pop up through a marketing career. Here are the problem-solving skills every marketer can benefit from developing:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Research</li> \n <li>Data collection</li> \n <li>Prioritization</li> \n <li>Checking for accuracy</li> \n <li>Risk-taking</li> \n <li>Attention to detail</li> \n <li>Dependability</li> \n <li>Team-building</li> \n <li>Logic and reasoning</li> \n <li>Organization</li> \n <li>Crisis management</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>6. Collaboration</h3> \n<p>Good collaboration skills can improve your working relationships, help you accomplish tasks on time, and reach your short- and long-term goals.</p> \n<p>And nearly every marketing team has to collaborate with sales, product, business development, and creative teams to get anything done, knowing how to create synergy with your colleagues will make work smoother and more enjoyable.</p> \n<p>The most common collaboration skills for marketers today are:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Persuasion</li> \n <li>Adaptability</li> \n <li>Time management</li> \n <li>Responsiveness</li> \n <li>Negotiation</li> \n <li>Giving and receiving feedback</li> \n <li>Emotional intelligence</li> \n <li>Open-mindedness</li> \n <li>Process improvement</li> \n <li>Adapting to change</li> \n <li>Networking</li> \n</ul> \n<h2>How to Improve Analytical Skills</h2> \n<p>Developing analytical skills takes time and effort. Unlike technical skills that have a structured approach to follow, analytical skills are more difficult to define and develop. There's a process to learn how to use Google Analytics for SEO, but the steps to become an effective communicator are more fuzzy and undefined.</p> \n<p>Fortunately, analytical skills can be honed. Here how you can go about boosting your skills and contributing to your company's productivity and success.</p> \n<h3>Take courses, certifications, or on the job training.</h3> \n<p>Infinite resources exist both in-person and online that can help you improve your analytical skills. Universities and online companies like <a href=\"https://www.coursera.org/\"><span>Coursera</span></a> offer online schooling, <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/\"><span>HubSpot Academy</span></a> offers free certification courses, and many companies provide stipends for continuing education.</p> \n<p>Start by identifying which skills you want to improve and do research to find the resources that are right for your skill set and budget.</p> \n<h3>Find a mentor.</h3> \n<p>You likely know someone who is an excellent negotiator or always crafts the perfect email. Noticing how these people approach a situation and problem solve can help you hone your skills. Take notes, save examples, and apply their process to your work.</p> \n<p>To take it a step further, ask them to chat over coffee or a phone call to discuss how they developed their skill. They can likely point you in the right direction or provide guidance on what you need to do to excel at the skill.</p> \n<h3>Try practice problems.</h3> \n<p>Role-playing is incredibly effective when working to improve analytical skills. Instead of simply reading a case study about an innovative digital media campaign, find a tool to help you develop your brainstorming skills.</p> \n<p>Depending on the skill, you can find a practice book or an online resource to walk you through various mental models and scenarios. Work on an idea, and then present it to a trusted colleague or mentor to get feedback.</p> \n<h3>Play games to improve your analytical skills.</h3> \n<p>Spending hours on your phone playing Sudoku has more benefits than the personal satisfaction of beating your top score. Games that test your mental agility and memorization can improve your ability to think logically and challenge norms. While game trends are constantly changing, there are several classics that have withstood the test of time.</p> \n<ol> \n <li>Sudoku</li> \n <li>Jigsaw puzzles</li> \n <li>Board games (i.e. Scrabble, Settlers of Catan, Splendor, Pictionary, and Bananagrams)</li> \n <li>Computer or mobile games (i.e. Lumosity, Elevate, and Peak)</li> \n <li>Chess</li> \n <li>Crossword puzzles</li> \n</ol> \n<h2>Analytical Skills for Your Resume</h2> \n<p>Once you gain or improve your analytical skills, make sure to update your resume to reflect those strengths. Your resume should include a list of 10 to 20 skills, with a mix of both hard and soft skills. Note at least five to 10 analytical skills so potential employers know you have the knowledge to get your job done.</p> \n<p>When choosing which skills to highlight, look to the job requirements section. A role may involve managing the company's social media accounts, but this typically includes collaborating with multiple teams to get the content and analytics you need to do that successfully. Showcasing a blend of technical and analytical skills is what makes you a competitive candidate.</p> \n<p>As your career develops, you'll likely need to keep your analytical skills sharp. Be proactive by practicing and paying attention to people who have the skills you want to acquire, and you'll be on your way to solving complex problems with ease.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=5f7685cd-6442-4846-afea-a28dcbad007c&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New Call-to-action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5f7685cd-6442-4846-afea-a28dcbad007c.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fanalytical-skills&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 16 Sep 2021 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/4e634041-e1ce-4a85-8e65-aea12fc10b84.png","linkMd5":"abcdc5f6ad85e163ba78cf7198fb7d6a","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn35@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-42-278_a76d18c90cdcfa92.webp","destWidth":660,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":7430,"destBytes":10618,"author":"Katrina Kirsch","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/4e634041-e1ce-4a85-8e65-aea12fc10b84.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn35@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-42-278_a76d18c90cdcfa92.webp","https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/RrP4jhDZJdEEZlbR2WO1rM6q8xW_ont2GKkr0EJqI-yFJFxcTTQg8pm0XglaGpVNcFKlRbdKerzVJZFfCHIbms1QhJsdbZPadCfaU1584fU4OJb2kXUzJnPVTxCjQEAG4UGct6eI=s0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn60@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-46-537_9dd2031b6b8033f0.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5f7685cd-6442-4846-afea-a28dcbad007c.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn38@2020_4/2021/09/27/16-55-47-520_15a22acbc5258093.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fanalytical-skills&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn51@2020_6/2021/09/27/16-55-45-914_16ff3a56c14bd7f8.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1632761741252},{"createdTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","updatedTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","title":"The Death of the Third-Party Cookie: What Marketers Need to Know About Google's 2022 Phase-Out","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/third-party-cookie-phase-out","description":"<p>What do marketers and <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ye8mB6VsUHw\">Sesame Street</a><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ye8mB6VsUHw\"> monsters</a> have in common? They LOVE cookies.</p>  \n<p>For years, brands have been using them to track <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/customers/what-is-cookie-tracking\">website visitors</a>, improve the user experience, and collect data that helps us target ads to the right audiences. We also use them to learn about what our visitors are checking out online when they aren't on our websites.</p> \n<p>But the way we use cookies and Google ad-tracking tools&nbsp;could change dramatically with Google's efforts to phase phase out the third-party cookie on <a href=\"https://blog.chromium.org/2020/01/building-more-private-web-path-towards.html\">Chrome browsers by 2022</a>.</p> \n<p>The third-party phase-out was initially announced in February 2020, but Google accelerated buzz around it this month when <a href=\"https://blog.google/products/ads-commerce/a-more-privacy-first-web/\">they announced</a> that they won't be building \"alternate identifiers to track individuals as they browse across the web, nor will we use them in our products.\"</p> \n<p>\"We realize this means other providers may offer a level of user identity for ad tracking across the web that we will not — like PII graphs based on people’s email addresses,\" <a href=\"https://blog.google/products/ads-commerce/a-more-privacy-first-web/\">a Google post wrote</a>.</p> \n<p>\"We don’t believe these solutions will meet rising consumer expectations for privacy, nor will they stand up to rapidly evolving regulatory restrictions, and therefore aren’t a sustainable long term investment. Instead, our web products will be powered by<span>&nbsp;</span><a href=\"https://github.com/google/ads-privacy/blob/master/proposals/FLoC/FLOC-Whitepaper-Google.pdf\">privacy-preserving APIs</a><span>&nbsp;</span>which prevent individual tracking while still delivering results for advertisers and publishers,\" says Google.</p> \n<h2><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=b0f73a5e-16e4-41fd-9511-8564efc560a7&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"Download Now: State of Marketing in 2021 Report\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b0f73a5e-16e4-41fd-9511-8564efc560a7.png\"></a>How Marketers and Advertisers are Reacting to Google's Phase-Out</h2> \n<p>While <a href=\"https://www.aaaa.org/statement-from-the-4as-and-ana-responding-to-googles-announcement-regarding-third-party-cookies/?cn-reloaded=1\">numerous advertising agencies criticized Google's pivot</a>, companies like <a href=\"https://www.getapp.com/\">GetApp</a> have begun to research potential marketing impact. In a recent survey. GetApp, which provided HubSpot with exclusive data, discovered that:&nbsp;</p> \n<ul> \n <li>41% of marketers believe their biggest challenge will be their inability to track the right data.</li> \n <li>44% of marketers predict a need to increase their spending by 5% to 25% in order to reach the same goals as 2021.</li> \n <li>23% of marketing experts plan on investing in email marketing software due to Google’s new policy.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Below, I'll note a brief history of how the third-party cookie phase-out, and Google's pivots for tracking security, came to be. Then I'll highlight a few things marketers should keep in mind as we get closer to 2022.</p> \n<h2>A Brief History of the Third-Party Cookie Phase-Out</h2> \n<p>While you might be seeing this news for the first time, we've been following it since 2020 and just recently updated this post to reflect Google's most recent statements.</p> \n<p>In February of last year, a Google blog post <a href=\"https://blog.chromium.org/2020/01/building-more-private-web-path-towards.html\">announced the phaseout</a> ang gave initial reasoning for the pivot. Like the statement noted in the intro, Google similarly explained that this move was being done to protect users asking for more privacy.</p> \n<p>\"Users are demanding greater privacy--including transparency, choice, and control over how their data is used--and it’s clear the web ecosystem needs to evolve to meet these increasing demands,\" the post wrote.</p> \n<p>Although Firefox and Safari had already phased out the third-party cookie, <a href=\"https://blog.chromium.org/2020/01/building-more-private-web-path-towards.html\">Google's post</a> said that its changes will happen over the course of two years as the tech company works with advertisers to ensure that this pivot doesn't destroy the online advertising business.</p> \n<p>\"Some browsers have reacted to these concerns by blocking third-party cookies, but we believe this has unintended consequences that can negatively impact both users and the web ecosystem,\" the <a href=\"https://blog.chromium.org/2020/01/building-more-private-web-path-towards.html\">blog post notes</a>. \"By undermining the business model of many ad-supported websites, blunt approaches to cookies encourage the use of opaque techniques such as fingerprinting (an invasive workaround to replace cookies), which can actually reduce user privacy and control. We believe that we as a community can, and must, do better.\"</p> \n<p>Although Chrome isn't the first browser to phase out the third-party cookie, it's the biggest. In late 2019, Google Chrome made up <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/268299/most-popular-internet-browsers/\">more than 56% of the web browser market</a>. Chrome also accounts for <a href=\"https://www.techadvisor.co.uk/test-centre/software/best-web-browsers-3635255/\">more than half of all global web traffic</a>.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/The%20Death%20of%20the%20Third%20Party%20Cookie%20What%20Marketers%20Need%20to%20Know-1.png\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"Most used website browsers.\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><em>Source: </em><a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/268299/most-popular-internet-browsers/\">Statista</a></p> \n<p>Meanwhile, Safari and Firefox, which <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/in-defense-of-tracking-cookies\">have blocked third-party cookies since 2013</a>, come in a distant second and third place, respectively.</p> \n<p>Because Chrome, Safari, and Firefox will all no longer support this type of data tracking by 2022, publications like Digiday are calling Google's phase-out the <a href=\"https://digiday.com/media/publishers-planning-end-third-party-cookie/\">\"death of the third-party cookie.\"</a></p> \n<h2>What happens next?</h2> \n<p>As with any major shift involving privacy, data, and advertising, business experts and publications have been frantically buzzing about how the phase out and Google's rejection of ad-tracking will change the way we do business online.</p> \n<p>But, do we really need to panic?</p> \n<p>The truth is, Google Chrome's privacy efforts could heavily impact some areas of the marketing and advertising space, while other tactics will still stay pretty much the same.</p> \n<p>However, if you're an advertiser or a marketer who's thrived on third-party data or individual data for pinpointed online audience targeting strategies, you might be worried about how you'll navigate this pivot.</p> \n<p>Although some big changes might be underway, new alternatives are also emerging. To help you prepare for a world without third-party cookies, here are four things you should keep in mind about the latest cookie phase-out.</p> \n<h2>5 Things to Know About Google's Cookie Phase-Out and Privacy Pivots</h2> \n<h3>1. Google isn't banning all cookies.</h3> \n<p>If you're thinking that all your cookie-fueled marketing strategies will soon be rendered obsolete, take a breath.</p> \n<p>So far, Google says it's only planning to phase out the third-party cookie on its browsers. However, first-party cookies that track basic data about your own website's visitors are still safe.</p> \n<p>In fact, in Google's 2021 announcement, the tech giant called first-party relationships \"<a href=\"https://blog.google/products/ads-commerce/a-more-privacy-first-web/\">vital</a>.\" So, ultimately, any first-party data you gain from your website's visitors on all browsers will still remain in-tact.</p> \n<p>Still not sure about the difference between first-party and third-party cookies? Here's a quick breakdown.</p> \n<h4>First-Party Cookies</h4> \n<p>A first-party cookie is<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/customers/what-is-cookie-tracking\"> a code that gets generated and stored on your website visitor's computer</a> by default when they visit your site. This cookie is often used for user experience as it is responsible for remembering passwords, basic data about the visitor, and other preferences.</p> \n<p>With a first-party cookie, you can learn about what a user did while visiting your website, see how often they visit it, and gain other basic analytics that can help you develop or automate an effective marketing strategy around them. However, you can't see data related to your visitor's behavior on other websites that aren't affiliated with your domain.</p> \n<p>Ever wonder how Amazon always remembers <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/customers/what-is-cookie-tracking\">your login information, the language you speak, the items in your cart</a>, and other key things that make your user experience so smooth? This is because Amazon uses first-party cookies to remember these basic details.</p> \n<p>On the other hand, if you're a marketer running a website on a CMS, you'll have access to analytics dashboards that track first-party cookie data. For example, you'll usually be able to see basic analytics, such as the number of web sessions on a page, the number of pages people click on during a visit, basic browser types, geographical demographics, or even referring websites where visitors clicked a link to your site's URL. However, this data doesn't inform you of everything your visitors do online.</p> \n<h4>Third-Party Cookies</h4> \n<p>Third-party cookies are tracking codes that are placed on a web visitor's computer after being generated by another website other than your own. When a web visitor visits your site and others, the third-party cookie tracks this information and sends it to the third-party who created the cookie -- which might be an advertiser.</p> \n<p>If you're an advertiser, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/in-defense-of-tracking-cookies\">third-party cookie data</a> allows you to learn about your web visitor's overall online behaviors, such as websites they frequently visit, purchases, and interests that they've shown on various websites. With this detailed data, you can build robust visitor profiles. With all of this data, you can then create a retargeting list that can be used to send ads to your past visitors or people with similar web profiles.</p> \n<p>Want to visualize how third-party cookie data might work? Say you research a particular smart TV on Amazon. Then, you go to another site later in the day and see an ad Amazon advertisement for the same exact product. If you aren't on an Amazon-owned site, it's very possible that this advertisement was triggered by third-party cookie data.</p> \n<p>While first-party cookies are accepted automatically, visitors must be informed that they are accepting a third-party cookie due to the amount of data that companies can retain from them.</p> \n<p>The bottom line? If you're just aiming to track your website's visitors' behaviors, preferences, and basic demographics only while they're on your website, you probably won't be deeply impacted by this change.</p> \n<p>However, if you're a marketer that relies on robust data for online advertising, pop-up ads, or a pinpointed audience-targeting strategy, you'll need to continue to follow the news around this phase-out, and consider alternative first-party strategies, as the phase-out nears.</p> \n<h3>2. Many marketers saw the cookie phase-out coming.</h3> \n<p>While the <a href=\"https://digiday.com/media/publishers-planning-end-third-party-cookie/\">\"death of the third-party cookie\"</a> might seem shocking, it certainly wasn't a surprise.</p> \n<p>Recently, governments around the world have been investigating and cracking down on data privacy issues. <span>For example, in an October 2019 shakeup,&nbsp;</span><a href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2019/10/01/europes-top-court-says-active-consent-is-needed-for-tracking-cookies/?__hstc=45788219.ea89173da3bc307159a4e87e0707993a.1619541388289.1619541388289.1619541388289.1&amp;__hssc=45788219.1.1619541388289&amp;__hsfp=1437041088&amp;_ga=2.117846601.1334902982.1619541387-1894650829.1619541387\">Europe's highest court</a><span> ruled that users in the EU must actively consent to all analytics cookies when they log on to a website. If not, the website can’t drop analytics or web tracking cookies on the user’s browser.</span>&nbsp;</p> \n<p><span>The&nbsp;</span><a href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2019/10/01/europes-top-court-says-active-consent-is-needed-for-tracking-cookies/?__hstc=45788219.ea89173da3bc307159a4e87e0707993a.1619541388289.1619541388289.1619541388289.1&amp;__hssc=45788219.1.1619541388289&amp;__hsfp=1437041088&amp;_ga=2.117846601.1334902982.1619541387-1894650829.1619541387\">GDPR ruling</a><span>&nbsp;means that websites can no longer rely on implicit opt-in (meaning, a website displays a cookie banner but the user continues to browser. Websites must not capture opt-in consent before any analytics or web tracking cookies are placed on a browser.</span></p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/The%20Death%20of%20the%20Third%20Party%20Cookie%20What%20Marketers%20Need%20to%20Know.png?width=600&amp;name=The%20Death%20of%20the%20Third%20Party%20Cookie%20What%20Marketers%20Need%20to%20Know.png\" alt=\"A banner that asks users for permission to use cookies.\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>If your website only catered to local or domestic users outside of the affected countries, you might not have been impacted. However, international websites took a major reporting hit as numbers from Google Analytics -- which relies on cookies -- started to appear inaccurately low.</p> \n<p>For international brands that relied on Google Analytics, this was a scary reminder that data-driven brands are vulnerable to software-related issues. It also showed us how governance and privacy regulations could dramatically impact our strategies.</p> \n<p>Earlier, in August, Google announced it was developing a \"Privacy Sandbox.\" Although Google didn't have a product created when they announced the move, a <a href=\"https://www.blog.google/products/chrome/building-a-more-private-web/\">blog post</a> explained that the tool that could allow marketers to continue to publish and circulate ads to the right audiences without having the same amount of user data.</p> \n<p>\"We’ve started sharing our preliminary ideas for a Privacy Sandbox -- a secure environment for personalization that also protects user privacy,\" wrote Justin Schuh, Director of Chrome Engineering, <a href=\"https://www.blog.google/products/chrome/building-a-more-private-web/\">in the Google blog post</a>. \"Some ideas include new approaches to ensure that ads continue to be relevant for users, but user data shared with websites and advertisers would be minimized by anonymously aggregating user information, and keeping much more user information on-device only. Our goal is to create a set of standards that is more consistent with users’ expectations of privacy.\"</p> \n<p>In a January 2020 <a href=\"https://digiday.com/marketing/wtf-googles-privacy-sandbox/\">interview with Digiday</a>, Amit Kotecha, a marketing director at data management platform provider Permutive, explained the key features of the proposed Sandbox:</p> \n<p>“The most significant item in the Privacy Sandbox is Google’s proposal to move all user data into the [Chrome] browser where it will be stored and processed,” said <a href=\"https://digiday.com/marketing/wtf-googles-privacy-sandbox/\">Kotecha</a>. “This means that data stays on the user’s device and is privacy compliant. This is now table stakes and the gold standard for privacy.”</p> \n<p>Between the Privacy Sandbox and GDPR rulings that impacted data tracking, it's become apparent to marketers that the third-party cookie was at risk of governance or other tech company changeups that could render it obsolete. This was so apparent that <a href=\"https://digiday.com/media/publishers-planning-end-third-party-cookie/\">advertising software firms and publishers</a> were already contemplating alternative solutions before the official news of Google's cookie phase-out broke.</p> \n<p>At this point, data management firms, like Permutive, are looking at creating alternative tools for advertisers that <a href=\"https://digiday.com/media/publishers-planning-end-third-party-cookie/\">more heavily leverage first-party cookies</a> and lump visitor profiles into more anonymous \"segments\" similar to what <a href=\"https://digiday.com/media/publishers-planning-end-third-party-cookie/\">Google's Privacy Sandbox is predicted to do</a>.</p> \n<h3>3. Marketers aren't just concerned about data.</h3> \n<p>While the elimination of third-party cookies on Chrome will be inconvenient to some, marketers are also concerned about Google's reasoning behind the phase-out.</p> \n<p>Without Chrome-based third-party cookie data, you'll still be able to leverage and target Google Ads, which will be powered by Google Chrome's first-party cookies and the <a href=\"https://digiday.com/marketing/wtf-googles-privacy-sandbox/\">Privacy Sandbox tools</a>. However, some ad software and platforms that require third-party data will take a huge hit without support from Chrome.</p> \n<p>\"This move, while good for consumer privacy (in theory) is likely going to hurt most of the third-party ad platforms that utilize these cookies to generate revenue,\" says <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/author/matthew-howells-barby\">Matthew <i>Howells-</i>Barby</a>, HubSpot's Director of Acquisition.</p> \n<p>\"The big question behind all of this for me is what's motivating Google to phase third-party cookies out? Is it to improve privacy for the end-user or is it to gain a further grip on the ad market by forcing the adoption of Chrome's own first-party cookie, which would likely result in many of those dollars being previously spent on third-party platforms to move in Google's bottom line.\"</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/author/matthew-howells-barby\"><i>Howells-</i>Barby</a> isn't the only marketer to voice these concerns. In fact, in a joint statement, the Association of National Advertising and the American Association of Advertising Agencies called the tech giant out for disrupting healthy competition in the advertising space.</p> \n<p>\"Google’s decision to block third-party cookies in Chrome could have major competitive impacts for digital businesses, consumer services, and technological innovation,\" the statement said. \"It would threaten to substantially disrupt much of the infrastructure of today’s Internet without providing any viable alternative, and it may choke off the economic oxygen from advertising that startups and emerging companies need to survive.\"</p> \n<p>Later in the statement, the two advertising groups urged Google to push back the third-party cookie \"moratorium\" until effective and meaningful opportunities were made available to advertisers.</p> \n<h3>4. Google won't stop tracking people entirely.</h3> \n<p>While Google will not invest in tech that tracks people at an individual level, it will still be investing in alternatives. Along with Google's Privacy Sandbox development, the company has already seen successful advertising results from <a href=\"https://blog.google/products/ads-commerce/2021-01-privacy-sandbox/\">FloC</a>, a technology that tracks groups of people rather than individuals.</p> \n<p><span>\"Our&nbsp;</span><a href=\"https://blog.google/products/ads-commerce/2021-01-privacy-sandbox/\">latest tests of FLoC</a><span>&nbsp;show one way to effectively take third-party cookies out of the advertising equation and instead hide individuals within large crowds of people with common interests,\" Google's <a href=\"https://blog.google/products/ads-commerce/a-more-privacy-first-web/\">recent announcement</a> explained. </span></p> \n<p><span>\"Chrome intends to make FLoC-based cohorts available for public testing through origin trials with its next release this month, and we expect to begin testing FLoC-based cohorts with advertisers in Google Ads in Q2. Chrome also will offer the </span><a href=\"https://blog.chromium.org/2021/01/privacy-sandbox-in-2021.html\">first iteration of new user controls</a><span> in April and will expand on these controls in future releases, as more proposals reach the origin trial stage, and they receive more feedback from end users and the industry,\" <a href=\"https://blog.google/products/ads-commerce/a-more-privacy-first-web/\">the post</a> added.</span></p> \n<h3>5. This move still opens the door for innovation in advertising</h3> \n<p>While things look grim for one type of cookie, this might not be a bad thing for skilled and adaptable brands.</p> \n<p>Although this move does cause concern, Google and other browsers have still taken a stand for user privacy. As privacy laws continue to arise, this might be a great opportunity to look at other less-vulnerable advertising alternatives just incase another governance renders one of your marketing tactics or processes as obsolete.</p> \n<p>Why? As a marketer with an innovative mindset, you should always be asking yourself questions like, \"Are we too reliant on this technology?\" or \"What happens if and when our strategy gets regulated?\" Innovative marketers will be able to come up with more clever alternatives and ads that identify with the masses -- aside from just hyper-targeted content or annoying pop-ups.</p> \n<p>Another area that could be innovated is the way we leverage and use data. As noted above, data management platforms <a href=\"https://digiday.com/marketing/wtf-googles-privacy-sandbox/\">are now looking to create alternative tools</a> that help advertisers track data in a way that makes the most out of the third-party cookie. While these options might be different from your third-party cookie solutions or require some new strategizing, they would still allow you to target and learn about relevant audiences without getting intrusive.</p> \n<h2>How to Prepare for Google's Third-Party Phase-Out</h2> \n<p>Don't panic. At this point, marketers, advertisers, and data engineers alike <a href=\"https://digiday.com/marketing/wtf-googles-privacy-sandbox/\">are actively looking for solutions</a> to determine what will happen next. And, because the third-party cookie was already weakened by Safari and Firefox ad blocking, it likely wasn't the strongest advertising tool anymore anyway.</p> \n<p>Right now, the best thing to do as a marketer is to continue to stay up-to-date with news related to third-party cookies and other data privacy moves that could impact your business.</p> \n<p>If your advertising strategies rely on third-party data, start considering alternatives now. As you continue to follow the news related to the phase-out, you should also vet any software or solutions that can help you better transition away from this type of cookie.</p> \n<p>For example, although marketers are wary of Google's move, the tech giant's Privacy Sandbox and could still serve as valuable alternatives for ad targeting. You could also consider strategies or software that can <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/first-party-data\">better help you leverage first-party data</a>.</p> \n<p>Additionally, you could also revitalize older strategies, like <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/contextual-targeting\">contextual advertising</a>. While third-party data allowed you to place ads directly in front of people who matched certain user profiles, contextual advertising allows you to circulate PPC ads on websites that rank for similar keywords as your ad. This way, if you're selling sports apparel, your PPC ad could show up on sports-oriented websites.</p> \n<p>Lastly, to make your brand as safe as possible from future governance or monopoly-related policies, brainstorm even more basic strategies that you can still use to reach your audiences even without cookies, hyper-targeted ads, or mass amounts of data. This will allow you to be less vulnerable to technology, even when you can benefit from the latest tracking software.</p> \n<p><em><strong>Disclaimer: </strong>This blog post is not legal advice for your company to use in complying with EU data privacy laws like the GDPR. Instead, it provides background information to help you better understand the GDPR. This legal information is not the same as legal advice, where an attorney applies the law to your specific circumstances, so we insist that you consult an attorney if you’d like advice on your interpretation of this information or its accuracy.</em></p> \n<p><em>In a nutshell, you may not rely on this as legal advice, or as a recommendation of any particular legal understanding.</em></p> \n<p><em>Editor's Note: This blog post was originally published in February 2020 but was updated to reflect current announcements from Google in September 2021.&nbsp;</em></p> \n<p><em><a /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"state of marketing\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/d976e6fb-0071-4c77-9973-772d11ef72d3.png\"></a></em></p> \n<p><em></em></p>  \n<img Bump)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b0f73a5e-16e4-41fd-9511-8564efc560a7.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn16@2020_2/2021/09/27/16-55-42-284_88b93bfb7be7b212.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/The%20Death%20of%20the%20Third%20Party%20Cookie%20What%20Marketers%20Need%20to%20Know-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn34@2020_5/2021/09/27/16-55-44-961_8a2fbeeaf72af758.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/The%20Death%20of%20the%20Third%20Party%20Cookie%20What%20Marketers%20Need%20to%20Know.png?width=600&name=The%20Death%20of%20the%20Third%20Party%20Cookie%20What%20Marketers%20Need%20to%20Know.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn22@2020_4/2021/09/27/16-55-44-382_c618e7a2a30e2e5b.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/d976e6fb-0071-4c77-9973-772d11ef72d3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn53@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-44-178_ba6ee21c8b9c368e.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fthird-party-cookie-phase-out&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn65@2020_4/2021/09/27/16-55-46-943_c884b2b026cdded0.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1632761741209},{"createdTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","updatedTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","title":"The 70 Best Chrome Extensions for 2021","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-chrome-extensions","description":"<p>Google Chrome browser extensions allow you to increase productivity, reduce distractions, and source content — all in the comfort of your internet browser.</p> \n<p>The best part is that you have plenty of options. The <a href=\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/category/extensions?__hstc=20629287.a51a184b1f4b68b5a109abeccb174b23.1628192355924.1630000442296.1630011805805.80&amp;__hssc=20629287.1.1630011805805&amp;__hsfp=4043529008\">Google Chrome web store</a> offers a variety of different tools that help you become safer, smarter, and more productive with just one click. We’ve curated the best ones here.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=e7730c75-3fdf-41cc-842f-465c8e939da7&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Uncover more leads in less time with HubSpot's Chrome Extension\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/e7730c75-3fdf-41cc-842f-465c8e939da7.png\" align=\"middle\" /></a></p> \n<p>We can't guarantee that these extensions will make puppy YouTube videos less tempting to watch, but we recommend them for busy marketers who want to make their time online more efficient. We've broken them down into different categories if you want to jump ahead:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-chrome-extensions#productivity\">Productivity</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-chrome-extensions#security\">Security</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-chrome-extensions#social-media\">Social Media</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-chrome-extensions#seo\">SEO</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-chrome-extensions#tab\">New Tab</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-chrome-extensions#content-sourcing\">Content Sourcing</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-chrome-extensions#blogging\">Blogging</a></li> \n</ul> \n<p><em>Please note</em>: All of these are free tools, but some of the services that they work with may have paid features or subscriptions.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p>For all of the greatness that the internet affords — <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/lovable-video-marketing-campaigns#sm.00006uybatuk9erxqe91juzya6sra\">cute animal videos</a>, GIFs, and interesting blogs — one of its biggest downsides is how distracting it can be. How many times have you sat down to work and been pulled into a pit of <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/tips-fight-procrastination#sm.00006uybatuk9erxqe91juzya6sra\">procrastination</a>?</p> \n<p>Perhaps you get absorbed in updates on social media, or maybe you click through Wikipedia trying to determine what exactly Gina Rodriguez's first TV role was (it was on <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gina_Rodriguez#Filmography\">Law &amp; Order</a>). No matter where you click online, it's easy to be pulled into a black hole of distraction and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/bad-habits-for-productivity\">low productivity</a>.</p> \n<p>Check out the extensions below to remedy this problem and be your most productive self.</p> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/hubspot-sales/oiiaigjnkhngdbnoookogelabohpglmd?__hstc=20629287.a51a184b1f4b68b5a109abeccb174b23.1628192355924.1630000442296.1630011805805.80&amp;__hssc=20629287.1.1630011805805&amp;__hsfp=4043529008\">HubSpot Sales</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/sales%20tool.png?width=650&amp;name=sales%20tool.png\" alt=\"HubSpot Sales Chrome extension\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<h4>Users: 800K+</h4> \n<p>HubSpot's Sales tool connects your email inbox with your <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/crm\">CRM</a>. Instead of having to navigate back and forth between the two products, this extension allows you to transfer contact information from your email directly into your CRM. This saves employees time in their day-to-day workflow and retains valuable information about customers.</p> \n<p>Another cool feature that HubSpot Sales provides is the tracking and logging of emails. Users can send emails and receive alerts when their message is delivered, opened, and clicked on. The email thread can then be logged continuously into the CRM throughout the entire correspondence.</p> \n<h3>2. <a href=\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/todoist-to-do-list-and-ta/jldhpllghnbhlbpcmnajkpdmadaolakh?hl=en&amp;__hstc=20629287.a51a184b1f4b68b5a109abeccb174b23.1628192355924.1630000442296.1630011805805.80&amp;__hssc=20629287.1.1630011805805&amp;__hsfp=4043529008\">Todoist</a><i><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pv_A75wlrWA\" style=\"font-style: italic;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/todoist-chrome-extension.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=todoist-chrome-extension.jpeg\" alt=\"Todoist Chrome extension\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></a></i><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pv_A75wlrWA\" style=\"font-style: italic;\"></a></h3> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pv_A75wlrWA\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<h4>Users: 700K+</h4> \n<p>Todoist is a project management tool that lets you create highly organized and visually appealing to-do lists across all of your devices. What's neat about the Chrome extension is that you can see your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/organize-to-do-list\">to-do list</a>, or your team's shared lists, and add tasks to it without having to open a separate tab, app, or device.</p> \n<h3>3. <a href=\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/reply-free-email-search-a/amcdijdgmckgkkahhcobikllddfbfidi?__hstc=20629287.a51a184b1f4b68b5a109abeccb174b23.1628192355924.1630000442296.1630011805805.80&amp;__hssc=20629287.1.1630011805805&amp;__hsfp=4043529008\">Reply</a></h3> \n<h4><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/reply-chrome-extension.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=reply-chrome-extension.jpeg\" alt=\"Reply Chrome extension\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\">Users: 10K+</img></h4> \n<p>Reply's Chrome extension helps you research and engage with your potential prospects on LinkedIn. This is a fast and easy way to find and verify anyone’s email address — both one by one or in bulk using LinkedIn Sales Navigator.</p> \n<p>Once you get the contacts, you can sync them to your CRM — including HubSpot — or connect with the prospects right away.</p> \n<h3>4. <a href=\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/stayfocusd/laankejkbhbdhmipfmgcngdelahlfoji?hl=en&amp;__hstc=20629287.a51a184b1f4b68b5a109abeccb174b23.1628192355924.1630000442296.1630011805805.80&amp;__hssc=20629287.1.1630011805805&amp;__hsfp=4043529008\">StayFocusd</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/stayfocusd-chrome-extension.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=stayfocusd-chrome-extension.jpeg\" alt=\"Stayfocusd Chrome extension\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<h4>Users: 600K+</h4> \n<p>StayFocusd lets you budget your time on specific websites so you can eliminate distractions when you need to buckle down and work. It's highly customizable — you could set your time limit to 20 minutes on Twitter and only five minutes on Facebook, for example. It also has neat features like the Require Challenge: Once you set time limits on sites, if you want to go back and change your settings, you have to complete a challenge (think: retyping a piece of text without typos or answering questions).</p> \n<h3>5. <a href=\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/lastpass-free-password-ma/hdokiejnpimakedhajhdlcegeplioahd?hl=en&amp;__hstc=20629287.a51a184b1f4b68b5a109abeccb174b23.1628192355924.1630000442296.1630011805805.80&amp;__hssc=20629287.1.1630011805805&amp;__hsfp=4043529008\">LastPass</a></h3> \n<h4><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/lastpass-chrome-extension.png?width=650&amp;name=lastpass-chrome-extension.png\" alt=\"Lastpass Chrome extension\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></h4> \n<h4>Users: 10M+</h4> \n<p>LastPass is a password manager that autofills in passwords for all of the accounts you save with this extension. You only have to remember one password: your LastPass password. This saves you time and headaches and increases the security of your personal data.</p> \n<h3>6. <a href=\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/add-to-trello/engmocckoohpopiacajolojeobefbcec?hl=en&amp;__hstc=20629287.a51a184b1f4b68b5a109abeccb174b23.1628192355924.1630000442296.1630011805805.80&amp;__hssc=20629287.1.1630011805805&amp;__hsfp=4043529008\">Add to Trello</a></h3> \n<h4><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/add-to-trello-chrome-extension.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=add-to-trello-chrome-extension.jpeg\" alt=\"Add to Trello Chrome extension\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></h4> \n<h4>Users: 10K+</h4> \n<p>If you use Trello for <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/agency/task-management-tools#sm.00006uybatuk9erxqe91juzya6sra\">project management</a>, team collaboration, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/social-media-calendar-tools\">your content calendar</a>, or just a personal to-do list, this extension lets you easily add links as cards to your Trello boards.</p> \n<h3>7. <a href=\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/extension-manager/gjldcdngmdknpinoemndlidpcabkggco?hl=en\">Extensions Manager</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/extensions-manager-chrome-extension.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=extensions-manager-chrome-extension.jpeg\" alt=\"Extensions Manager Chrome extension\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<h4>Users: 100K+</h4> \n<p>We couldn't give you 50+ different extensions to try out without also suggesting Extensions Manager. Try this tool to organize all of your extensions so they don't take up half of your browser's screen. It shows you what extensions you have operating on Google Chrome and gives you the option to hide some of the icons to keep your browser better organized.</p> \n<h3>8. <a href=\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/toggl-track-productivity/oejgccbfbmkkpaidnkphaiaecficdnfn\">Toggl Track</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/toggl-track-chrome-extension.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=toggl-track-chrome-extension.jpeg\" alt=\"Toggl Track Chrome extension\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<h4>Users: 300K+</h4> \n<p>If you often find yourself spending too much time on one task — to the point that you no longer have time to complete other tasks — consider using the Toggl Track Chrome extension. It initiates a timer right within the comfort of the browser. There’s no need to start a timer on your phone. Simply open up the extension and begin tracking the time you spend on tasks.</p> \n<h3>9. <a href=\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/print-friendly-pdf/ohlencieiipommannpdfcmfdpjjmeolj\">Print Friendly &amp; PDF</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/print-friendly-chrome-extension.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=print-friendly-chrome-extension.jpeg\" alt=\"Print Friendly Chrome extension\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<h4>Users: 700K+</h4> \n<p>If you ever need to save a page in a print-friendly format or as a PDF, you can easily do so with the Print Friendly &amp; PDF Chrome extension. The extension removes ads and other cluttering elements from the web page to turn it into a pleasant reading experience. You can also delete images and change the text size.</p> \n<h3>10. <a href=\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/email-finder-by-snovio/einnffiilpmgldkapbikhkeicohlaapj\">Email Finder</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/email-finder-chrome-extension.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=email-finder-chrome-extension.jpeg\" alt=\"Email Finder Chrome extension\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<h4>Users: 200K+</h4> \n<a></a> \n<p>Whether you’re carrying out sales outreach, seeking guest blogging opportunities, or looking for the owner of a small website, Email Finder will automatically give you a list of verified emails associated with that domain. It’s an absolutely brilliant tool for sales reps and marketers who want to save time when looking for potential contacts at a company.</p> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/https-everywhere/gcbommkclmclpchllfjekcdonpmejbdp?hl=en&amp;__hstc=20629287.a51a184b1f4b68b5a109abeccb174b23.1628192355924.1630000442296.1630011805805.80&amp;__hssc=20629287.1.1630011805805&amp;__hsfp=4043529008\">HTTPS Everywhere</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/https-everywhere-chrome-extension.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=https-everywhere-chrome-extension.jpeg\" alt=\"HTTPS Everywhere Chrome extension\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<h4>Users: 2M+</h4> \n<p>\"HTTPS\" is a website protocol that ensures a site is secure before you visit it. And although you might recognize this tag at the beginning of most websites, it's not quite ubiquitous across the internet — nor does it guarantee that the site you're browsing is 100% secure.</p> \n<p>The Chrome extension, HTTPS Everywhere, rewrites the request you send to any website you visit in Chrome so you can be sure your browser produces the secure version of that site. Browse assured that all your personal information is kept safe and your computer doesn't catch malware while you're online.</p> \n<h3>2. <a href=\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/clickclean/ghgabhipcejejjmhhchfonmamedcbeod?hl=en&amp;__hstc=20629287.a51a184b1f4b68b5a109abeccb174b23.1628192355924.1630000442296.1630011805805.80&amp;__hssc=20629287.1.1630011805805&amp;__hsfp=4043529008\">Click&amp;Clean</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/click-and-clean-chrome-extension.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=click-and-clean-chrome-extension.jpeg\" alt=\"Click and Clean Chrome extension\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<h4>Users: 1M+</h4> \n<p>If you're constantly searching and downloading work material during the day, it can be a tedious task to clear your browser history. You just don't have the time to keep pulling up your history page and manually clearing your cache or download log.</p> \n<p>The Click&amp;Clean extension for Chrome allows you to clear your cache, URL searches, website cookies, and download history with a single click of a button on your browser toolbar. The extension can also scan your computer for viruses and clean up your hard drive of unused applications — helping your computer run faster as a result.</p> \n<h3>3. <a href=\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/j2team-security/hmlcjjclebjnfohgmgikjfnbmfkigocc?hl=en&amp;__hstc=20629287.a51a184b1f4b68b5a109abeccb174b23.1628192355924.1630000442296.1630011805805.80&amp;__hssc=20629287.1.1630011805805&amp;__hsfp=4043529008\">J2TEAM Security</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/j2team-chrome-extension.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=j2team-chrome-extension.jpeg\" alt=\"J2TEAM Security Chrome extension\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<h4>Users: 200K+</h4> \n<p>J2TEAM Security isn't your average firewall. This Chrome extension starts with basic virus protection. It also allows you to customize your website block list and ensures your Chrome browser uses the \"HTTPS\" security tag on blogging sites — preventing you from visiting user blogs that are deemed unsafe.</p> \n<p>The extension also offers a variety of Facebook-specific privacy settings, such as blocking the \"seen\" tag after you read certain private messages and hiding how long you've been active in Facebook Messenger.</p> \n<h3>4. <a href=\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/ghostery-%E2%80%93-privacy-ad-blo/mlomiejdfkolichcflejclcbmpeaniij?hl=en&amp;__hstc=20629287.a51a184b1f4b68b5a109abeccb174b23.1628192355924.1630000442296.1630011805805.80&amp;__hssc=20629287.1.1630011805805&amp;__hsfp=4043529008\">Ghostery</a></h3> \n<h4><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/ghostery-chrome-extension.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=ghostery-chrome-extension.jpeg\" alt=\"Ghostery Chrome extension\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px;\" /></h4> \n<h4>Users: 2M+</h4> \n<p>Ghostery is a sophisticated ad-blocking extension designed to remove ads that distract or interrupt you while you're viewing specific website content. It also disguises your browsing data so ad-tracking tools are unable to collect personal information that you'd prefer to keep private. These features help to speed up webpages' load time and ultimately improve your browsing experience.</p> \n<h3>5. <a href=\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/checkbot-seo-web-speed-se/dagohlmlhagincbfilmkadjgmdnkjinl?hl=en&amp;__hstc=20629287.a51a184b1f4b68b5a109abeccb174b23.1628192355924.1630000442296.1630011805805.80&amp;__hssc=20629287.1.1630011805805&amp;__hsfp=4043529008\">Checkbot</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/checkbot-chrome-extension.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=checkbot-chrome-extension.jpeg\" alt=\"Checkbot Chrome extension\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<h4>Users: 40K+</h4> \n<p>Checkbot combines technical SEO with modern security to help you analyze both how safe and how optimized a website is for search engines. Because search engines like Google prioritize website security in addition to content quality in their rankings, this Chrome extension is a handy one-two punch for content creators and web developers.</p> \n<p>Checkbot can test the page speed, SEO, and overall security of more than 250 URLs per domain for free — and help you improve in these three categories to protect you and your website visitors from unsafe material.</p> \n<h3>6. <a href=\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/avast-online-security/gomekmidlodglbbmalcneegieacbdmki?__hstc=20629287.a51a184b1f4b68b5a109abeccb174b23.1628192355924.1630000442296.1630011805805.80&amp;__hssc=20629287.1.1630011805805&amp;__hsfp=4043529008\">Avast Online Security</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/avast-online-security-chrome-extension.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=avast-online-security-chrome-extension.jpeg\" alt=\"Avast Online Security Chrome extension\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<h4>Users: 10M+</h4> \n<p>Avast Online Security is known as a \"web reputation plugin,\" examining each individual website you visit for suspicious information. The extension also warns you if the site you're visiting simply has a bad reputation. In turn, you can rate the websites you visit to help Avast get better at flagging potentially unsafe webpages while on Chrome.</p> \n<h3>7. <a href=\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/flowcrypt-encrypt-gmail-w/bnjglocicdkmhmoohhfkfkbbkejdhdgc?hl=en&amp;__hstc=20629287.a51a184b1f4b68b5a109abeccb174b23.1628192355924.1630000442296.1630011805805.80&amp;__hssc=20629287.1.1630011805805&amp;__hsfp=4043529008\">FlowCrypt</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/flowcrypt-chrome-extension.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=flowcrypt-chrome-extension.jpeg\" alt=\"Flowcrypt Chrome extension\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<h4>Users: 70K+</h4> \n<p>This security extension is specific to emails, allowing you to send and receive encrypted emails (and attachments) to and from your colleagues. It's one of the best ways to be sure your emails are kept private and secure while in transit to the recipient.</p> \n<p>FlowCrypt uses PGP encryption, which stands for \"Pretty Good Privacy\" — the standard for encryption in most email clients. The tool integrates perfectly with Gmail, adding a \"Secure Compose\" button to your inbox.</p> \n<h3>8. <a href=\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/fair-adblocker/lgblnfidahcdcjddiepkckcfdhpknnjh?hl=en-US&amp;__hstc=20629287.a51a184b1f4b68b5a109abeccb174b23.1628192355924.1630000442296.1630011805805.80&amp;__hssc=20629287.1.1630011805805&amp;__hsfp=4043529008\">Fair AdBlocker</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/fair-adblocker-chrome-extension.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=fair-adblocker-chrome-extension.jpeg\" alt=\"Fair AdBlocker Chrome extension\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<h4>Users: 1M+</h4> \n<p>Fair AdBlocker offers both malware and adware in one browser extension. The tool protects you from malware as well as distracting ads and pop-ups. Once installed, you can configure your blocking settings to hide the types of ads you're least interested in seeing — especially those that carry dangerous information that can infect your computer.</p> \n<h3>9. <a href=\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/speedtest-by-ookla/pgjjikdiikihdfpoppgaidccahalehjh\">Speedtest by Ookla</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/speedtest-ookla-chrome-extension.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=speedtest-ookla-chrome-extension.jpeg\" alt=\"Speedtest by Ookla Chrome extension\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<h4>Users: 2M+</h4> \n<p>Find out how fast your internet connection is and learn how quickly websites are loading. Knowing this information can help you move to another internet connection if needed, and you’ll also get to see performance metrics for your own site.</p> \n<h3>10. <a href=\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/hola-free-vpn-proxy-unblo/gkojfkhlekighikafcpjkiklfbnlmeio\">Hola Free VPN</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/hola-free-vpn-chrome-extension.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=hola-free-vpn-chrome-extension.jpeg\" alt=\"Hola Free VPN Chrome extension\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<h4>Users: 7M+</h4> \n<p>Whether you need to cloak your identity online or browse content from another country, Hola Free VPN allows you to do that for free. The tool can help you browse the internet safely and anonymously without needing to pay for an external VPN service.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Chrome Extensions for Social Media</h2> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/bitly-unleash-the-power-o/iabeihobmhlgpkcgjiloemdbofjbdcic?__hstc=20629287.a51a184b1f4b68b5a109abeccb174b23.1628192355924.1630000442296.1630011805805.80&amp;__hssc=20629287.1.1630011805805&amp;__hsfp=4043529008\">Bitly</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/bitly-chrome-extension.jpeg?width=640&amp;name=bitly-chrome-extension.jpeg\" alt=\"Bitly Chrome extension\" width=\"640\" style=\"width: 640px;\" /></p> \n<h4>Users: 500K+</h4> \n<p>This extension lets marketers quickly and easily shorten links and share them on social media directly from their browser. This is particularly useful for social media marketers and allows for personalization with an Enterprise plan.</p> \n<h3>2. <a href=\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/buzzsumo/gedpbnanjmblcmlfhgfficjnglidndfo?__hstc=20629287.a51a184b1f4b68b5a109abeccb174b23.1628192355924.1630000442296.1630011805805.80&amp;__hssc=20629287.1.1630011805805&amp;__hsfp=4043529008\">BuzzSumo</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/buzzsumo-chrome-extension.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=buzzsumo-chrome-extension.jpeg\" alt=\"Buzzsumo Chrome extension\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<h4>Users: 20K+</h4> \n<p>BuzzSumo provides insight into how content is performing. When you're on a web page, click the extension to show metrics such as the number of social shares and backlinks to a piece. This tool provides an easy way to see how much engagement your content is generating. You could also use BuzzSumo to perform competitor analysis and uncover strategies that might make your content more shareable.</p> \n<h3>3. <a href=\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/pinterest-save-button/gpdjojdkbbmdfjfahjcgigfpmkopogic?__hstc=20629287.a51a184b1f4b68b5a109abeccb174b23.1628192355924.1630000442296.1630011805805.80&amp;__hssc=20629287.1.1630011805805&amp;__hsfp=4043529008\">Pinterest</a></h3> \n<h4><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/pinterest-chrome-extension.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=pinterest-chrome-extension.jpeg\" alt=\"Pinterest Chrome extension\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\">Users: 8M+</img></h4> \n<p>This extension allows you to easily save items onto your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-use-pinterest#sm.00006uybatuk9erxqe91juzya6sra\">Pinterest</a> boards without navigating away from what you're doing. What's neat about this tool is that it shows you multiple pinnable items available on each website so you can save more than one item to your board at a time. (Normally, you would have to click into each blog post or image in order to separately pin each to your boards individually.)</p> \n<h3>4. <a href=\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/save-to-facebook/jmfikkaogpplgnfjmbjdpalkhclendgd?__hstc=20629287.a51a184b1f4b68b5a109abeccb174b23.1628192355924.1630000442296.1630011805805.80&amp;__hssc=20629287.1.1630011805805&amp;__hsfp=4043529008\">Save to Facebook</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/save-to-facebook-chrome-extension.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=save-to-facebook-chrome-extension.jpeg\" alt=\"Save to Facebook Chrome extension\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<h4>Users: 1M+</h4> \n<p>Facebook's \"Save\" feature lets users aggregate links, images, and videos they find on Facebook in one location in their account. This extension allows you to do the same from anywhere on the web, making Facebook a centralized place to save content you're interested in checking out later.</p> \n<h3>5. <a href=\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/ritetag/hclhpnhohpmlbadmeieecaandnglfodm?__hstc=20629287.a51a184b1f4b68b5a109abeccb174b23.1628192355924.1630000442296.1630011805805.80&amp;__hssc=20629287.1.1630011805805&amp;__hsfp=4043529008\">RiteTag</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/ritetag-chrome-extension.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=ritetag-chrome-extension.jpeg\" alt=\"Ritetag Chrome extension\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<h4>Users: 30K+</h4> \n<p>RiteTag shows you how hashtags are performing on Twitter and Facebook before you post content. Once you log in to RiteTag using your Twitter or Facebook credentials, it checks the hashtags you begin typing in real time and color codes them:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>If your hashtag is green, it means the hashtag will help your content be seen now.</li> \n <li>If your hashtag is blue, it means the hashtag will help your content be seen over time.</li> \n <li>If your hashtag is gray, you should select a new hashtag because it has low levels of engagement.</li> \n <li>If your hashtag is red, you should select a new hashtag because it's so popular, your content will disappear into the crowd.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>6. <a href=\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/buffer/noojglkidnpfjbincgijbaiedldjfbhh\">Buffer</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/buffer-chrome-extension.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=buffer-chrome-extension.jpeg\" alt=\"Buffer Chrome extension\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<h4>Users: 200K+</h4> \n<p>Buffer allows you to easily share content from any website to your Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn profiles. If you’re a Buffer customer, you can also use the extension to schedule posts from your browser without needing to access the Buffer website. You can also queue posts for future publication.</p> \n<h3>7. <a href=\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/web-for-instagram-with-di/kcphkpjlcmfhhgiondcilolmgijhhmip?hl=en\">App for Instagram</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/app-for-instagram-chrome-extension.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=app-for-instagram-chrome-extension.jpeg\" alt=\"App for Instagram Chrome extension\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<h4>Users: 90K</h4> \n<p>Want to keep tabs on Instagram notifications without having to constantly check your phone? You can use this tool to further refine your social media marketing efforts and track brand sentiment.</p> \n<h3>10. <a href=\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/hubspot-social/edkibgpollgbhnjalcdlpmbjmdgohjko\">HubSpot Social</a></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/hubspot-social-chrome-extension.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=hubspot-social-chrome-extension.jpeg\" alt=\"HubSpot Social Chrome extension\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<h4>Users: 20K+</h4> \n<p>Are you a current HubSpot customer?
