Riserbato","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5e999bfc-f8b2-4ab7-96a8-c1467f450ca2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn7@2020_2/2021/09/27/16-55-42-927_6a368182cf964ce9.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Make%20Instagram%20Story%20Highlights%20%5B+Engage%20Your%20Audience%5D-3.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn26@2020_2/2021/09/27/16-55-44-809_4e39b516fd66b73b.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Make%20Instagram%20Story%20Highlights%20%5B+Engage%20Your%20Audience%5D.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn94@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-47-423_fed3e7b15a80ba85.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Make%20Instagram%20Story%20Highlights%20%5B+Engage%20Your%20Audience%5D-2.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn41@2020_6/2021/09/27/16-55-45-239_a80d9a6475d550e9.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Make%20Instagram%20Story%20Highlights%20%5B+Engage%20Your%20Audience%5D-1.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn28@2020_6/2021/09/27/16-55-46-868_400d6a2ff47ab5e0.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Make%20Instagram%20Story%20Highlights%20%5B+Engage%20Your%20Audience%5D.png":null,"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/2db39870-e18b-4909-9c9e-8606903b35fb.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn61@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-44-831_b8faa1ff5575500a.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Finstagram-story-highlights&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn41@2020_5/2021/09/27/16-55-45-174_63d7603d8d629334.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1632761741215},{"createdTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","updatedTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","title":"Want to Be a Better Manager? Work on These 7 Management Skills","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/management-skills","description":"<p>You’ve worked hard to become a manager and now you feel ill-prepared. Or perhaps you’ve been in your role for a while and feel stuck, stagnant.</p> \n<p>The imposter syndrome sets in and you’re not sure how to succeed in this role.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=4e634041-e1ce-4a85-8e65-aea12fc10b84&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"→ Click here to download leadership lessons from HubSpot founder, Dharmesh  Shah [Free Guide].\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/4e634041-e1ce-4a85-8e65-aea12fc10b84.png\"></a></p> \n<p>Management skills aren’t innate, they’re learned over time so the work is never fully done. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/people-manager-skills\">Succeeding as a manager</a> is a fluid dance that requires a willingness to learn.</p> \n<p>If you’ve already identified areas of improvement, this article will offer actionable tips. If you have no idea where to start, you will learn the top management skills every people manager needs and the ways to refine the ones you already have.</p> \n<h3>Types of Management Skills</h3> \n<p>There are three facets of <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/leadership-skills\">management skills that every leader will need </a>to succeed in their role.</p> \n<p>The first is interpersonal skills. How are you with people?</p> \n<p>Are you able to build relationships with leaders, peers, and direct reports? Would they describe you as trustworthy and reliable?</p> \n<p>To be a great manager, you have to hone the skills to navigate conversations within – and outside of – your team. On a personal level, interpersonal skills will allow you to empathize, celebrate and motivate those around you.</p> \n<p>The next facet of management is the strategic facet. As a leader, you’ll be tasked with identifying roadblocks, problem-solving and developing strategies to improve efficiency. This can be anything from helping your team improve its workflow to providing an innovative way to reach customers.</p> \n<p>As for the technical piece, think of this as the foundational piece. It includes software knowledge, the ability to operate certain machinery, expertise in equipment used at your company.</p> \n<p>To be a great manager, you should aim to be strong in all three management areas. Start by ranking yourself in each area and identify which one(s) you should focus on improving.</p> \n<p>Read the following section on what steps to tackle next.</p> \n<h3>Developing Management Skills</h3> \n<p>So you’ve identified some management areas you want to want on. So how do you actually develop them? There are three main ways:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Training </strong>– This is the first thing you should do once you know what you want to work on. Ideally, your company offers internal <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/black-business-leadership-advice\">training to help leaders</a> like you improve their skills. You can also seek out training programs online and reach out to your business network.</li> \n <li><strong>Mentorship </strong>– A mentor is a valuable asset to have when learning how to model new behaviors and skills. With a mentor by your side, you can discover new ways to do things, get feedback on your process, and brainstorm ideas.</li> \n <li><strong>Experience </strong>– Nothing beats experience. While getting training and a mentor is great, going through your own experiences is the best way to learn. While it isn’t always the easiest route, as you can hit roadblocks and make mistakes, you’ll likely face unique situations that will prepare you well for the future.</li> \n</ul> \n<h2>Top People Management Skills Every Leader Needs</h2> \n<p>As a people manager, you have to be multi-faceted – able to support your team, colleagues, and leaders all at once.</p> \n<p>Here are the top skills you’ll need to succeed:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Communicator</li> \n <li>Motivator</li> \n <li>Able to take accountability</li> \n <li>Business-minded and strategic</li> \n <li>Problem-solver and decision-maker</li> \n <li>Organized and willing to delegate</li> \n <li>Trustworthy and reliable</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Your team will look to you for guidance and support, your peers will look to you for collaboration and your leaders will look to you for strategic thinking and an innovative spirit.</p> \n<h3>1. Get to know your team.</h3> \n<p>In an ideal world, you would use the same approach to manage your team. In reality, everyone operates differently and requires a different <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/leadership-styles\">management style.</a></p> \n<p>To know what works best for your team, you have to get to know them. You’ll find that each person varies in how they communicate, receive feedback, want recognition, address conflicts, and more.</p> \n<p>So, how do you get to know them?</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Have weekly 1-on-1s.</li> \n <li>Conduct personality assessments and surveys.</li> \n <li>Have non-work activities on a regular basis, like a weekly watercooler or a monthly game night.</li> \n <li>Ask them about themselves, like \"What are your goals for the next 6 months?\", \"How do you prefer to be recognized?\".</li> \n <li>Host team-building activities.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Once you understand which approach to take, you’ll build a stronger relationship with your team and be equipped to handle any roadblocks down the line.</p> \n<h3>2. Be empathetic.</h3> \n<p>Now more than ever, employees want empathetic managers and leaders.</p> \n<p>A <a href=\"https://www.businessolver.com/resources/state-of-workplace-empathy\">2021 State of Workplace Empathy Study,</a> administered by software company Businessolver, revealed that only 1 in 4 employees believed empathy in their organizations was \"sufficient.\"</p> \n<p>The same study revealed that while the majority of CEOs recognize the positive impact an empathetic culture has on business, 68% still fear they’ll be less respected if they show empathy.</p> \n<p>The same study \"84% of CEOs and 70% of employees believe empathy drives better business outcomes\" however 68% of CEOs say they fear they will be less respected if they show empathy in the workplace, up 31 points from last year.\"</p> \n<p>However, one study suggests that couldn’t be further from the truth.</p> \n<p>According to the <a href=\"https://cclinnovation.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/empathyintheworkplace.pdf?webSyncID=4a998c41-e01a-03e6-d06a-66a59a1b7e93&amp;sessionGUID=62c8eba1-9359-822c-e5c4-45c3ada36d9e\">2020 Empathy in the Workplace study</a> by the Center for Creative Leadership, leaders see managers who show more empathy to their direct reports as better performers than those who show less or little empathy.</p> \n<p>How do you show empathy? Here are a few ways:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Get training on <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/psychological-safety-according-to-edmondson\">cultivating psychological safety at the workplace</a>.</li> \n <li>Practice active listening.</li> \n <li>Go behind the words and focus on their meaning or intent.</li> \n <li>Validate your team’s feelings and concerns.</li> \n <li>Offer resources.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>3. Build trust.</h3> \n<p>Trust is a core pillar of any workplace environment.</p> \n<p>In 2017, Harvard Business Review reported that employees who work in a culture of trust are more productive and have higher energy levels. High-trust organizations also have better employee retention rates.</p> \n<p>The key thing to remember here is that trust is a two-way street. Employees must trust their managers to support and guide them. However, managers must also instill trust in their team.</p> \n<p>Otherwise, you’re left with a micromanager who’s unwilling to delegate and empower their team.</p> \n<p>Building trust takes time, but here are some tactics you can start using today:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Be transparent</strong> about the reasons behind your decisions, address mistakes and setbacks, be clear about your goals and vision.</li> \n <li><strong>Follow-up </strong>on conversations you’ve had with your team. It will show that you listen and take action.</li> \n <li><strong>Make yourself available</strong> to your team, whether it’s by having an open-door policy, setting office hours, having regular 1-on-1s.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>4. Uplift and celebrate your team.</h3> \n<p>When I spoke to 5 HubSpot managers on <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/be-a-good-manager\">their management journey,</a> they shared one common belief: A key part of their role involved taking a backseat to allow their team to step into the spotlight.</p> \n<p>This can take many forms. One way to uplift your team is by identifying high-visibility opportunities. For instance, your direct report suggested using the audio and video content platform <a href=\"https://www.casted.us/\">Casted</a> for an upcoming project.</p> \n<p>Instead of relaying the message to the DRI, you could find a way for your direct report to collaborate on the project.</p> \n<p>Start by checking in with your team to understand their goals and from there, you can find opportunities that will help them meet their objectives.</p> \n<p>Another way to uplift your team is by recognizing their performance.</p> \n<p>One thing to keep in mind is that not everyone likes recognition the same way.</p> \n<p>Some employees may like public recognition while others prefer private, quieter celebrations. This goes back to knowing your team and understanding how they operate.</p> \n<h3>5. Learn how to manage your time.</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/time-management-tips-long-term-deadlines\">Time management</a> is a skill you should master, whether you’re a team lead or an individual contributor.</p> \n<p>As a manager, it’s particularly important because you’re responsible for more than just your work. As such, you’ll need to organize your time in a way that factors in your tasks as well as time to support your team.</p> \n<h3>6. Cultivate self-awareness.</h3> \n<p>Do you know what your strengths and weaknesses are?</p> \n<p>Some of us never think about them outside of job interviews, but it’s important to check in with yourself on a regular basis.</p> \n<p>This self-assessment will allow you to identify areas of improvement and seek out resources to be a better manager for your team.</p> \n<h3>7. Lean on your peers and mentors<span style=\"color: #434343; font-size: 14px;\">.</span></h3> \n<p>You’ve done everything you can on your end to become a better manager. That’s great – now lean on those around you.</p> \n<p>Your peers can offer insight into their strategies and thought processes to help you on your own. A mentor will have a breadth of knowledge and experience that you can learn from to grow as a manager.</p> \n<p>In fact, one <a href=\"http://surveymonkey.com/curiosity/cnbc-workplace-happiness-index-july-2019/\">2019 CNBC/Survey Monkey survey</a> found that employees are more likely to be satisfied with their job when they have a mentor than those who don’t.</p> \n<p>We naturally tend to stay in our comfort zone and seek out information that validates our current beliefs and biases. By seeking out guidance from others, you widen your lens and gain an opportunity to do things differently.</p> \n<p>Improving your management skills won’t happen overnight. However, if you stay in tune with your team’s needs and maintain a willingness to learn, you’re well on your way.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=5174aed9-1caa-4a36-b2d6-84c4d96c25fb&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New Call-to-action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5174aed9-1caa-4a36-b2d6-84c4d96c25fb.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fmanagement-skills&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 21 Sep 2021 17:45:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/4e634041-e1ce-4a85-8e65-aea12fc10b84.png","linkMd5":"0271f7c787609458ee397a0a39560ad6","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn35@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-42-278_a76d18c90cdcfa92.webp","destWidth":660,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":7430,"destBytes":10618,"author":"mbretous@hubspot.com (Martina Bretous)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/4e634041-e1ce-4a85-8e65-aea12fc10b84.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn35@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-42-278_a76d18c90cdcfa92.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5174aed9-1caa-4a36-b2d6-84c4d96c25fb.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn74@2020_5/2021/09/27/16-55-49-176_5d7cf3090735f322.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fmanagement-skills&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn57@2020_6/2021/09/27/16-55-45-554_b42214572906e93e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1632761741256},{"createdTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","updatedTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","title":"LinkedIn vs. Facebook: Which Is Best for Your Business?","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/linkedin-vs-facebook","description":"<p>The slew of social media channels available today can paralyze even the savviest business owners.</p> \n<p><em>Where do you start? Which one is best? How do you avoid wasting time on channels that won't bring in a solid ROI? </em>The struggle is real.</p> \n<a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=5effd942-8317-40c2-86c5-7af4169660ea&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Download Now: Free Social Media Calendar\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5effd942-8317-40c2-86c5-7af4169660ea.png\" align=\"middle\" /></a> \n<p>Facebook and LinkedIn are two of the biggest social media platforms and provide a number of opportunities to reach your audience. This leaves us with this question: Which one should <em>you</em> focus your efforts on?</p> \n<p>We’ll cover the pros and cons of each platform below.</p> \n<h2>LinkedIn vs. Facebook for Business</h2> \n<p>Let's recap quickly.</p> \n<p>At its core, LinkedIn is a professional network that was initially created as a corporate recruitment platform. Now, it <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/linkedin-content-marketing?_ga=2.257431054.449608931.1631435253-542225752.1631435253\">boasts many features</a> similar to traditional social media sites, including status updates, blogging capabilities, and private messages.</p> \n<p>It’s also the<a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/marketing-statistics\"> </a><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/marketing-statistics\">most effective platform</a> when it comes to delivering content and securing audience engagement.</p> \n<p>Facebook, on the other hand, was specifically designed as a place for people to share and communicate. The \"sharing\" element is its most prominent selling point, but there are still plenty of other features that allow businesses to effectively reach their audiences.</p> \n<p>In fact, <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/news/new-ways-to-drive-product-discovery-and-purchases\">one survey by Facebook</a> found that 74% of American consumers use the platform to discover new products and brands.</p> \n<p>LinkedIn and Facebook both have the Groups feature that allows you to connect with other like-minded people, and they both have powerful ad setups.</p> \n<p>So with similar features, what <em>are </em>the key differences between the two? We’ll cover those here.</p> \n<h3>Numbers-wise, Facebook wins hands down.</h3> \n<p>Facebook has an astounding<a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/264810/number-of-monthly-active-facebook-users-worldwide/\"> </a><a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/264810/number-of-monthly-active-facebook-users-worldwide/\">2.8 </a><a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/264810/number-of-monthly-active-facebook-users-worldwide/\">billion monthly </a><a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/264810/number-of-monthly-active-facebook-users-worldwide/\">active users (MAU) across the world</a>, which makes <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/194471/number-of-linkedin-users-usa/\">LinkedIn's 64.7 million MAU</a> seem small in comparison.</p> \n<p>On both platforms, the biggest age group is 25- to 34-year-olds, according to 2021 data from Statista. However, Facebook has a wider range of users with roughly 10% falling below 18 years old or above 64 years old.</p> \n<p>This is because LinkedIn caters mostly to professionals looking to network whereas Facebook hosts the everyday consumer.</p> \n<p>Furthermore, the <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-marketing\">2020 State of Marketing Report</a> by HubSpot revealed that marketers see the highest return on investment from Facebook, with LinkedIn being the 4th highest out of 8 platforms.</p> \n<h3>LinkedIn is a stronger B2B platform.</h3> \n<p>As mentioned before, LinkedIn is a go-to spot for business-driven individuals. As such, it’s a great platform for business-to-business brands.</p> \n<p>Here’s a breakdown of why:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>It’s easy to identify key decision-makers (and reach them in ads).</li> \n <li>Social selling is embedded into the platform.</li> \n <li>It’s easier to network as the platform was built specifically for that purpose.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>In fact, <a href=\"https://www.emarketer.com/content/linkedin-holds-third-of-all-us-b2b-digital-display-ad-revenue?trk=lms-blog-librand\">eMarketer reported</a> that LinkedIn occupies the largest share of B2B display ad spending at 32%. But we’ll talk more about ads in <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/linkedin-vs-facebook#ads\">this section</a>.</p> \n<p>Facebook may work better for brands that want to reach consumers directly. In addition, you gain access to ten times more prospects and have a great place to generate brand awareness and engagement. So, while Facebook leads in numbers, LinkedIn takes the win when it comes to generating tangible leads.</p> \n<h3>Thought leadership happens more organically on LinkedIn.</h3> \n<p>Thought leadership is one way brands are gaining credibility as well as visibility. According to a <a href=\"https://www.surveymonkey.com/curiosity/2020-thought-leadership-report/\">2020 Thought Leadership Report by Survey Monkey</a>, 66% of marketers consider it a top priority within their marketing team.</p> \n<p>A thought leader’s role is to educate, encourage conversation and drive action. The same study shows that thought leadership programs help with lead generation and brand awareness efforts by increasing website traffic, media mentions, subscribers, and more.</p> \n<p>When it comes to thought leadership articles, LinkedIn has a leg up. The platform is already designed for business conversations. As such, brands can have more success with thought leadership content compared to Facebook.</p> \n<p>So, here’s a quick recap:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Facebook pros: </strong>Large user base, proven ROI</li> \n <li><strong>Facebook cons: </strong>Isn’t the best for B2B marketing</li> \n <li><strong>LinkedIn pros: </strong>Business-driven platform, social selling and networking tools, great opportunities for thought leadership</li> \n <li><strong>LinkedIn cons: </strong>Smaller user base</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Now that we've taken a general look at the two platforms, let's take a more detailed look at some of the key features they have for businesses.</p> \n<h2>LinkedIn Groups vs. Facebook Groups</h2> \n<p>The Groups feature on both<a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/help/linkedin/answer/1164/linkedin-groups-membership-overview?lang=en\"> </a><a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/help/linkedin/answer/1164/linkedin-groups-membership-overview?lang=en\">LinkedIn</a> and<a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/help/265435626889287\"> </a><a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/help/265435626889287\">Facebook</a> gives businesses the chance to mingle and connect with prospects and other like-minded businesses.</p> \n<p>However, it's critical to keep in mind people's motives when they're on different sites. When users are engaging with others in <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/4710/5-tips-for-creating-promoting-and-managing-a-linkedin-group.aspx\">LinkedIn Groups</a>, there's a high chance they're in a work-related mindset in some capacity.</p> \n<p>In Facebook Groups, on the other hand, people are more likely to share their personal opinions on everything – from lifestyle and food to politics and hobbies.</p> \n<p>So, when determining which Groups feature is best for you, think about the audience you're targeting.</p> \n<p>For instance, if you're targeting general consumers with an interest in cooking because you're selling the latest food blender, Facebook Groups is probably the way to go.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p>However, if you're selling a high-priced service for top-tier management personnel, LinkedIn Groups might be a better bet.</p> \n<p>Finally, let's touch on the ads aspect of both platforms.</p> \n<p>In terms of variety, both platforms have reached pretty equal footing.</p> \n<p>While Facebook has boasted a diverse range of ad types for years (we're talking canvas, carousel, video, dynamic, and lead ads just to name a few), LinkedIn now also offers several ad formats, including video, carousel, lead, dynamic, and Sponsored InMail ads.</p> \n<p>Each offers a user-friendly ad manager. This means that you can start organizing your creative assets on a content marketing platform like <a href=\"https://www.casted.us/solution/platform\">Casted</a>, then build your ad in just a few steps on either LinkedIn or Facebook.</p> \n<p>Targeting-wise, if you think Facebook has the <em>capability</em> of reaching more people, you're right. However, this doesn't mean that LinkedIn doesn't have powerful targeting capabilities.</p> \n<p>Both platforms are centered around user input and serve up ads and content relevant to the information their members give them.</p> \n<p>On both Facebook and LinkedIn, you can target users based on job title, household income, company, location, and age on both platforms. Where Facebook has the upper hand is that you can dig a little deeper on Facebook, targeting users depending on their life milestones, behavior, and other personalized information.</p> \n<p>In addition, both platforms allow brands to use source audiences to reach consumers who are similar to their current audience. Facebook calls it \"Lookalike Audience\" while LinkedIn has named it \"Audience Expansion.\"</p> \n<p>Lastly, it's important to consider the cost.</p> \n<p>Typically, you get more for your money on Facebook. <a href=\"https://www.webfx.com/blog/social-media/facebook-ads-vs-linkedin-ads/\">According to WebFX</a>, the average cost-per-click for a LinkedIn ad is a whopping $5.26, compared to just $0.97 with Facebook.</p> \n<p>However, a higher cost doesn’t necessarily translate to a higher return on ad spend (ROAS).</p> \n<h2>Who Wins? You Decide</h2> \n<p>While LinkedIn and Facebook do share common features, it's clear their purpose and audiences are quite different.</p> \n<p>Which one you decide to use depends entirely on what industry you're in, who you're trying to reach, and your marketing goals.</p> \n<p>It’s also important to note that you don’t necessarily have to choose. Perhaps you use LinkedIn for a targeted lead generation campaign, while you use Facebook to increase brand awareness and engage with your customers.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's Note: This post was originally published in August 2019 and has been updated for comprehensiveness. </em></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=3798b15e-747c-485c-9978-e2892c7e9811&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"social media content calendar\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3798b15e-747c-485c-9978-e2892c7e9811.png\" /></a></p> \n<p></p> \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Flinkedin-vs-facebook&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \" />","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 22 Sep 2021 18:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5effd942-8317-40c2-86c5-7af4169660ea.png","linkMd5":"8d871ea0ded450648a0e94b552a1ef1d","destWidth":393,"destHeight":60,"sourceBytes":3692,"destBytes":6052,"author":"Ryan Gould","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5effd942-8317-40c2-86c5-7af4169660ea.png":null,"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3798b15e-747c-485c-9978-e2892c7e9811.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn19@2020_3/2021/09/27/16-55-44-001_dfeb7fad21cab804.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Flinkedin-vs-facebook&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn54@2020_5/2021/09/27/16-55-46-411_18a25a2639483d61.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1632761741252},{"createdTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","updatedTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","title":"10 Real Estate Social Media Marketing Strategies That'll Bring in New Business","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/5911/social-media-dos-and-don-ts-for-realtors.aspx","description":"<div class=\"hs-migrated-cms-post\"> \n <p><em>The following is a guest post by <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/leslie-mann-4b681717/\">Leslie Mann</a>, a real estate agent with <a href=\"http://www.gibsonsothebysrealty.com/eng\">Gibson Sotheby's International Realty</a> of Weston, MA.</em></p> \n <p>Buying or selling a home is an important financial (and emotional) decision. Most people are full of questions when they undertake this endeavor.</p> \n <p>Your clients want more than someone with a real estate license. They want an agent who will protect their interests and help them navigate the complexities of property ownership. The agent they choose must be someone they'll feel confident having by their side throughout the process.</p> \n <p></p> \n <p>That's where social media comes in. If applied correctly, it can be a great way to open a dialogue, share advice, and forge an ongoing relationship with buyers, sellers, and renters. In this post, learn the benefits of using social media for real estate, a handy list of do’s and don’ts for agents to follow, and examples of posts you can incorporate into your real estate social media strategy.</p> \n <p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=5f39ea20-9313-42f4-b9c7-86b8b59e717a&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Free Resource: Real Estate Strategy Template\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5f39ea20-9313-42f4-b9c7-86b8b59e717a.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n <p></p> \n <p><a href=\"https://ryantombul.parksathome.com/\">Ryan Tombul</a>, Nashville Realtor, J.D., <a href=\"https://www.rocketmortgage.com/learn/evolution-of-home-showings-during-covid-19\">says</a>, “Social media doubles as an avenue for free marketing that allows agents to supplement exposure for listings within their own personal network and beyond.” Read on to discover real estate social media strategy tips, as well as things you should avoid.&nbsp;</p> \n</div> \n<h3>Tips That Agents Should Embrace</h3> \n<h4>1. Promote the town, not just the house.</h4> \n<p>Homebuyers want to know the good, bad, and ugly of each town to which they're considering a move. Yet, most real estate blogs simply give buyers basic demographic statistics and perhaps some flowery language about the area. Instead, use your social media channels to provide potential clients a far richer understanding of the markets you serve, letting them know the pros and cons of each neighborhood.</p> \n<p>Many cities have a \"@CityOf ...\" Twitter handle, which you can mention directly in your own tweets. Use these handles to promote properties you have listed in that city. City accounts on Twitter tend to be receptive to these shout-outs and might retweet you — increasing your post's reach to <em>their</em> followers.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://business.instagram.com/?ref=sem_smb&amp;utm_source=GOOGLE&amp;utm_medium=fbsmbsem&amp;utm_campaign=Instagram_LP_Phase_2_Alpha&amp;kenid=eb821d0b-6091-4287-96a2-35bfd4a838c0&amp;gclid=EAIaIQobChMIjcy56b3t3AIVB56fCh1sCAVEEAAYASAAEgLSNPD_BwE\">Instagram Business accounts</a> are also prime real estate (no pun intended) for you to post beautiful photos of the town in which your properties are listed.</p> \n<h4>2. Be yourself.</h4> \n<p>I've heard of many realtors who pay a ghost writer to write their marketing copy, yet this approach has its shortcomings. The copy simply doesn't ring true; it fails to give clients a sense of who you really are. Studies show that consumers want to make a personal connection with those whom they do business with, and there's no shortcut to writing your own authentic social media content that resembles who you are as a real estate agency.</p> \n<p>Let your personality shine through across each social network you're on. It's a great way to open a dialogue with a client before they ever pick up the phone.</p> \n<h4>3. Educate your buyers.</h4> \n<p>Some of the most trying days as a real estate agent prove to be great lessons we can share with our clients. Talking about common real estate pitfalls makes your buyers smarter, giving them a smoother browsing experience and qualifying them to work with you.</p> \n<p>Social media is the perfect outlet for this. If you have a blog, consider writing articles about home-buying tips, and use social media to promote them. Perhaps you can tweet a \"Real Estate Fact of the Day,\" hashtagging #realestate while you're at it.</p> \n<h4>4. Chat with your followers.</h4> \n<p>Home buyers today expect instant responses to their questions, but where they ask those questions has changed.</p> \n<p>Home buyers are calling real estate agents much less than they used to with questions about a property or neighborhood. They're going online, using <a href=\"https://newsroom.fb.com/news/2016/10/getting-things-done-with-the-help-of-your-friends/\">Facebook's Recommendations feature</a>, and tweeting at real estate offices on Twitter. Be ready for this outreach, answer them, and use these questions as an opportunity to start dialogue with followers who might be in the early stages of the buying process.</p> \n<h4>5. Respond to comments, good and bad.</h4> \n<p>Respond promptly and courteously to engage readers who post comments on your social media sites. One caveat: Don't feel compelled to respond to those who post abusive comments. Social media does lure its share of online bullies, and not every remark aimed at your is worth your breath.</p> \n<p>Resist the temptation to get into battle with your harshest critics, and acknowledge those who praise your service. A lot of people who reach out to you are simply looking for more information about a listing -- or a listing they might've thought was still available, but has been sold or rented. Absorb their frustration and use their comment as an opportunity to pivot their interest to other properties.</p> \n<h3>Practices That Agents Should Avoid</h3> \n<h4>6. Shouting about your home listings</h4> \n<p>It's fine to let people know about the homes you're marketing, but don't make the house itself the primary topic of your conversation. Think about common questions home buyers and sellers ask you, and turn these into posts. Provide valuable content and you'll keep people coming back.</p> \n<h4>7. Forgetting video</h4> \n<p>There are more than <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/marketing-statistics?_ga=2.47226663.1495790357.1629647959-1194139283.1629647959\">8 billion</a> daily video views on Facebook.</p> \n<p>It's tempting to skip the expense of shooting and editing a video, but online video is an important element of home marketing. Think about it: Home buyers are visual buyers, and if done well, a video creates an emotional connection with them that they might not have from just a photo-based listing.</p> \n<p>YouTube videos also improve your website's ranking in search engines like Google -- a common place where home buyers and renters start their search for a new home.</p> \n<h4>8. Assuming you're only connecting with first-time buyers</h4> \n<p>According to a <a href=\"https://www.nar.realtor/sites/default/files/documents/2021-home-buyers-and-sellers-generational-trends-03-16-2021.pdf\">recent PDF by the National Association of Realtors (NAR)</a>, 24% of home buyers in America are 41-50 years old or younger. About 22% of them are <em>first-time</em> buyers. If you think you're just talking to first-time home buyers on social media, think again.</p> \n<p>If you think you think you're just talking to first-time home buyers on social media, think again.</p> \n<p>Social networks like Facebook are great places to engage \"fans\" and learn what they're looking for from their agent, but keep in mind they're not all new to the buying process. Have content suited for all levels of home-buying experience ready to serve up to your fans and followers -- you never know whom you'll be connecting with.</p> \n<h4>9. Talking to yourself</h4> \n<p>A post, link, photo, or tweet on your profile might look nice to <em>you</em>, but it means very little if it doesn't resonate with the people who are following your page.</p> \n<p>Social media is more about listening than about talking. Pay attention to what people are saying about you and your brand. Solicit and gather feedback through informal polls or via free survey services like <a href=\"https://www.surveymonkey.com/\">Survey Monkey</a><a href=\"http://www.tweetbeep.com/\">&nbsp;</a>or <a href=\"https://docs.google.com/forms/u/0/?tgif=d\"> Google Forms</a>.&nbsp;This will ensure each and every piece of content you share on social media reflects the interests of your customers.</p> \n<h4>10. Ignoring your existing clients</h4> \n<p>Invite your previous buyers and sellers to join you on social media. That way, your sites becomes richer communities of shared experiences and objective advice from those who recently completed the home buying/selling journey.</p> \n<h2>Using Social Media for Real Estate</h2> \n<p>It may not seem like the right channel to use for your industry, but using social media for real estate has various benefits. Most significantly, there are more than <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/278414/number-of-worldwide-social-network-users/\">3.78 billion</a> social media users globally, and the average person spends close to <a href=\"https://datareportal.com/social-media-users\">2 ½</a> hours using social media every single day. So, statistically speaking, your audience is already on social media — why not meet them where they already are?</p> \n<p>Second, social media also offers targeted advertising options tailored to audiences in specific locations — isn’t that just what realtors look for?&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Lastly, having a social media presence helps you build brand awareness and generate trust with your audience. They may not be ready to make a purchase yet or even reach out to begin a conversion, but if they see you’re consistently active on your platforms, or they come across one of your advertisements, they may make a mental note of what you offer and come back to you when they’re prepared to begin their process.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>COVID-19 has also impacted the real estate market, just as it has for other industries, so leveraging social media will help you stay up-to-date with current trends.</p> \n<h3>Social Media House-Buying Trends from COVID-19</h3> \n<p>While social media has always been a tool for realtors to leverage, COVID-19 has brought it center stage.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>One of the biggest changes is the rise of virtual showings. Some agencies reserved virtual viewings for specific circumstances or luxury homes, but it has now become a common practice: “We used to keep our virtual tours for our luxury homes, but we’ve found it adds to the home buying experience for our clients,” <a href=\"https://www.rocketmortgage.com/learn/evolution-of-home-showings-during-covid-19\">says Lisa Alexander</a>, president of Del-Co Realty.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>As health and safety restrictions are lifted, virtual showings are likely here to stay as buyers have realized a significant benefit from them: reduced costs. Buyers searching for new homes in locations they’re not in can save time and money on travel costs until they’re sure about their options.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>The length of the searching process is also lowered, as buyers can view multiple homes in a short period via online video or virtual tour, as opposed to waiting weeks for an open house or for there to be a space for them during a showing.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Given its relevance, let’s go over the various ways to leverage different social media platforms to share real estate content.&nbsp;</p> \n<h2>Real Estate Social Media Content</h2> \n<p>Realtors can benefit from using many of the same platforms that most businesses can benefit from — Facebook, Instagram, and TikTok. Let’s discuss how you can use them, and then go over content ideas to share on each platform.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>Facebook for Realtors</h3> \n<p>Facebook is an excellent tool for real estate professionals. It offers various high-quality options: targeted ads for local listings, Facebook messenger for conversations with clients, and the ability to share multiple forms of multimedia: images, videos, and even live video.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>Instagram for Realtors</h3> \n<p>On Instagram, Realtors can create a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/instagram-for-business-guide?_ga=2.72536211.1495790357.1629647959-1194139283.1629647959\">business account</a> and include contact CTA buttons so those who land on your profile can send you a message on the platform, an email about a property image they saw that intrigued them, or other personalized options.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>The platform is great for sharing high-quality image content, and the image below is an example of a new property announcement.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/annunce%20recently%20listed%20real%20estate%20properties%20on%20instagram.jpg?width=543&amp;name=annunce%20recently%20listed%20real%20estate%20properties%20on%20instagram.jpg\" alt=\"realtor social media example instagram post announcing new listing\" width=\"543\" style=\"width: 543px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>TikTok for Realtors</h3> \n<p>TikTok is an emerging platform for all industries, but it can be extremely beneficial for realtors, especially considering that the audience favors <a href=\"https://medium.com/clyde-group/gen-z-is-all-about-authenticity-59d863b0bdcf\">behind-the-scenes type content</a>, which is exactly what house walkthroughs are (the video below is an example).</p> \n<div class=\"hs-embed-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; width: 100%; height: auto; padding: 0px; max-width: 540px; min-width: 256px; display: block; margin: auto; max-height: 811px;\">\n <div class=\"hs-embed-content-wrapper\">\n  <blockquote class=\"tiktok-embed\" cite=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@smartcityhtx/video/6985547722610756870\" style=\"max-width: 605px;min-width: 325px;\">  \n   <a title=\"@smartcityhtx\" href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@smartcityhtx\">@smartcityhtx</a> \n   <p>Can anyone guess what this floor plan goes for before specials?👇 <a title=\"houstonapartments\" href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/tag/houstonapartments\">#houstonapartments</a> <a title=\"midtownhouston\" href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/tag/midtownhouston\">#midtownhouston</a> <a title=\"houstonmidtown\" href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/tag/houstonmidtown\">#houstonmidtown</a> <a title=\"apartmentliving\" href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/tag/apartmentliving\">#apartmentliving</a> <a title=\"houston\" href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/tag/houston\">#houston</a></p> \n   <a title=\"♬ original sound - smartcityhtx\" href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/music/original-sound-6985547600460073734\">♬ original sound - smartcityhtx</a>  \n  </blockquote> \n </div>\n</div> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<p>In addition, TikTok users don’t expect content to be high-quality or professional-grade, which is even better for realtors that can just use a phone camera on-site to take a video. Below we’ll go over additional content ideas to post on social media.&nbsp;</p> \n<h2>Real Estate Social Media Ideas</h2> \n<p><strong>Going live for open house and virtual showings.</strong></p> \n<p>Realtors can do this on Instagram, Facebook, and TikTok, and a benefit to going live is that the videos can be saved and later shared to your profile, acting as an additional form of content.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><strong>Answering audience questions.&nbsp;</strong></p> \n<p>All social media platforms are a great place to answer audience questions, as you can engage with your audience and develop a rapport that leads to a working relationship. The TikTok below is an example of a realtor answering an audience question about financing a home.&nbsp;</p> \n<div class=\"hs-embed-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; width: 100%; height: auto; padding: 0px; max-width: 540px; min-width: 256px; display: block; margin: auto; max-height: 811px;\">\n <div class=\"hs-embed-content-wrapper\">\n  <blockquote class=\"tiktok-embed\" cite=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@mickeywrightrealtor/video/6987474860771380485\" style=\"max-width: 605px;min-width: 325px;\">  \n   <a title=\"@mickeywrightrealtor\" href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@mickeywrightrealtor\">@mickeywrightrealtor</a> \n   <p>Down Payment for a $350,000 house! <a title=\"tiktokrealtor\" href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/tag/tiktokrealtor\">#tiktokrealtor</a> <a title=\"smallbusinessowner\" href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/tag/smallbusinessowner\">#smallbusinessowner</a> <a title=\"downpayment\" href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/tag/downpayment\">#downpayment</a> <a title=\"firsttimehomebuyer\" href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/tag/firsttimehomebuyer\">#firsttimehomebuyer</a> <a title=\"realestate\" href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/tag/realestate\">#realestate</a></p> \n   <a title=\"♬ original sound - JoceM\" href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/music/original-sound-6928337222290770694\">♬ original sound - JoceM</a>  \n  </blockquote> \n </div>\n</div> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Another benefit to answering questions publicly is that it’s <em>public</em>, and everyone can see your responses. This can help interested buyers approach you with qualified, further-down-the-funnel questions.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><strong>Share customer testimonials and success stories.</strong></p> \n<p>All platforms are a great place to share <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/testimonial-request-template?_ga=2.155768635.1495790357.1629647959-1194139283.1629647959\">customer testimonials</a>, helping you use <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/user-generated-content-stats?_ga=2.155768635.1495790357.1629647959-1194139283.1629647959\">user-generated content</a> to establish legitimacy and credibility with your audience. The Facebook post below is an example of a client testimonial.&nbsp;</p> \n<div class=\"hs-embed-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; width: 100%; height: auto; padding: 0; max-width: 500px; max-height: 703px; min-width: 256px; display: block; margin: auto;\">\n <div class=\"hs-embed-content-wrapper\">\n  <div style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 140.6%; margin: 0px;\">\n   <iframe src=\"https://www.facebook.com/plugins/post.php?href=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2F112431123752651%2Fposts%2F373675244294903%2F%3Fd%3Dn&amp;width=500&amp;show_text=true&amp;height=703&amp;appId\" width=\"500\" height=\"703\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0px; left: 0px; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"true\"></iframe>\n  </div>\n </div>\n</div> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<p><strong>Property photos.</strong></p> \n<p>Property photos are a must for realtors on social media, especially on Instagram and Facebook. You can give clients a sneak peek of what to expect from the property and entice them to reach out to you to learn more through a virtual or in-person tour.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Here’s an example of high-quality property photos on Instagram:</p> \n<div class=\"hs-embed-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; width: 100%; height: auto; padding: 0px; max-width: 540px; min-width: 256px; display: block; margin: auto; max-height: 704px;\">\n <div class=\"hs-embed-content-wrapper\">\n  <blockquote class=\"instagram-media\" style=\" background:#FFF; width: 16px; transform: translateY(-4px);\">\n        &nbsp;\n       </div> \n       <div style=\" width: 0; height: 0; border-top: 8px solid #F4F4F4; border-left: 8px solid transparent; transform: translateY(-4px) translateX(8px);\">\n        &nbsp;\n       </div>\n      </div>\n     </div> \n     <div style=\"display: flex; flex-direction: column; flex-grow: 1; justify-content: center; margin-bottom: 24px;\"> \n      <div style=\" background-color: #F4F4F4; border-radius: 4px; flex-grow: 0; height: 14px; margin-bottom: 6px; width: 224px;\">\n       &nbsp;\n      </div> \n      <div style=\" background-color: #F4F4F4; border-radius: 4px; flex-grow: 0; height: 14px; width: 144px;\">\n       &nbsp;\n      </div>\n     </div></a>\n    <p style=\" color:#c9c8cd; font-family:Arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px; line-height:17px; margin-bottom:0; margin-top:8px; overflow:hidden; padding:8px 0 7px; text-align:center; text-overflow:ellipsis; white-space:nowrap;\"><a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/p/CSxPWDss2Co/?utm_source=ig_embed&amp;utm_campaign=loading\" style=\" color:#c9c8cd; font-family:Arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px; font-style:normal; font-weight:normal; line-height:17px; text-decoration:none;\">A post shared by Bovingdons (@bovingdonsbucks)</a></p>\n   </div>\n  </blockquote> \n </div>\n</div> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<p>You can share property photos on TikTok as still images, but the platform is better suited for video.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><strong>Property videos and tours.&nbsp;</strong></p> \n<p>All three platforms are great for video, as it gives your audiences an interactive way to learn about different properties. If they’re still curious after watching the video, they can click on a CTA button on your profile to ask for more info.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Here is an example of a property tour on TikTok:</p> \n<div class=\"hs-embed-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative;
