flex-direction: column; flex-grow: 1; justify-content: center; margin-bottom: 24px;\"> \n      <div style=\" background-color: #F4F4F4; border-radius: 4px; flex-grow: 0; height: 14px; margin-bottom: 6px; width: 224px;\">\n       &nbsp;\n      </div> \n      <div style=\" background-color: #F4F4F4; border-radius: 4px; flex-grow: 0; height: 14px; width: 144px;\">\n       &nbsp;\n      </div>\n     </div></a>\n    <p style=\" color:#c9c8cd; font-family:Arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px; line-height:17px; margin-bottom:0; margin-top:8px; overflow:hidden; padding:8px 0 7px; text-align:center; text-overflow:ellipsis; white-space:nowrap;\"><a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/reel/CSwDHgpCXdc/?utm_source=ig_embed&amp;utm_campaign=loading\" style=\" color:#c9c8cd; font-family:Arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px; font-style:normal; font-weight:normal; line-height:17px; text-decoration:none;\">A post shared by INTERIOR DESIGN (@interiors.media)</a></p>\n   </div>\n  </blockquote> \n </div>\n</div> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<p><strong>Realtor bios.</strong></p> \n<p>Relationships between agents and clients are important, as they trust you to take to heart the things that they care about and point them in the right direction. As a result, using social media to share realtor bios is worth considering. Your audience can learn more about what you offer and reach out if it feels like a good match.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/real%20estate%20agent%20bio%20on%20instagram.jpg?width=549&amp;name=real%20estate%20agent%20bio%20on%20instagram.jpg\" alt=\"real estate social media realtor bio instagram post example\" width=\"549\" style=\"width: 549px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p>If you're looking for more supporting information, the statistics below will further emphasize the importance of using social media for real estate.&nbsp;</p> \n<h2>Real Estate Social Media Statistics</h2> \n<ul> \n <li>In 2020, <a href=\"https://theclose.com/agent-survey-2021/\">44%</a> of real estate agents generated the most clients via social media, only topped by referrals.&nbsp;</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://theclose.com/agent-survey-2021/\">82%</a> of agents plan to improve their social media presence to grow their business in 2021.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>The National Association of Realtors <a href=\"https://www.nar.realtor/research-and-statistics/research-reports/realtor-technology-survey\">2021 Realtor Technology</a> survey found that 53% of respondents say that social media is one of the most valuable technology tools they use.&nbsp;</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.nar.realtor/research-and-statistics/quick-real-estate-statistics\">74%</a> of realtors use Facebook for professional purposes.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>Clubhouse, a social media app that prioritizes audio, has real estate conversation clubs with <a href=\"https://www.socialmediatoday.com/news/why-real-estate-agents-are-prioritizing-social-media-more-than-email-in-202/594647/\">over 50k followers</a>.&nbsp;</li> \n <li>81% of older millennials, 80% of younger millennials, and 78% of Gen X <a href=\"https://www.nar.realtor/research-and-statistics/research-reports/real-estate-in-a-digital-age\">found their home on a mobile device</a>.&nbsp;</li> \n</ul> \n<p>At the end of the day, your followers may prove themselves to be your strongest property advocates.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>If you take the time to create a social media presence that includes high-quality photos of the properties you sell, you interact with clients, and you follow a consistent schedule, you’ll likely find yourself generating new clients and closing on more homes.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=bda2ff96-1786-4644-9d40-c4ccd7b7f376&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New call-to-action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/bda2ff96-1786-4644-9d40-c4ccd7b7f376.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fblog%2Ftabid%2F6307%2Fbid%2F5911%2Fsocial-media-dos-and-don-ts-for-realtors.aspx&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 13 Sep 2021 20:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5f39ea20-9313-42f4-b9c7-86b8b59e717a.png","linkMd5":"669766298725c482b6db623e0d8bc78a","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn60@2020_5/2021/09/27/16-55-42-300_1228983177d052d6.webp","destWidth":408,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":4511,"destBytes":6278,"author":"kbodnar@hubspot.com (Kipp Bodnar)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5f39ea20-9313-42f4-b9c7-86b8b59e717a.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn60@2020_5/2021/09/27/16-55-42-300_1228983177d052d6.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/annunce%20recently%20listed%20real%20estate%20properties%20on%20instagram.jpg?width=543&name=annunce%20recently%20listed%20real%20estate%20properties%20on%20instagram.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn86@2020_1/2021/09/27/16-55-45-507_ac0269a379dbf6b9.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/real%20estate%20agent%20bio%20on%20instagram.jpg?width=549&name=real%20estate%20agent%20bio%20on%20instagram.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn85@2020_5/2021/09/27/16-55-44-316_a446bc4054386547.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/bda2ff96-1786-4644-9d40-c4ccd7b7f376.png":null,"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fblog%2Ftabid%2F6307%2Fbid%2F5911%2Fsocial-media-dos-and-don-ts-for-realtors.aspx&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn96@2020_5/2021/09/27/16-55-46-516_0ddcf4c7c9547ec1.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1632761741249},{"createdTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","updatedTime":"2021-09-28 00:55:41","title":"The Ultimate Guide to Social Testing","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/social-testing","description":"<p>As marketers, we know the importance of making data-driven decisions. The more information we have about our audience, the more we’re able to make effective marketing moves.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>In addition, having the numbers to back up the implementation of a marketing strategy is almost as important as the strategy itself. One of the ways to get this data is through social media testing, where you figure out what campaigns resonate most with your audience and help you meet your marketing goals.</p>  \n<p>In this post, learn how you can run a social media test to help you meet your marketing goals and discover high-quality tools that will help you do so.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=5d42eade-1de3-4ff1-adba-6b1521e6cbde&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Free Download: A/B Testing Guide and Kit\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5d42eade-1de3-4ff1-adba-6b1521e6cbde.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p></p> \n<p>For instance, you might run a social test to learn if video campaigns are worth investing in on Facebook, so you create a post that measures impressions of an ad with and without a video attached. After the campaign, the interactions with your post will tell you if a video is a worthwhile investment for your brand, which makes this process so important.</p> \n<h3>The Benefits of Social Testing</h3> \n<p>Social media testing is important because it provides data-driven insights about your social media marketing activities. It allows you to analyze how different variables, like photo and video, affect performance.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, social media tests provide data about how audience behavior can influence the structure of your campaigns. You’ll get a picture of what is successful for your brand, and you can create campaigns that you know will work. Instead of researching countless industry benchmarks, you’ll have concrete data specific to your business that comes from testing results.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>There are multiple types of social media tests you can run for your business, and we’ll discuss them next.</p> \n<h2>Types of Social Tests</h2> \n<p>Let's say you want to know how copy affects an international audience on LinkedIn. Or, that you want evidence of a <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/landing-pages?_ga=2.2260019.2001540731.1628802809-620318951.1628802809\">landing page</a> performing better with a different image. Maybe you're trying to identify if changing the tone of <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/write-good-instagram-caption\">Instagram captions</a> will lead to more audience engagement.</p> \n<p>All of these scenarios are prime for social tests. They point out a problem that can be answered with data. This data would give insight about audiences interactions with brands on social media.</p> \n<p>After identifying the goal, it’s time to pick the type of test. Let's go through the different types and when you might use them.</p> \n<h3>A/B Test</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-do-a-b-testing?_ga=2.2260019.2001540731.1628802809-620318951.1628802809\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\"><span>A/B tests</span></a> are likely the most common form of social testing. They look at a variable between two content types, measure the outlined goal, and provide results. So, consider running an A/B test if you want to test a single, small variable that may alter audience behavior.</p> \n<p>For example, run an A/B test if you want to test out different CTA buttons on a Facebook ad or experiment with a post's copy with/without emojis. The image below is an example of what an A/B test can look like.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/a_b%20testing-2.jpg?width=1386&amp;name=a_b%20testing-2.jpg\" alt=\"social a/b testing set-up layout example\" width=\"1386\" style=\"width: 1386px;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-do-a-b-testing?_ga=2.2260019.2001540731.1628802809-620318951.1628802809\"><em><span>Image Source</span></em></a></p> \n<h3>Split Test</h3> \n<p>Split tests are often confused with A/B tests. In essence, they do the same thing: test two content types based on a goal. The difference is that a split test is more general than an A/B test; they're used to determine big changes, and the two variants are often entirely different.</p> \n<p>Use split testing if you want to know which layout of your Facebook Business page performs better. You can also run split tests to determine A/B test factors. For example, you can run a split test to determine which ad video cut you will use for a Sponsored Tweet, then A/B test different sections of the winning cut. The image below is an example of what a split test could look like on a business website.&nbsp;</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/split-testing.jpeg?width=1200&amp;name=split-testing.jpeg\" alt=\"split social testing example set up\" width=\"1200\" style=\"width: 1200px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"><span style=\"font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://adespresso.com/blog/facebook-ads-split-testing-101/\"><em>Image Source</em></a></span></p> \n<h3>Multivariable Test</h3> \n<p>Multivariable tests work differently than the two previously mentioned types, as they work with multiple variables instead of one or two. You can run a multivariable test to determine which of four ads works best. Alternatively, you can run one to assess the different makings of a post, like images vs. copy vs. captions.</p> \n<p>Run a multivariate test if you want to see the results of more than two different elements. For example, compare the caption, image, and CTA of a LinkedIn post to see what audiences are responding to, or look at three versions of a GIF to learn how audiences react to them. The image below is an example of a what a multivariate test set up could look like.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/multivariate%20testing.png?width=630&amp;name=multivariate%20testing.png\" alt=\"social multivariate testing example\" width=\"630\" style=\"width: 630px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"><span style=\"font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://www.comarch.com/trade-and-services/loyalty-marketing/blog/adapting-to-changing-consumer-behaviors-with-a-b-and-multivariate-testing/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></span></p> \n<p>When you've picked out your social test experiment, make sure you're imploring best practices so the results are helpful.</p> \n<h2>Social Testing Best Practices</h2> \n<p>Social media testing can be extremely helpful — if you're executing them correctly. Otherwise, your test could be inaccurate, immeasurable, and ultimately, a waste of time.</p> \n<p>The good news is that social tests aren't hard to create or run. The bad news is that if you aren't prepared to run one, your results won't be usable. Make sure that when you design your test, you follow these best practices:</p> \n<h3>1. Have one specific goal.</h3> \n<p>When your social test has one identifiable goal, everything else falls into place: variables, unit of measurement and time frame. To illustrate this, let's say your goal is to improve international engagement with your next Facebook ad.</p> \n<p>With that goal decided, you can create the variables, so you decide to run an A/B test to determine which copy earns the most impressions. You estimate that because your impression ads usually run for a month, half that time would give measurable results.</p> \n<p>You also know the direction of the ad, so <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-write-a-smart-goal-template?_ga=2.6424497.2001540731.1628802809-620318951.1628802809\"><span>your focused goal</span></a> makes it easier to know what to look for during analysis. Impressions, for example, would be the metric to look at for the Facebook ad mentioned earlier.</p> \n<h3>2. Know who your audiences are.</h3> \n<p>If you decide to conduct a social test, your data will reflect the behaviors of a specific target market and how they engage with your messaging.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Social testing is a great way to learn about the social media behavior of an audience segment. If you had little to no information about how your millennial audience would react to a new Instagram Story Ad, running a test would give you a data-driven answer.</p> \n<p>Without knowing your audience, your data wouldn't apply to a defined set of your target market. You’d have insight, but it would be unclear how results relate to your different <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/customers/how-to-segment-and-nurture-your-customers-with-hubspot?_ga=2.12210103.2001540731.1628802809-620318951.1628802809\"><span>audience segments</span></a>.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>3. Take note of your current performance.</h3> \n<p>Before you run the test, know how your current campaign is running or note previous results. Then, at the end of your experiment, you can compare results and make informed decisions. The previous report will give the background information and context needed to analyze the social test findings.</p> \n<p>Even if your marketing goals for your social test are different than previous campaigns, it's still a good idea to refer to them for context. For instance, you may be testing for conversions rather than retargeting, but having an idea of what audiences prefer helps you structure your campaign.</p> \n<h3>4. Monitor your test periodically.</h3> \n<p>Don't leave your test as soon as it begins — monitor it so you can adjust accordingly. A test that's running for a month, for example, should be checked regularly for performance benchmarks.</p> \n<p>If you use social test software or tools on social media channels, the report starts aggregating when your test starts. So, when you check-in, look at how you're tracking for your #1 goal. Additionally, take note of what other metrics you see and how they're performing.</p> \n<p>You might find, for instance, that your conversion rate is low. You can monitor conversions for the duration of the test or make a minor tweak to try to improve performance. For the subsequent check-ins, you'll have an additional metric to take into account.</p> \n<p>When the test concludes, you'll have the knowledge from previous checks to round out your perception of the completed report. Along with your intended goal, identify supporting metrics to understand how they work together.</p> \n<h3>5. Make your test timely.</h3> \n<p>How long should you run your test? Long enough to get the answer to your hypothesis. That doesn't tell you much, though, so let's add to that.</p> \n<p>Ideally, your test should run for at least seven days. A week is enough time for your social testing software to compile a basis of data. It won't be as concrete as a more extended test, but it's a starting point.</p> \n<p>After seven days, look at your performance and decide if you've gathered enough data to answer your hypothesis. If not, run the test for a few more days. Then, based on the nature of your campaign, fix the time frame to fit your business and your audience — but make sure you give yourself enough room for an actionable report.</p> \n<p>Picking a test duration period ensures you won't be wasting money and time. Instead of having a test run for too long or too little, figure out your time frame and budget during the planning process.</p> \n<p>So, with these best practices in mind, you're almost ready to run a successful social test. Before you get going, though, let's talk about where — and how — to do that.</p> \n<h2>Where can I run a social test?</h2> \n<p>There's a couple of avenues to explore when choosing where to run a social network test. If you're running a test specifically for social media, the channel you're using might have testing tools in their business software.</p> \n<p>Running social tests on the corresponding media platforms is helpful because you don't have to track different channels during the test. Additionally, you won't have to worry about misconstrued data a third party might provide.</p> \n<p>You can also run a social test using a CRM, like <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/?_ga=2.107030401.2001540731.1628802809-620318951.1628802809\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\"><span>HubSpot</span></a>. CRMs are a great choice if you want to test functions outside of social media — landing pages, emails, or other marketing activities. First, though, let's talk about social media offerings.</p> \n<h3>Facebook Social Testing</h3> \n<p>Facebook offers tools to run A/B and multivariate tests for ads. You can access these tests via <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/tools/ads-manager\">Ad Manager</a>. Ad Manager tells you which ads (or ad tests) are running and their status. When you click on a certain test, details and metrics open.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Social%20Testing.png\" alt=\"Facebook A/B testing\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>Multivariate tests on Facebook are similar, except they can be found in the Experiments section of your <a href=\"https://business.facebook.com/\">Facebook Business</a> account. Though the social tests are located in different places, the process for setting them up is largely the same.</p> \n<p>Social testing on Facebook is intuitive, especially if you're used to running Facebook Ads. After clicking \"Create Ad,\" you'll be taken through a series of prompts to create, set metrics, and pick an audience. When you fill in the details, you publish it, and wait for the results.</p> \n<p>Start small if you're getting the hang of things. Its features are customizable, so the choice is yours in terms of time frame, audience, copy, testing options, and metrics. As your familiarity grows, tests can be scaled.</p> \n<p>As an example, after running a social test on Facebook, bone broth brand Kettle &amp; Fire found a <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/success/kettle-and-fire\">14 point increase in brand awareness</a>. The marketing team wanted to raise online sales with a video campaign, and wanted to find out which video length was favored by customers.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Social%20Testing-3.png\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"Kettle &amp; Fire Facebook social media A/B Test example\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/success/kettle-and-fire\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>In a little less than a month, a 1.5 lift in purchasing consideration and sales conversions from the short video led to the answer. A Facebook test saved the team ad spend and informed them about their audience's Facebook preferences.</p> \n<p>Facebook delivers social testing results in a downloadable report. The software determines the winner based on the metric(s) you chose when creating the test. For information about running a Facebook social testing, check out this post about testing on the platform.</p> \n<h3>Twitter Social Testing</h3> \n<p>Social testing on Twitter leads to creating tweets audiences will interact with and enjoy. You'll identify how they use the platform and know how to cater to their needs. Twitter's testing tools are best fit for creative, targeting, and brand awareness campaigns.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Social%20Testing-Jun-29-2020-09-51-43-58-PM.png\" alt=\"A Twitter A/B social media test example\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/success/kettle-and-fire\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>Twitter lets you social test Ads in an A/B format. To do this, after publishing the ad, go back into <a href=\"https://ads.twitter.com/\">Ads</a>, duplicate it, make the change, and publish the new variable. Track performance from the Tweet Activity Dashboard and campaign dashboard.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Note that there's no way to set an official test using Twitter, so you'll have to analyze the data yourself. For instance, if you want to see if your new brand voice is taking flight, you'll probably want to look at the amount of clicks and impressions your Ad earned.</p> \n<h3>LinkedIn Social Testing</h3> \n<p>If you're not used to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/linkedin-advertising-campaigns?_ga=2.254609416.1220074992.1593395332-940436819.1565181751\">LinkedIn Ads</a>, there's several different types. They're sorted based on campaign goal, like Conversion, or type of ad, like Carousel, Text, or Sponsored. It's a great idea to test LinkedIn Ads for promoting — your brand, event, or job listing.</p> \n<p>Dynamic Ads, which show up on the ride side of a user's main feed are highly personalized. Under Dynamic Ads, there's several versions: Follower, Job, Content, and Spotlight. These versions specify what the goal of your ad is — so if you want to let audiences know your company is hiring, you would run a Dynamic Job Ad.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Social%20Testing-2.png\" alt=\"\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>If you wanted to make a similar Dynamic Job Ad on LinkedIn, you can run a test to see if your listing ad is compelling to job seekers. You'll have the option to test image layouts, such as the company photo, copy, and central images, if applicable.</p> \n<p>LinkedIn's marketing team uses social testing for content and event promotion, as well as <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/account-based-marketing-guide?_ga=2.254609416.1220074992.1593395332-940436819.1565181751\">account-based marketing</a>. They ran a test for a webinar Dynamic Ad to gauge if audiences preferred an image of the speaker or the company's logo. According to one of LinkedIn's senior marketing managers, Cassandra Clark, results included a <a href=\"https://business.linkedin.com/content/dam/me/business/en-us/marketing-solutions/products/pdfs/LinkedIn-IG-DynamicAds-Final.pdf\">326% lift in click-through rate</a> in the ad with the speaker.</p> \n<p>To access ad results, check your Conversion Tracking dashboard, which will show you page and audience activity from your ads. While LinkedIn doesn't have a formal testing feature, they do have an option for you to duplicate and tweak a portion of an ad, like Twitter.</p> \n<h3>CRM Social Testing</h3> \n<p>If you're not running a test on a social media channel, using a CRM is another worthwhile option. With a CRM, you can set up tests for website content, like landing pages.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>In HubSpot, you can run social tests for web pages simply by accessing your dashboard and going to one of your web pages. Click the \"Actions\" hyperlink next to one of your pages, and you'll find the option to \"Run a test.\"</p> \n<p>HubSpot lets you run an A/B or multivariate (Adaptive) test. As you're creating your test, you'll have the option to look at testing tips, like figuring out what to test. Since HubSpot has a drag-and-drop editor, and tons of modules to choose from, you'll have plenty of options. In the past, I've run tests for CTA buttons, images, headline copy, body text, and landing page layout through social media.</p> \n<p>It's commonplace for CRMs to have tools for running social testing. Some offer a niche version of social testing; for instance, <a href=\"https://mailchimp.com/\">MailChimp's</a> are for emails. When you decide to use a CRM for testing, do some research to determine which one will offer you the tools you need to succeed.</p> \n<p>But, if you don't know where to begin looking for software that offers social testing, here's a list of tools for your benefit.</p> \n<h3>1. HubSpot</h3> \n<p><strong>Price: </strong><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/pricing/marketing?term=annual&amp;edition=starter&amp;_ga=2.81920533.2001540731.1628802809-620318951.1628802809\">Free plan, or $800 for Marketing Hub Professional</a></p> \n<p>With HubSpot's CRM, you can run A/B and multivariate tests. The tools are part of HubSpot's Marketing Software and are included in the Marketing Hub Professional and Enterprise plans. You can use HubSpot to test landing pages that are promoted through social media.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Social%20Testing-Jun-29-2020-09-51-44-13-PM.png\" alt=\"HubSpot testing screens\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>The CRM's drag-and-drop editor makes it easy to configure variables for tests. In addition, you’ll have optimization features to make your page shareable and user-friendly, like social media badges. That way, when you promote the page on socials, your followers can share them with one click.</p> \n<p>HubSpot's testing tool is accessible from the landing page dashboard via \"Run a test\" from the drop-down menu. From there, you can choose your test type and get started. If you want an easy-to-use platform that lets you create and analyze social tests, HubSpot is a great choice.</p> \n<h3>2. OptinMonster</h3> \n<p><strong>Price:</strong> <a href=\"https://optinmonster.com/pricing/\">Free plan, or $19-49/mo.</a></p> \n<p>OptinMonster is a CRM that also offers built-in testing software. You can run A/B or split tests to increase conversions over time with tools that let you experiment with content, headlines, campaign triggers, styles, and layouts.</p> \n<p>Once you set up the test, you can leave the software to do the work. It'll show your test content to website visitors and collect data on conversion rates. Your report will determine the number of impressions, acquisitions, and page visits.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Social%20Testing-Jun-29-2020-09-51-43-91-PM.png\" alt=\"social media testing tool Optinmonster A/B test results example\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><span style=\"font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://optinmonster.com/docs/how-to-enable-test-mode/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></span></p> \n<p>You can use OptinMonster's testing tool to test social media landing pages. Test the landing page’s effectiveness for your next ebook offer before it's published on LinkedIn first. If you want a platform that offers intuitive tools for social testing, try OptinMonster.</p> \n<h3>3. Optimizely</h3> \n<p><strong>Price:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.optimizely.com/plans/\">Case-by-case basis, contact sales for pricing</a></p> \n<p>If you're heavily promoting your website on social media, test it to learn how it performs among your audience. One way you can do that is with Optimizely, which provides marketing software solutions.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Social%20Testing-4.png\" alt=\"Optimizely social media testing tool multivariate test example\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://www.optimizely.com/customers/comscore/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>Optimzely's tools let you perform split and multivariate tests. Optimizely will count the number of website visitors and the metrics you pick, such as engagement, goals, conversions, and clicks. You'll be able to apply custom audience segments that can be filtered based on social proof performance.</p> \n<h3>4. Leadpages</h3> \n<p><strong>Price:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.leadpages.com/pricing/compare-plans?gclid=EAIaIQobChMI2craiJid6gIVj4TICh0K_wJhEAAYASABEgJTaPD_BwE\">Free, or $48-$199/mo.</a></p> \n<p>If you want a tool specifically for testing landing pages you promote on social media, try Leadpages. This is software that was made just for building professional landing pages. You can use the split testing feature with the tool.</p> \n<p>When you run split tests with Leadpages, you'll be able to access its analytics the minute it aggregates traffic and engagements. At the conclusion, you'll get a report that includes the total and unique visits, conversions and total conversion rate. Your report will also include specific insights about test variations.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Social%20Testing-1.png\" alt=\"example of social media testing with Leadpages A/B landing page test tool\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://www.leadpages.com/pricing/compare-plans?gclid=EAIaIQobChMI2craiJid6gIVj4TICh0K_wJhEAAYASABEgJTaPD_BwE\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>Keep in mind that you can't set a time frame for your tests. From the analytics dashboard, you'll be able to see how many days your test has been running. When you're ready for the test to be complete, you'll have to end it manually.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>5. Inspectlet</h3> \n<p><strong>Price:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.inspectlet.com/plans\">Free, or $39-$499/mo.</a></p> \n<p>Inspectlet was created just for testing. It's a software that lets you test multiple different content types, including web pages. You can also create content variations for future social tests, like edited graphics.</p> \n<p>The visual editor in Inspectlet makes it easy to code or create different pages. You can change your page's design or code in real-time and access analytics as soon as the test begins. Inspectlet lets you track views, page elements, unique visitors, and custom events.</p> \n<p>When you access your performance report, you'll get the metrics based on the goals you set. This can be anything from tracking clicks, user engagement, custom events, or URL views. Basically, anything that you can track with the software can be measured.</p> \n<p>Now, you have a couple of options separate from social media sites that you can social test with. With this in mind, you're ready to run the test.</p> \n<p>Think back to the example in the beginning of the post. Knowing all you do about social testing now, you're fully equipped to run a video engagement experiment of your own. Will it be on a social channel or with testing software?</p> \n<p>One of the many great things about social testing is how creative they can be — you can social test just about any piece of content, and social media sites are starting to make that process easy. Testing your social ads ensures you're providing the most value to your customers, and now, you can.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=1fb2d19e-9ff9-40a7-947e-cc67e7d472cb&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \"
